Title: Copolymerization of cationic monomers with acrylamide in an aqueous solution
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerizations of commercially available cationic monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with acrylamide (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) have been investigated at pH 6.1 in aqueous solutions. The cationic groups in copolymers were analyzed by a colloid titration method and the reactivity ratios were determined by the Fineman–Ross method. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were 1.71 and 0.25 for methacryloyloxyethyltrimethylammonium chlorideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.68 and 1.26 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminoethylmethacrylateM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.13 and 0.57 for methacrylamidopropyltrimethylammonium chlorideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 1.10 and 0.47 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminopropylmethacrylateM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.47 and 0.95 for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylaminopropylacrylamideM<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, 0.48 and 0.64 for acryloyloxyethyltrimethylammonium chloride‐M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and 0.58 and 6.7 for dimethyldiallylammonium chloride‐M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> systems. The Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were calculated and the linear relationship between log <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and ultraviolet absorption maxima of cationic monomers was found.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios of N‐octadecylacrylamide and N‐allylstearamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 60 ± 0.1°C. were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.44 ± 0.019, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.10 ± 0.035; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.60, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.20; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.37 ± 0.008, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.438 ± 0.008; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.65, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.11 ± 0.045, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.027 ± 0.009; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.72, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12. The mean copolymerization parameters, therefore, were <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.66, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.13. The reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ally lstearamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers, polymerized in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 80 ± 0.1°C. (except for vinyl acetate, polymerized in bulk at 70 ± 0.1°C.) were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.118 ± 0.084, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 3.61 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.058; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0 ± 0.136, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 5.23 ± 0.067; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.028, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.80; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.0532 ± 0.012, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.740 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −1.18. The mean copolymerization parameters for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐allylstearamide were, therefore, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.59.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios of N‐octadecylacrylamide and N‐allylstearamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 60 ± 0.1°C. were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.44 ± 0.019, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.10 ± 0.035; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.60, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.20; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.37 ± 0.008, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.438 ± 0.008; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.65, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.11 ± 0.045, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.027 ± 0.009; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.72, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.12. The mean copolymerization parameters, therefore, were <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.66, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.13. The reactivity ratios and the corresponding copolymerization parameters for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐ally lstearamide (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and several monomers, polymerized in <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol at 80 ± 0.1°C. (except for vinyl acetate, polymerized in bulk at 70 ± 0.1°C.) were determined and were: with acrylonitrile, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.118 ± 0.084, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 3.61 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.058; <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21; with vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0 ± 0.136, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 5.23 ± 0.067; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.028, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.80; with vinyl acetate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.0532 ± 0.012, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.740 ± 0.087; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −1.18. The mean copolymerization parameters for <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐allylstearamide were, therefore, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.043, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.59.</jats:p>

Title: Use of n.m.r. data to calculate copolymer reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Analysis of the linear methods of determining copolymerization reactivity ratios, 10. Estimation of errors and planning of experiments in penultimate systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>For a recently proposed new linearization method of the two‐parameter penultimate model (monomer M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> does not homopolymerize, i.e. <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0), an estimation of confidence intervals for both parameters <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ is presented. A procedure of minimizing the experimental error in both parameters was developed according to statistical planning of experiments. In analogy to the already existing procedure of planning (classical model) an “efficiency factor” of planning, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>, was introduced, which makes it possible to estimate the quality of planning for a given series of copolymerization experiments.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of alkyl methacrylates with triallyl cyanurate. Determination of monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of propyl, pentyl, hexyl, heptyl, octyl, and dodecyl methacrylates with triallyl cyanurate was investigated. The reactivity ratios were determined using the methods of Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös. The Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for the methacrylates were also evaluated. The effect of the length of alkyl group in methacrylates on reactivity ratios is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic Study of the Free Radical Copolymerization of Methyl Methacrylate with 2-Perfluorooctyl Ethyl Methacrylate by Quantum Computational Approach
Abstract: <jats:p xml:lang="en">Fluorinated copolymers with perfluoroalkyl side chains have widespread use in applications requiring superior technology due to their unique surface properties. Kinetic analysis of copolymerization of fluorinated acrylates with conventional acrylates is necessary to synthesize such copolymers efficiently. However, kinetic investigation of such reactions are limited in the literature due to the experimental difficulties. In this study, the kinetic of copolymerization of methyl methacrylate with 2-perfluorooctyl ethyl methacrylate in toluene medium using AIBN initiator was investigated using quantum chemistry postulates as an alternative to experimental methods. Reaction rate constants (kp) for propagation were determined using transition state theory. A terminal effect models were used to examine four different addition reactions involving monomeric and dimeric radicals and monomers for both self- and cross-propagation. Reactant and product conformations were optimized with a DFT method using PBE0 function. The Evans-Polanyi relationship was used to calculate the rate of self- and cross-propagation of monomers. The results showed that the reactivity ratio of 2-perfluorooctyl ethyl methacrylate was found to be higher than that of methyl methacrylate. In addition, it was observed that the reaction conditions caused the random polymer structure due to the different rate constants in self and cross propagation.</jats:p>

Title: A method for determining reactivity ratios whenn copolymerizations are influenced by penultimate group effects
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Effects of temperature on styrene–methacrylonitrile copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and methacrylonitrile was studied in toluene solution at 60, 90, and 120°C. Copolymer composition was estimated from gas‐chromatographic measurement of unreacted monomer concentrations. Reactions were carried to about 20% conversion to minimize analytical errors. Reactivity ratios were calculated by using an integrated form of the Mayo‐Lewis simple copolymerization equation. Reactivity ratios were not sensitive to reaction temperature. The values at 90°C are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.41 (methacrylonitrile) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.37 (styrene). The <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> values are higher than those reported by other workers, presumably because of advantages in the present analytical technique and calculation method. The negligible temperature dependence of reactivity ratios is in accord with theory. If monomer pairs exhibit pronounced dependence of reactivity ratios on polymerization temperature, this may indicate a change in mode of placement of units in the polymer chain.</jats:p>

Title: Study of radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with ethylene in suspension
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene (TFE) with ethylene (E) was initiated by 2,2′‐azo‐bis‐isobutyronitrile in batch and semibatch operation. The effect of reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, stirring speed, molar ratio of monomers, etc.) on copolymerization rate and copolymer molecular weight was studied. The highest reaction rate was observed at TFE content over 70 mol % and was found to be proportional to initiator concentration and total monomer content by powers of 0.9 and 1.54, respectively. These dependencies were attributed to the heterophase character of the copolymerization.</jats:p><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and overall activation energy of the reaction were determined. The effect of the monomer composition on the distribution of monomer units in the copolymer chain was studied. Kinetic mechanism of the copolymerization was suggested.</jats:p><jats:p>Some of the basic physical properties and chemical resistance of the alternating copolymers synthesized were also determined. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Study of radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with ethylene in suspension
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene (TFE) with ethylene (E) was initiated by 2,2′‐azo‐bis‐isobutyronitrile in batch and semibatch operation. The effect of reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, stirring speed, molar ratio of monomers, etc.) on copolymerization rate and copolymer molecular weight was studied. The highest reaction rate was observed at TFE content over 70 mol % and was found to be proportional to initiator concentration and total monomer content by powers of 0.9 and 1.54, respectively. These dependencies were attributed to the heterophase character of the copolymerization.</jats:p><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios and overall activation energy of the reaction were determined. The effect of the monomer composition on the distribution of monomer units in the copolymer chain was studied. Kinetic mechanism of the copolymerization was suggested.</jats:p><jats:p>Some of the basic physical properties and chemical resistance of the alternating copolymers synthesized were also determined. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Comparative recalculation of the monomer reactivity ratios in copolymerization for styrene and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios (MMRs) in radical copolymerization for styrene and methyl methacrylate were recalculated by five different methods using literature copolymerization data. The use of approximate 95% confidence limits and their visual inspection helps to separate possibly biased copolymer composition data. The recalculated mean MRR values were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (styrene) = 0.501 ± 0.031 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.472 ± 0.031. The results of the linear least‐squares calculation procedures seldom approach the quality of the nonlinear least‐squares analysis according to the method of Tidwell and Mortimer.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity of methacrylates in anionic copolymerization with methyl methacrylate by n‐BuLi
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were determined in the anionic copolymerizations of methyl methacrylate (MMA, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with ethyl (EtMA), isopropyl (<jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐PrMA), <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl (t‐BuMA), benzyl (BzMA), α‐methylbenzyl (MBMA), diphenylmethyl (DPMMA), α,α‐dimethylbenzyl (DMBMA), and trityl (TrMA) methacrylates (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) by use of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BuLi as an initiator in toluene and THF at ‐78°C. The order of the reactivity of the monomers towards MMA anion was DPMMA > BzMA > MMA > EtMA > MBMA > <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐PrMA > <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BuMA > TrMA > DMBMA in toluene and TrMA > BzMA > MMA > DPMMA > EtMA > MBMA > <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐PrMA > DMBMA > <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BuMA in THF. Except for the extremely low reactivity of TrMA and DPMMA in toluene due to steric hindrance, the order was explained in terms of the polar effect of the ester groups. A linear relationship was found between log (1/<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and Taft's σ* values of the ester groups, where the ρ* value was 1.1. The plots of log (1/<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) vs. the <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H<jats:sub>a</jats:sub> (<jats:italic>cis</jats:italic> to the carbonyl) and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C<jats:sub>ß</jats:sub> chemical shifts of the monomers were also on straight lines. The polymer obtained in the copolymerization of MMA with TrMA in toluene by <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BuLi at ‐78°C was a mixture of poly‐MMA and a copolymer, suggesting that there exist two kinds of growing centers.</jats:p>

Title: Solution copolymerization of styrene and 2‐hydroxyethyl mechacrylate.
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The rate of solution copolymerization of styrene (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was investigated by dilatometry. <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethyl formamide, toluene, isopropyl alcohol, and butyl alcohol were used as solvents. Polymerization was initiated by α,α′‐azobisisobutyronitrile at 60°C. The initial copolymerization rate increased nonlinearly with increasing 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA)/styrene ratio. The copolymerization rate was promoted by solvents containing hydroxyl groups. Two different approaches were used for the prediction of copolymerization rates. The relationships proposed for the copolymerization rates calculation involve the effects of the total monomer concentration, mole fraction of HEMA, and of the solvent type. Different reactivity ratios were found in polar and nonpolar solvents: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.53, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.59 in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethyl formamide, isopropyl alcohol and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.50, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.65 in toluene. The usability of these reactivity ratios was confirmed by batch experiments.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios of some monomer pairs
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To continue the study of the effect of structure on reactivity, an experimental investigation of the free radical copolymerization behavior of eight monomer pairs has been made. The monomer pairs include: vinyl acetate‐methyl vinyl ketone; vinyl acetate‐1,3‐acetoxybutadiene; acrylonitrile‐1,3‐acetoxybutadiene; methylacrolein‐acrylonitrile; vinylsulfonic acid‐methyl methacrylate; 2,5‐dichlorostyrene‐2,5‐dimethylstyrene; vinyl acetate‐fumaryl chloride; and styrene‐fumaryl chloride.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios of some monomer pairs
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To continue the study of the effect of structure on reactivity, an experimental investigation of the free radical copolymerization behavior of eight monomer pairs has been made. The monomer pairs include: vinyl acetate‐methyl vinyl ketone; vinyl acetate‐1,3‐acetoxybutadiene; acrylonitrile‐1,3‐acetoxybutadiene; methylacrolein‐acrylonitrile; vinylsulfonic acid‐methyl methacrylate; 2,5‐dichlorostyrene‐2,5‐dimethylstyrene; vinyl acetate‐fumaryl chloride; and styrene‐fumaryl chloride.</jats:p>

Title: The Reactivities of Nuclear-Substituted Phenyl Methacrylates in Radical Copolymerization with Styrene
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In order to clarify the effects of the alkyl substituents on the reactivities of methacrylate monomers toward the attack of a radical, the copolymerizations of a series of nuclear-substituted phenyl methacrylates with styrene were investigated. From the results, the monomer reactivity ratios and the Alfrey-Price Q, and e values were determined. It was found that the relative reactivities toward the polystyryl radical were not correlated with the ordinary Hammett equation, but a linear relationship was obtained with a modified Hammett equation which contained a term of the resonance contribution by the substituents. Accordingly, it was considered that the reactivities of substituted phenyl methacrylates depend on both polar and resonance effects caused by the substituents.</jats:p>

Title: A kinetic study of free‐radical copolymerization of butyl acrylate with methyl methacrylate in solution
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free‐radical copolymerization at 50°C of butyl acrylate with methyl methacrylate was carried out in benzene solution using 3 and 5 mol/L as the overall concentration of monomers. Both the reactivity ratios and the rate coefficients of copolymerization are affected by the total monomer concentration. Reactivity ratios were analyzed on the basis of the “bootstrap” model, and the copolymerization rate is interpreted assuming a penultimate effect upon the propagation reaction.</jats:p>

Title: Determination o f the reactivity ratios in terpolymerization on the example of acrylic acid - styrene - acrylonitrile system
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: An Error in Variables Method for Determining the Implicit Penultimate Copolymerization Ratios by On‐Line Monitoring of Reactions
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:bold>Summary:</jats:bold> In copolymerization systems with implicit penultimate effect, there are two radical reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic>, which influence the reaction kinetics in addition to the monomer reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic>, which govern the copolymer composition. Here, an error in variables method has been developed to determine <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> and <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic>. It is based on continuous on‐line monitoring of the polymerization process, where monomer and polymer concentrations are measured through the monitoring of two independent properties of the system. The ratios and the corresponding <jats:italic>χ</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> values were found by taking into account errors emanating from measurements and from calibration of the instruments. It is shown that the kinetic data allows both ratios to be found if both monomer reactivity ratios are less than one. If the system is near ideality (<jats:italic>r<jats:sub>a</jats:sub>r<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> ≅ 1) or if both reactivities are greater than one, only an average radical reactivity ratio, <jats:styled-content>$\overline s$<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-ueqn-1.gif" xlink:title="equation image" /></jats:styled-content>, can be reliably determined.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:caption><jats:p>The 2<jats:italic>σ</jats:italic> confidence contours for the 3 individual experiments. The reactivity ratios are <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.5, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.2, <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.3, <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.4. For clarity the contours are plotted as functions of 1/<jats:italic>s<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> and 1/<jats:italic>s<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic>.</jats:p></jats:caption><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text><jats:caption><jats:p>The 2<jats:italic>σ</jats:italic> confidence contours for the 3 individual experiments. The reactivity ratios are <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.5, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.2, <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.3, <jats:italic>s<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.4. For clarity the contours are plotted as functions of 1/<jats:italic>s<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> and 1/<jats:italic>s<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic>.</jats:p></jats:caption></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of styrene with vinyl acetate using p‐acetylbenzylidene triphenylarsonium ylide as an initiator
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Acetylbenzylidene triphenylarsonium ylide (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐ABTAY) initiated free radical copolymerization of styrene (Sty) with vinyl acetate (VA) in dioxane, at 65 ± 0.1°C, under the inert atmosphere of nitrogen has been studied. The system follows ideal radical kinetics and the kinetic equation for the system is <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> ∝ [<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐ABTAY]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup>[Sty][VA]. The rate of copolymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) is proportional to the square root of [<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐ABTAY] indicating biomolecular termination. The values of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> and energy of activation have been computed as 5.0 × 10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> mol l<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and 34.0 kJ mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> respectively. The reactivity ratios calculated by using Kelen–Tudos method are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>(Sty) = 42.8, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(VA) = 1.0. SEM analysis shows that arsenic is not incorporated in the polymer and the copolymerization reaction is initiated by phenyl free radicals. The formation of phenyl radicals may be attributed to the pπ–dπ overlap between the hybridized sp<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> orbital and more diffused 4d orbital of arsenic. © 2002 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Adv Polym Techn 21: 108–115, 2002; Published online in Wiley Interscience (www.interscience.wiley.com). DOI 10.1002/adv.2000</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate with butyl methacrylate: determination of monomer reactivity ratios and glass transition temperatures
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Reactivity ratios for vinyl stearate–vinyl acetate copolymers
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Determination of monomer reactivity ratios using in situ FTIR spectroscopy for maleic anhydride/norbornene‐free‐radical copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios for maleic anhydride (MAH) and norbornene (Nb) free‐radical copolymerizations were estimated by using a linear graphical method, which is based upon the terminal model developed by Mayo and Lewis. Reactions were performed by using optimized reaction conditions that were previously determined. MAH/Nb copolymerizations (3 mol % AIBN initiator, 60% solids in THF, 65°C, 24 h). Copolymerization data were collected via <jats:italic>in situ</jats:italic> FTIR to low degrees of conversion (∼ 10%) for copolymerizations of MAH and Nb. The following five different MAH/Nb comonomer feed molar ratios were analyzed: 40/60, 45/55, 50/50, 55/45, and 60/40. Conversion data that were measured with <jats:italic>in situ</jats:italic> FTIR were employed in the rearranged copolymer composition equation to estimate MAH and Nb reactivity ratios. Both of the reactivity ratios were determined to be near 0 (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAH</jats:sub> = 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Nb</jats:sub> = 0.01), which was indicative of an alternating copolymerization mechanism. The highest observed rate constant for copolymerization was obtained at an equal molar concentration of monomers. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 92: 3240–3246, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene with methyl-substituted styrenes in the presence of titanium monometallocenes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This paper investigates the homo- and copolymerization of styrene with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>-methylstyrene, <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>-methylstyrene, 2,4-dimethylstyrene, 2,5-dimethylstyrene and 2,4,6-trimethylstyrene using a Cp*TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> (Cp: cyclopentadienyl) semimetallocene catalyst activated with methylaluminoxane. Syndiotactic homo- and copolymers were obtained only for the monosubstituted monomers. For the di- or trisubstituted monomers, reduced reactivities, stereoregularities, and degrees of polymerization were obtained with respect to the monosubstituted monomers. More specifically, the homopolymerization of 2,5-dimethylstyrene and 2,4,6-trimethylstyrene and their copolymerization with styrene was inhibited. The reason for this are combined steric and inductive effects. The presence of methyl groups in <jats:italic>para </jats:italic>position seems to inhibit crystallization of the syndiotactic polymers. In contrast, crystallinity was evidenced in the materials produced in the presence of <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>-methyl substituted monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Study of radical copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene with ethylene in bulk
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization of tetrafluorethylene (TFE) with ethylene (E) by azo‐<jats:italic>bis</jats:italic>‐iso‐butyronitrile in the temperature interval 333–363 K, monomer pressure from 3.0 to 7.0 MPa at TFE/E molar ratio from 77/23 to 23/77 in bulk was carried out. The effect of reaction conditions on the yield, molecular weight, and polymer composition of copolymer synthesized was studied. White powdery alternating copolymers were obtained at TFE content in the monomer mixture from 65 to 85 mol %. Copolymerization rate <jats:italic>R</jats:italic> was described by the equation <jats:italic>R</jats:italic> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:sub>[ln] [Σ <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>]<jats:sup>1.3</jats:sup> which was related to the heterophase character of the reaction. The reactivity ratio of TFE and E (0.067 ± 0.12 and 0.52 ± 0.18, respectively) and apparent activation energy <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub> = 135 kJ/mol were found. The TFE and E block formation probabilities were calculated and compared with IR spectroscopy data. Melting point, entropy, and enthalpy of fusion of the entirely alternating copolymers were determined. Some of the basic properties of the alternating copolymers obtained were also studied. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization and copolymers of N‐(2,4,6‐tribromophenyl)maleimide with methyl acrylate and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(2,4,6‐Tribromophenyi)maleimide (TBPMI) was copolymerized with methyl acrylate (MA) or methyl methacrylate (MMA) in toluene solution using 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile as free‐radical initiation. The copolymerization reactivity ratios were found to be for the system TBPMI/MA <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,095 ± 0,045 (TBPMI) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2,17 ± 0,142 (MA) and for the system TBPMI/MMA <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,037 ± 0,042 (TBPMI) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4,32 ± 0,230 (MMA); <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were also calculated. The initial rate of copolymerization, <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>, for TBPMI/MA sharply decreases as the content of TBPMI in the monomer mixture increases but the composition of the feed does not have a strong influence on <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> for the TBPMI/MMA copolymerization system. The course of copolymerization to high conversion is characterized by an increase of conversion up to a mole fraction of TBPMI of 0,7 in the monomer mixture, when MA was used as the comonomer. An opposite behaviour was found with MMA. Its copolymers show a considerable increase of thermal stability as well as of the glass transition temperatures with increasing TBPMI content.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics of ylide‐initiated radical copolymerization of 4‐vinylpyridine and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The ylide‐initiated radical copolymerization of 4‐vinylpyridine (4‐VP) with methyl methacrylate (MMA) at 60°C using carbon tetrachloride as inert solvent yields non‐alternating copolymers. The kinetic parameters, average rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) and orders of reaction with respect to monomers and initiator, have been evaluated and the kinetic equation is found to be <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>α[ylide]<jats:sup>0.94</jats:sup> [MMA]<jats:sup>1.0</jats:sup> [4‐VP]<jats:sup>1.5</jats:sup>. The values of the energy of activation and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> are 48 kJ mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and 6.6 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> litre mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, respectively. The copolymers have been characterized by IR and NMR spectroscopy.</jats:p>

Title: A new method of estimating monomer reactivity ratios in copolymerization by linear regression methods
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Sequential gas‐liquid chromotographic analysis of the reaction mixture throughout a copolymerization reaction in conjuction with the improved curve‐fitting <jats:italic>I</jats:italic> (integrated form) method, which accounts for measurements errors in both variables, allows accurate estimation of the monomer reactivity ratios. In this article an alternative method is presented for estimating <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values in copolymerization with linear regression only, which is especially suited to cases in which one or two of the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values is close to 1. In these cases the improved curve‐fitting <jats:italic>I</jats:italic> method tends to converge slowly because of the numerical instability of the integrated copolymerization equation. The use of the new method is illustrated for the estimation of the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values for ethylene and vinyl acatate in benzene at 35 kg/cm<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> and 62°C. The linear regression method was also tried on other copolymerizations and the results are compared with those obtained from the improved curve‐fitting <jats:italic>I</jats:italic> method. The limits of the applicability of the linear regression method were determined by simulated sequential sampling experiments. It appears that the new method is applicable when the product of the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values is between 0.001 and 2, provided both monomer conversions are large enough compared with the measurements error.</jats:p>

Title: An improved method of calculating copolymerization reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A nonlinear least‐squares method for solving for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> the copolymerization reactivity ratios, is explained. This new method is superior to all other methods that have been used heretofore in the following ways: (<jats:italic>1</jats:italic>) a unique pair of values is obtained which does not depend on the judgment of the person examining the data; (<jats:italic>2</jats:italic>) this pair of values can be shown mathematically to be the best pair obtainable from the data at hand; (<jats:italic>3</jats:italic>) the errors are quantitatively defined in meaningful terms: and (<jats:italic>4</jats:italic>) the data are checked to see how well they fit the copolymer equation. A basis for selecting experimental conditions which will provide data from which precise values of the reactivity ratios can be obtained is explained, and experimental conditions appropriate for obtaining these precise values over a wide range of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values are presented in tabular form.</jats:p>

Title: Alternating copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and maleic anhydride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Alternating copolymers of α‐methylstyrene (α‐MeSt) and maleic anhydride (MAn) were prepared by free‐radical‐initiated polymerization in bulk, benzene, or butanone as solvents. By applying the generalized model described by Shirota and co‐workers, the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>1c</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>2c</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> were calculated from the change of copolymerization rate with monomer feed at constant total monomer concentration. From the equation <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(f) + <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(CT) were calculated <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(f) and <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>(CT), and it was found that in benzene the reaction proceeds predominantly by the addition of CT‐complex monomers, while in butanone, cross propagation of free monomers predominates. Termination occurs predominantly by homotermination of α‐MeSt macro free radicals, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t22</jats:sub>, although the cross termination <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t21</jats:sub> is also operative.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios and copolymer composition evolution during styrene/dimethacrylate free‐radical crosslinking copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In this article, experimental and simulated results are presented for the evolution of the copolymer composition as unsaturations are consumed in the free‐radical cross‐linking copolymerization of Styrene(St) and BisphenolA glycerolate dimethacrylate (BDMA). Real time FTIR measurements were performed to monitor the depletion of each comonomer double bond during the isothermal curing reaction at 80°C. From the experimental data corresponding to different feed compositions, the initial reactivity ratios and their evolution with conversion were determined via a nonlinear least squares optimization of the integrated form of the copolymerization equation. The reactivity ratio of St increases continuously and exponentially with the overall reaction conversion, while that of BDMA decreases linearly. A modified terminal copolymerization model including the dependence of the reactivity ratios with the overall conversion was proposed. The application of this model provides a consistent fitting for the conversion of each comonomer during all reaction stages, even at high conversion values where large diffusion and topological restrictions for chain movements are present. Simulations show that the concentration of styrene units added to the copolymer increases with the overall reaction conversion, while that for the BDMA double bonds diminishes. Structures rich in homopolymerized styrene are predicted at later stages of the reaction.© 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2010</jats:p>

Title: Solution copolymerization of alkyl methacrylates and N–vinyl carbazole: Reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of ethyl methacrylate and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl carbazole was studied at 60°C, using AIBN as the initiator. The reactivity ratios of the monomers were determined in benzene, ethyl acetate, acetone or (<jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>–dimethylformamide) solutions. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were calculated by the Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdös methods and were compared with those obtained earlier in bulk copolymerization.</jats:p>

Title: The temperature dependence of the monomer reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of styrene with methyl and ethyl cinnamates
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of fluorinated acrylic monomers with p‐vinylphenol and hydroxyethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylphenol were prepared in bulk with heptafluorobutyl and pentadecafluorooctyl acrylates and trifluoroethyl, hexafluoroisopropyl, heptafluorobutyl, octafluoropentyl and pentadecafluorooctyl methacrylates using azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator in sealed tubes. Intrinsic viscosities of the copolymers ranged from 0.44 to 1.85. Monomer reactivity ratios for copolymers of trifluoroethyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were: with hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.47, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.0; with methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.82, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.50; with styrene (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.29, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, = 0.20; and with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylphenol (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.096, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.5. <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of trifluoroethyl methacrylate were 1.30 and 0.92, respectively. Monomer reactivity ratios of octafluoropentyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were: with styrene (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.26, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.20; and with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylphenol, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.21, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.5. <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for octafluoropentyl methacrylate were 1.27 and 0.92, respectively. Critical surface tensions of the homopolymers ranged from 17.9 to 14.8 dyn/cm. A copolymer of hexafluoro‐<jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐propyl methacrylate and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinylphenol exhibited a critical surface tension of 16.5 dyn/cm.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and characterization of (allylamine hydrochloride-vinyl sulfonic acid) copolymer and determination of monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Well‐controlled radical copolymerization of styrene with 2‐[(perfluorononenyl)oxy] ethyl methacrylate and characterization of its copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The atom transfer radical copolymerization of styrene with 2‐[(perfluorononenyl)oxy] ethyl methacrylate was performed in benzotrifluoride at 100 °C in the presence of 1‐bromoethyl benzene (1‐BrEB), cuprous bromide (CuBr), and α,α′‐bipyridine (bpy; [1‐BrEB]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[CuBr]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[bpy]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> = 1/1/3). The experimental results demonstrate that this polymerization proceeded in a living fashion, producing fluorinated random copolymers with narrow polydispersities, controlled molecular weights, and desired unit ratios. The compositions of the copolymers were calculated from <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectra. The monomer reactivity ratios were obtained with the Skeist integral method. The copolymers were characterized by gel permeation chromatography, Fourier transform infrared, and differential scanning calorimetry. The solid surface characteristics of the copolymers were evaluated with contact‐angle measurements. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 39: 2670–2676, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Correction to Recommendation for Accurate Experimental Determination of Reactivity Ratios in Chain Copolymerization

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 2‐hydroxyalkyl methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 2‐hydroxyethyl‐ (HEMA) and 2‐hydroxypropyl‐methacrylate (HPMA) has been studied in two media: dimethylformamide (DMF) and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), at 60°C. Copolymer composition was determined from the hydroxyl content and reactivity ratios were calculated by the Kelen‐Tüdös method. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> computed by the integrated and the Kelen‐Tüdös methods have been compared. A strong influence of the solvent on the reactivity ratios, particularly on <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (HEMA or HPMA), has been observed. The copolymers prepared in DMSO are richer in hydroxyalkyl acrylates than those prepared in DMF. This effect may be attributed to preferential monomer solvation and the stability of the growing radicals. The influence of hydroxyalkyl acrylate comonomer on the properties of acrylonitrile copolymers (intrinsic viscosity and thermal behavior) are also discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene with acrylonitrile initiated by 2‐methyl‐2‐undecanethiol
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of styrene (St) with acrylonitrile (AN) initiated with 2‐methyl‐2‐undecanethiol (RSH) was investigated. Kinetic studies revealed that the initial rate of the copolymerization, which does not occur spontaneously in the absence of RSH, obeys the following expression: <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> ∝︁ [RSH]<jats:sup><jats:italic>x</jats:italic></jats:sup>, where <jats:italic>x</jats:italic> is 0,5 when [RSH] ranges from 3,4.10<jats:sup>−4</jats:sup> to 3,4.10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> mol/l and 0 when [RSH] is larger than 3,4.10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> mol/l. The initial copolymerization rate, <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>, increases with increasing percentage of AN in the monomer feed. From the slope of ln <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> vs. 1/<jats:italic>T</jats:italic>, the apparent activation energy, <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>app</jats:sub>, was calculated to be 17 kJ/mol in the temperature range of 30°C to 50°C. RSH is the only initiating species, and it also plays a role as chain‐transfer agent. The value of <jats:styled-content>M</jats:styled-content><jats:sub>w</jats:sub>/<jats:styled-content>M</jats:styled-content><jats:sub>n</jats:sub>, which varies from 1,5 to 2,0, is typical of a free‐radical poymerization. The reactivity ratios were calculated to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 0,42 ± 0,04 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0,02 ± 0,03. It seems to be unnecessary to introduce a penultimate effect for explaining the experimental data.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratio and Q–e values for copolymerization of hydroxyalkyl acrylates and 2‐(1‐aziridinyl)ethyl methacrylate with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of 2‐hydroxyethyl acrylate, hydroxypropyl acrylate, and 2(1‐aziridinyl)‐ethyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with styrene (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were prepared in benzene solution at 60°C. Benzoyl peroxide, 0.1–0.2 mole‐%, was used as initiator. Copolymer samples with the molar concentrations of M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> feed ranging from 0.10 to 0.85 were used to determine the reactivity ratios. Elemental analysis and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) were used to determine copolymer compositions. There was a solubility problem when the latter technique was applied. When samples which were completely soluble were analyzed, the results obtained from NMR and elemental analysis were in excellent agreement. The monomer reactivity ratios and the corresponding parameters for the copolymerization of (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with 2‐hydroxyethyl acrylate are: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.38 ± 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.34 ± 0.03; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.85, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.64; with hydroxypropyl acrylate are: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.45 ± 0.03, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.36 ± 0.03; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.75, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.56; with 2(1‐aziridinyl)ethyl methacrylate are: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.53 ± 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.63 ± 0.04; <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.82, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.25.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of N‐(4‐acetyl phenyl)‐ maleimide and styrene: Monomer reactivity ratios and thermal properties
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers containing N‐(4‐acetyl phenyl)maleimide (NAPMI) and styrene (ST) at different compositions have been prepared by radical copolymerization. FTIR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐, and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR and elemental analysis techniques were used on the identification of polymers. The monomer reactivity ratios were estimated using the Kelen‐Tüdös (KT) and Fineman‐Ross (FR) graphical methods. Structural parameters of the copolymers were obtained calculating the dyad monomer sequence fractions. A thermal study of the obtained copolymers related to the <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(4‐acetyl phenyl)maleimide content has been carried out taking into account several theories predicting the depence of the glass transition temperature on the copolymers composition. The <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s are linearly distributed between <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s of homopolymers and in all cases, single, well‐defined <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s are obtained. Glass transition temperatures increase with the increase of molar fraction of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(4‐acetylphenyl)maleimide. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 91: 964–970, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Integrodifferential Approach to the Estimation of Copolymerization Reactivity Ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Polymerization of macromonomers, 3. Monomer reactivity ratios in radical copolymerization of poly(tetrahydrofuran) macromonomers with 2‐vinylnaphthalene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Methacrylate‐terminated poly(tetrahydrofuran) (MA‐PTHF) and acrylate‐terminated poly‐(tetrahydrofuran) (A‐PTHF) macromonomers (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were radically copolymerized with 2‐vinylnaphthalene (2‐VN, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>). The composition of copolymers was determined by UV spectroscopy taking advantage of the very high absorption coefficient (UV) of the monomeric units of 2‐VN in copolymer. The monomer reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> evaluated are as follows. MA‐PTHF: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>1</jats:italic></jats:sub> =1,3 ± 0,21, ± 0,05; A‐PTHF: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2,5 ± 0,35, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,10 ± 0,05. These reactivity ratios were compared with those in the copolymerizations of 2‐VN with the corresponding small monomers and were discussed in terms of polymer (hindering) effect and the concept of equal reactivity of growing chain.</jats:p>
