Title: Free radical copolymerization of furfuryl acrylate and 2‐hydroxyethyl‐methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of furfuryl acrylate (<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) were prepared by free radical polymerization in DMF solution at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The reactivity ratios of both monomers were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös linearization methods, as well as the Tidwell and Mortimer nonlinear least‐squares treatment. The reactivity ratios obtained were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>F</jats:sub> = 0.93 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 1.42. The microstructure of copolymer chains is described on the basis of first‐order Markov statistics, and the copolymer glass transition temperatures were determined calorimetrically. The variation of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> with the copolymer composition is discussed according to modern methods, considering the sequence distribution of monomeric units along the copolymer chains. Also the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding homopolymers was determined giving the values <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) = 321 K and <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) = 358 K, whereas the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding alternating diad has an average value of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic>FH</jats:sub> = 326 K. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of furfuryl acrylate and 2‐hydroxyethyl‐methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of furfuryl acrylate (<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) and 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) were prepared by free radical polymerization in DMF solution at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The reactivity ratios of both monomers were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös linearization methods, as well as the Tidwell and Mortimer nonlinear least‐squares treatment. The reactivity ratios obtained were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>F</jats:sub> = 0.93 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 1.42. The microstructure of copolymer chains is described on the basis of first‐order Markov statistics, and the copolymer glass transition temperatures were determined calorimetrically. The variation of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> with the copolymer composition is discussed according to modern methods, considering the sequence distribution of monomeric units along the copolymer chains. Also the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding homopolymers was determined giving the values <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>F</jats:bold>) = 321 K and <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>(<jats:bold>H</jats:bold>) = 358 K, whereas the <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> of the corresponding alternating diad has an average value of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic>FH</jats:sub> = 326 K. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Non‐uniqueness in determination of terminal and penultimate model reactivity ratios in the styrene‐methyl methacrylate free‐radical copolymerization system
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The terminal and penultimate model reactivity ratios in the free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate in bulk at 40°C were calculated by means of the simplex and scanning methods. Calculations showed that for the terminal model <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> vary in comparatively narrow ranges of 0.548–0.552 and 0.480–0.483, respectively. For the penultimate model, the most accurate reactivity ratios calculated by the simplex method, which were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub> = 0.727, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub> = 0.490, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 2.890, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 4.583, are surrounded with sets of reactivity ratio values of equal accuracy. The ranges of variation were found to be 0.711–0.746, 0.487–0.492, 2.810–2.970 and 4.213–5.049, respectively. Numerical values of the penultimate <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>‐parameters calculated with the simplex method depend, due to the structure of the multidimensional space (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>, σ), on the initial guess for the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>‐parameters. Use of the covariance matrix for the estimation of the indetermination ranges is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Studies of the polymerization of diallyl compounds. XXVII. Copolymerization of diallyl tartrate with several vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of diallyl tartrate (DATa) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with diallyl succinate (DASu), diallyl phthalate (DAP), allyl benzoate (ABz), vinyl acetate (VAc), or styrene (St) was investigated in order to disclose in more detail the characteristic hydroxyl group's effect observed in the homopolymerization of DATa. In the copolymerization with DASu or DAP as a typical diallyldicarboxylate, the dependence of the rate of copolymerization on monomer composition was different for different copolymerization systems and unusual values larger than unity for the product of monomer reactivity ratios, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub><jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, were obtained. In the copolymerization with ABz or VAc (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values were estimated to be 1.50 and 0.64 for the DATa/ABz system and 0.76 and 2.34 for the DATa/VAc system, respectively; the product <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub><jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> for the latter copolymerization system was found again to be larger than unity. In the copolymerization with St, the largest effect due to DATa monomer of high polarity was observed. Solvent effects were tentatively examined to improve the copolymerizability of DATa. These results are discussed in terms of hydrogen‐bonding ability of DATa.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of the reactivity ratios for the 2-ethyl-n-hexyl methacrylate-methacrylamide system
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Solvent effect on the free‐radical copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate with t‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate with <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate was carried out at 50 °C in bulk and in 3 mol · L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> 1,4‐dioxane and <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>′‐dimethylformamide solutions. Differences between the apparent reactivity ratios determined in this work indicated a noticeable solvent effect. This is explained with a qualitative bootstrap effect. © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 39: 2043–2048, 2001</jats:p>

Title: Atom transfer radical copolymerization of acrylonitrile and ethyl methacrylate at ambient temperature
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of acrylonitrile (AN) and ethyl methacrylate (EMA) using copper‐based atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) at ambient temperature (30 °C) using various initiators has been investigated with the aim of achieving control over molecular weight distribution. The effect of variation of concentration of the initiator, ligand, catalyst, and temperature on the molecular weight distribution and kinetics were investigated. No polymerization at ambient temperature was observed with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>′,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>′,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>″‐pentamethyldiethylenetriamine (PMDETA) ligand. The rate of polymerization exhibited 0.86 order dependence with respect to 2‐bromopropionitrile (BPN) initiator. The first‐order kinetics was observed using BPN as initiator, while curvature in first‐order kinetic plot was obtained for ethyl 2‐bromoisobutyrate (EBiB) and methyl 2‐bromopropionate (MBP), indicating that termination was taking place. Successful polymerization was also achieved with catalyst concentrations of 25 and 10% relative to initiator without loss of control over polymerization. The optimum [bpy]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[CuBr]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> molar ratio for the copolymerization of AN and EMA through ATRP was found to be 3/1. For three different in‐feed ratios, the variation of copolymer composition (<jats:italic>F</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub>) with conversion indicated toward the synthesis of copolymers having slight changes in composition with conversion. The high chain‐end functionality of the synthesized AN‐EMA copolymers was verified by further chain extension with methyl acrylate and styrene. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 44: 1975–1984, 2006</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization. VIII. The Relation Between Structure and Reactivity of Monomers in Copolymerization<sup>1</sup>
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of methacrylic acid esters with methacrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of methacrylonitrile with styrene, methacrylic acid, and eleven alkyl methacrylates have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:bold>e</jats:bold> values calculated. Monomer reactivity in these systems is principally a function of resonance stabilization (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>), polar factors (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic>) playing a relatively minor role. With the exception of the stearyl ester, the changes in the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values which occur on ascending the homologous series can be accounted for qualitatively in terms of the expected relative electronic displacements and of the steric effects caused by the various alkyl groups. Some correlation between monomer reactivity and the depolymerizability of the corresponding polymer has been noted.</jats:p>

Title: Substituent effects in free radical copolymerization of substituted styrenes with acrylates and methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Relative reactivity ratios have been determined for <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene with five lower acrylates and methacrylates, respectively, and for methyl acrylate with a number of substituted styrenes in free‐radical copolymerization. Analysis of the data shows that: (a) acrylates are less reactive than methacrylates with <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene; (b) length of the side chain has little or no effect in methacrylates, but its effect is pronounced in acrylates with respect to their reactivity ratios; (c) chlorine substitution in the side chain of either acrylates or methacrylates has a significant influence on the reactivity ratio; (d) relative reactivity ratio data for methyl acrylate with substituted styrenes fail to show the expected relationship between monomer structure and resonance theory, inductive effect and, consequently, the Hammett σ values.</jats:p>

Title: Substituent effects in free radical copolymerization of substituted styrenes with acrylates and methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Relative reactivity ratios have been determined for <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene with five lower acrylates and methacrylates, respectively, and for methyl acrylate with a number of substituted styrenes in free‐radical copolymerization. Analysis of the data shows that: (a) acrylates are less reactive than methacrylates with <jats:italic>o</jats:italic>‐chlorostyrene; (b) length of the side chain has little or no effect in methacrylates, but its effect is pronounced in acrylates with respect to their reactivity ratios; (c) chlorine substitution in the side chain of either acrylates or methacrylates has a significant influence on the reactivity ratio; (d) relative reactivity ratio data for methyl acrylate with substituted styrenes fail to show the expected relationship between monomer structure and resonance theory, inductive effect and, consequently, the Hammett σ values.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of methacrylic acid esters with methacrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of methacrylonitrile with styrene, methacrylic acid, and eleven alkyl methacrylates have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:bold>e</jats:bold> values calculated. Monomer reactivity in these systems is principally a function of resonance stabilization (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>), polar factors (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic>) playing a relatively minor role. With the exception of the stearyl ester, the changes in the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values which occur on ascending the homologous series can be accounted for qualitatively in terms of the expected relative electronic displacements and of the steric effects caused by the various alkyl groups. Some correlation between monomer reactivity and the depolymerizability of the corresponding polymer has been noted.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of 2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine<sup>1</sup>
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The bulk copolymerization reactions of 2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine(MVP) with styrene(St), methyl methacrylate(MMA), methyl acrylate(MA), and acrylonitrile(AN) at 60°C. have been investigated. The copolymer compositions were estimated by means of electrometric titrations in a nonaqueous solvent mixture.</jats:p><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios of the following systems were determined: St/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.812 ± 0.005; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.91 ± 0.02), MMA/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.46 ± 0.02; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.61 ± 0.08), MA/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.172 ± 0.007; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.88 ± 0.10), and AN/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.116 ± 0.003; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.27 ± 0.04). Moreover the Q‐ and e‐values were calculated for the methyl vinylpyridine and its behavior in copolymerization is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of 2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine<sup>1</sup>
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The bulk copolymerization reactions of 2‐methyl‐5‐vinylpyridine(MVP) with styrene(St), methyl methacrylate(MMA), methyl acrylate(MA), and acrylonitrile(AN) at 60°C. have been investigated. The copolymer compositions were estimated by means of electrometric titrations in a nonaqueous solvent mixture.</jats:p><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios of the following systems were determined: St/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.812 ± 0.005; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.91 ± 0.02), MMA/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.46 ± 0.02; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.61 ± 0.08), MA/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.172 ± 0.007; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.88 ± 0.10), and AN/MVP (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.116 ± 0.003; r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.27 ± 0.04). Moreover the Q‐ and e‐values were calculated for the methyl vinylpyridine and its behavior in copolymerization is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic study of copolymerization of acrylonitrile with ammonium acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ammonium acrylate was first used to successfully copolymerize with acrylonitrile. Kinetics of copolymerization of acrylonitrile with ammonium acrylate was investigated in a H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O/dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) mixture. The rate of copolymerization and particle size were measured. Kinetic equation of the copolymerization was obtained. Effect of copolymerization systems on monomer apparent reactivity ratios for acrylonitrile/ammonium acrylate copolymers was studied in comparison. Values of monomer apparent reactivity ratios were calculated by Kelen‐Tudos method. It has been found that monomer apparent reactivity ratios in water‐rich reaction medium [H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O/DMSO>80/20] are approximately equivalent to those in aqueous suspension polymerization system. In DMSO‐rich reaction medium (DMSO/H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O > 80/20), apparent reactivity ratios are similar to those in solution polymerization system. With an increase in polarity of solvent, values of apparent reaction ratios both decrease. The values of apparent reaction ratios gradually tend to 1 with increase in the copolymerization temperature. © 2006 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 100: 4679–4683, 2006</jats:p>

Title: Analysis of the linear methods for determining copolymerization reactivity ratios. IV. A comprehensive and critical reexamination of carbocationic copolymerization data
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Increased insight into the mechanism of carbocationic copolymerization has been achieved by classifying and reviewing in detail 334 monomer pairs in terms of the extended Kelen‐Tüdös method. The reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values) of essentially all published olefin–olefin, olefin–vinyl ether, vinyl ether‐vinyl ether, and some miscellaneous systems have been reexamined and classified. Of the systems reviewed, only 121 (36.2%) contained sufficiently detailed information for comprehensive reevaluation and classification. Of these, only 49 (14.7%) were found to contain sufficiently accurate and reliable data to satisfy acceptance in class I, i.e., systems which are adequately described by the conventional copolymer composition equation, while 40 (12%) were accepted only in class I(!), i.e., systems for which the available data are somewhat less reliable than for class I and some caution is in order when employing <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values for quantitative purposes. Six (1.8%) monomer pairs were judged to belong to class II, i.e., systems for which the approximations implicit in the conventional copolymer composition equation do not hold and published <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values are probably erroneous and misleading. Finally, 26 (7.8%) monomer pairs were placed in class III, i.e., systems that exhibit unacceptable data scatter in the η versus ξ plot and published <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> values are meaningless. In some instances, even the existence of true copolymers is questioned.</jats:p>

Title: Preferential sorption of monomers and molecular weight effects in radical copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Specific thermodynamic properties of monomer mixtures as a solvent for copolymers lead to preferential sorption of one of the monomers by the polymer coils and preferential solvation of growing chains. The dependence of the preferential sorption coefficient upon the molecular weight of the copolymers results in the dependence of copolymer composition and monomer reactivity ratios upon the molecular weight of the copolymers and in gradient chemical heterogeneity of the copolymers. “Non‐classical” copolymerizations can be represented by both terminal and penultimate models.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios in UV‐initiated free‐radical copolymerization reactions
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The homopolymers of styrene (S) and vinyl acetate (VA) and their copolymers were prepared in bulk by ultraviolet (UV)‐radiation‐initiated free‐radical polymerization with azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as an initiator. The reacitivity ratios for these copolymerizations were determined by analyzing the monomer content in the copolymers by UV spectroscopy. The same method was extended to other copolymers of styrene such as styrene–methyl methacrylate and styrene–ethyl acrylate. A new analysis method was developed to measure reactivity ratios. For this purpose, UV light was used as a photochemical initiator and UV absorption spectroscopy was used for the determination of the instantaneous composition of copolymers. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was used to calculate percent conversion. © 1995 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Bulk Free Radical Terpolymerization of Butyl Acrylate, 2-Methylene-1,3-Dioxepane and Vinyl Acetate: Terpolymer Reactivity Ratio Estimation
Abstract: <jats:p>This investigation introduces the first estimation of ternary reactivity ratios for a butyl acrylate (BA), 2-methylene-1,3-dioxepane (MDO), and vinyl acetate (VAc) system at 50 °C, with an aim to develop biodegradable pressure-sensitive adhesives (PSAs). In this study, we applied the error-in-variables model (EVM) to estimate reactivity ratios. The ternary reactivity ratios were found to be r12 = 0.417, r21 = 0.071, r13 = 4.459, r31 = 0.198, r23 = 0.260, and r32 = 55.339 (BA/MDO/VAc 1/2/3), contrasting with their binary counterparts, which are significantly different, indicating the critical need for ternary system analysis to accurately model multicomponent polymerization systems. Through the application of a recast Alfrey–Goldfinger model, this investigation predicts the terpolymer’s instantaneous and cumulative compositions at various conversion levels, based on the ternary reactivity ratios. These predictions not only provide crucial insights into the incorporation of MDO across different initial feed compositions but also offer estimates of the final terpolymer compositions and distributions, underscoring their potential in designing compostable or degradable polymers.</jats:p>

Title: Study on soapless emulsion copolymerization methyl methacrylate and n‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The soapless emulsion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and n‐butyl acrylate (n‐BuA) at four levels of monomer feed composition (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>10</jats:sub>) was studied. Conversion (<jats:italic>X</jats:italic>), average particle diameter (<jats:italic>D</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>), molecular weight distribution (<jats:italic>MWD</jats:italic>), surface charge density, and glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of the copolymer as a function of reaction time (<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>) were measured. The copolymers obtained even at low conversion, except for the run of (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>10</jats:sub>) = 90 wt. percent MMA, exhibit two <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s in their DSC thermograms. Phase separation is found to occur in the latex particles during polymerization. The heterogeneous distribution of monomers in particles, in which a relatively rich MMA region exists in the shell and a relatively rich n‐BuA region exists in the core of the particles, is assumed to arise from phase separation. The average copolymer composition and the fraction of the two domains are estimated. The polymerizatrion course and particle size growth follow the linear <jats:italic>X</jats:italic> vs. <jats:italic>t</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>D</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub><jats:sup>3/2</jats:sup> vs. <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> relationships, respectively. Although the coagulation of particles happens after around 30 percent conversion, the polymerization behaviors, except for increasing rates, are not affected.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical copolymerization of [(4‐isopropyl phenyl) oxycarbonyl] methyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Results of investigations on the synthesis and characterization of free‐radical copolymerization of [(4‐isopropylphenyl) oxycarbonyl] methyl methacrylate (IPPOMMA), monomer (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with acrylonitrile (AN), and methyl methacrylate (MMA), monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) in CHCI<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> solution at 60°C with AIBN as initiator are presented. Fourier transform infrared, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, and elemental analyses techniques were used to identify of polymers. Reactivity ratios were calculated according to the general copolymerization equation using Kelen–Tüdös and Fineman–Ross linearization methods, yielding <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0.60 plusmn; 0.14 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>IPPOMMA</jats:sub> = 0.94 ± 0.28 for the AN/IPPOMMA system; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0.76 plusmn; 0.30 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>IPPOMMA</jats:sub> = 1.08 plusmn; 0.52 for the MMA/IPPOMMA system. The thermal properties of the polymers were studied by thermogravimetric analysis and differential scanning calorimetry. In addition, solubility parameters, inherent viscosities, and densities of polymers were determined. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 88: 2331–2338, 2003</jats:p>

Title: Bulk copolymerization of phenylacetylene with methacrylonitrile and with isoprene
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Anionic copolymerization of methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>An investigation was carried out of the anionic copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), 2‐methoxyethyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), and 2‐(N, N‐dimethylamino) ethyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) in benzene solution at 20°C initiated with lithium tert‐butoxide. The monomer reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>–<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.51 ± 0.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.10 ± 0.10, (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>–<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.20 ± 0.10, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub> = 0.40 ± 0.05, (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>–<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.40 ± 0.15, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub> = 0.60 ± 0.15 show that the reactivities of the individual monomers <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>3</jats:sub> do not differ too much from each other. A study of the microstructure of copolymers <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>–<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> by the NMR method revealed that at low conversions the tacticity of the copolymers depends on the concentration of 2‐methoxyethyl methacrylate in the starting monomer mixture; in the initial stage of copolymerization it is strongly dependent on conversion. Already a low content of <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in the starting monomer mixture (below 1%) strongly affects the tacticity of the forming copolymer by depressing the content of the isotactic component.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios and copolymerization parameters for copolymers incorporating n‐octadecyl acrylate and N‐n‐octadecylacrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios and copolymerization parameters were determined for <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐octadecyl acrylate and <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide with several monomers not previously reported. Values of <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> for the long‐chain acrylate now agreed more closely than before with the average of values for the lower acrylate homologs. The average polarity parameter for <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide still showed more electron withdrawal from the double bond (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.42) than was expressed by the average literature value (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.10) for <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octylacrylamide. Because penultimate effects were absent in this work, the reason for the discrepancy seems to reside in the copolymer analysis. Reactivity ratios for oleyl and octadecyl acrylate with methyl methacrylate were similar. Coefficients for the relation between overall rates of copolymerization and composition were obtained on some systems by curve fitting with a computer. They generally showed a slight minimum.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios and copolymerization parameters for copolymers incorporating n‐octadecyl acrylate and N‐n‐octadecylacrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios and copolymerization parameters were determined for <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐octadecyl acrylate and <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide with several monomers not previously reported. Values of <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> for the long‐chain acrylate now agreed more closely than before with the average of values for the lower acrylate homologs. The average polarity parameter for <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octadecylacrylamide still showed more electron withdrawal from the double bond (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.42) than was expressed by the average literature value (<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.10) for <jats:italic>N‐n</jats:italic>‐octylacrylamide. Because penultimate effects were absent in this work, the reason for the discrepancy seems to reside in the copolymer analysis. Reactivity ratios for oleyl and octadecyl acrylate with methyl methacrylate were similar. Coefficients for the relation between overall rates of copolymerization and composition were obtained on some systems by curve fitting with a computer. They generally showed a slight minimum.</jats:p>

Title: Self‐crosslinkable polymers. I. Copolymerization of glycidyl methacrylate with 2‐vinylpyridine and 2‐vinyl‐5‐ethylpyridine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A soluble and self‐crosslinkable linear copolymer with pendant epoxy and pyridyl groups was obtained from glycidyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and 2‐vinylpyridine (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) or 2‐vinyl‐5‐ethylpyridine (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) by the action of azobisisobutyronitrile. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined in tetrahydrofuran at 60°C: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.510, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.620 with 2‐vinylpyridine and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.57, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.62 with 2‐vinyl‐5‐ethylpyridine. These were consistent with the calculated values with the reported <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for these monomers. The intrinsic viscosities of the copolymers with 2‐vinylpyridine and with 2‐vinyl‐5‐ethylpyridine were found to be 0.17–0.19 and 0.26–0.38, respectively, in tetrahydrofuran at 30°C; they were independent of the copolymer composition. The copolymers were amorphous, had no clear melting points, and became insoluble crosslinked polymers under heating without further addition of any curing agents.</jats:p>

Title: Photo-induced controlled/living copolymerization of styrene and acrylic acid and determination of reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 3‐chloro, 2‐hydroxy‐propyl acrylate and methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrylonitrile (AN) was copolymerized with 3‐chloro, 2‐hydroxy propyl acrylate (CHPA) and 3‐chloro, 2‐hydroxy‐propyl methacrylate (CHPMA) in water and water‐acetone medium at 40°C with potassium persulfate and sodium metabisulfite as redox initiators. Copolymer composition was determined from the nitrogen content. The reactivity ratios for the AN‐CHPMA system were also calculated by the Kelen–Tudos method. The reactivity ratio <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (CHPMA) was higher for the AN‐CHPMA system in both media, which indicated higher reactivity of CHPMA toward the propagation species. Addition of acetone decreases <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and increases <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>. It was found that the copolymers prepared in water medium were not completely soluble in dimethylformamide (DMF); the insoluble fraction was rich in CHPA/CHPMA and increased with increasing comonomer composition. The influence of the acrylate comonomer on properties such as solubility and intrinsic viscosity was also studied.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics of copolymerization of acrylonitrile with ammonium itaconate in a H<sub>2</sub>O/dimethyl formamide mixture
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Kinetics of copolymerization of acrylonitrile (AN) with ammonium itaconate (AI) initiated by azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) were investigated in a H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O/dimethyl formamide (DMF) mixture between 50 and 70°C under a N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> atmosphere. The rate of copolymerization and particle size were measured. The kinetic equation of copolymerization system is obtained and the overall activation energy for the copolymerization system was computed. Values of monomer apparent reactivity ratios were calculated by the Kelen–Tudos method. It was found that in DMF‐rich reaction medium (DMF/H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O > 80/20), monomer apparent reactivity ratios are similar to those in the solution polymerization system. Effect of hydroquinone and dioxane additives on copolymerization was discussed. The polymerization is retarded by hydroquinone and accelerated by dioxane, which confirms the free‐radical copolymerization of AN with AI. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 94: 1151–1155, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios in copolymerization: a new method to determine r1 when r2 = 0
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of Diallyl Phthalate with Methyl Methacrylate and Acrylonitrile
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Solvent effects in radical copolymerization. I. Acrylamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrylamide has been free radical copolymerized with styrene and methyl methacrylate at 70°C in different solvents (dioxane, dioxane/ethanol mixture, ethanol). A strong influence of the solvent on the copolymer compositions has been observed; particularly copolymers richer in acrylamide have always been obtained in dioxane.</jats:p><jats:p>These results indicate that the nature of the solvent (polarity, dielectric constant <jats:italic>etc</jats:italic>.) could affect the polarity and the reactivity of the acrylamide double bond as well as the stability of the growing radical. Other factors are also discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical copolymerization of 9‐vinylanthracene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free‐radical copolymerization of methyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate with 9‐vinylanthracene was studied, and the reactivity ratios <jats:bold><jats:italic>r</jats:italic></jats:bold><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were calculated. In the light of earlier data on copolymerization of 9‐vinylanthracene with styrene results show that the difference in polarity of the monomers participating in the copolymerization has an insignificant influence compared with that of the steric factors involved in the reaction.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical copolymerization of 9‐vinylanthracene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Free‐radical copolymerization of methyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, butyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate with 9‐vinylanthracene was studied, and the reactivity ratios <jats:bold><jats:italic>r</jats:italic></jats:bold><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were calculated. In the light of earlier data on copolymerization of 9‐vinylanthracene with styrene results show that the difference in polarity of the monomers participating in the copolymerization has an insignificant influence compared with that of the steric factors involved in the reaction.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐Initiated homopolymerization and copolymerization of methylthiomethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Methylthiomethyl methacrylate (MtMA) was synthesized and homopolymerized in solution. The poly(MtMA) is readily soluble in benzene, acetone, tetrahydrofuran, and methylene chloride at room temperature. The values of <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> in the Mark–Houwink equation, [η] = <jats:italic>KM</jats:italic><jats:sup><jats:italic>a</jats:italic></jats:sup>, were found to be <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> = 2.88 × 10<jats:sup>–5</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> = 0.75 when <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> = <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>w</jats:italic></jats:sub>. The glass transition temperature of poly(MtMA) was observed to be 72°C by thermomechanical analysis. Intramolecular anhydride formation occurred when poly(MtMA) was heated to 250–300°C. The kinetics of MtMA homopolymerization was investigated in benzene, using azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The rate of polymerization <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> was expressed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup>[MtMA]<jats:sup>1.05</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated to be 75.7 kJ/mol. The relative reactivity ratios of MtMA in styrene copolymerizations (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>1</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 0.33, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>2</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 0.55) were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 1.07 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.51 for MtMA.</jats:p>

Title: Emulsion copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Chain transfer constants to monomer have been measured by an emulsion copolymerization technique at 44°C. The monomer transfer constant (ratio of transfer to propagation rate constants) is 1.9 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> for styrene polymerization and 0.4 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> for the methyl methacrylate reaction. Cross‐transfer reactions are important in this system; the sum of the cross‐transfer constants is 5.8 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup>. Reactivity ratios measured in emulsion were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (styrene) = 0.44, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.46. Those in bulk polymerizations were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.45, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.48. These sets of values are not significantly different. Monomer feed compcsition in the polymerizing particles is the same as in the monomer droplets in emulsion copolymerization, despite the higher water solubility of methyl methacrylate. The equilibrium monomer concentration in the particles in interval‐2 emulsion polymerization was constant and independent of monomer feed composition for feeds containing 0.25–1.0 mole fraction styrene. Radical concentration is estimated to go through a minimum with increasing methyl methacrylate content in the feed. Rates of copolymerization can be calculated a <jats:italic>priori</jats:italic> when the concentrations of monomers in the polymer particles are known.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and polymerization studies of some N‐alkylol acrylamides. II. Polymerization and copolymerization of 2‐methacrylamido‐2‐hydroxymethyl‐1,3‐propanediole
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A study has been made of the radical polymerization and copolymerization of 2‐methacrylamido‐2‐hydroxymethyl‐1,3‐propanediole with styrene at 60°C. This monomer homopolymerizes easily in water solution, yielding polymers of high molecular weight, but at high conversion crosslinking occurs. A further detailed kinetic investigation in dimethylformamide resulted in values for the overall rate of polymerization that were comparable to values for other acryl monomers. For copolymerization of 2‐methacrylamido‐2‐hydroxymethyl‐1,3‐propanediole (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) in dimethylformamide solution, the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.47 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.29 were obtained.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis of densely branched poly(methyl methacrylate)s via ATR copolymerization of methyl methacrylate and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Densely branched poly(methyl methacrylate)s have been synthesized by copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate (EGDMA) using atom transfer free radical polymerization (ATRP). By employing the phenyl and benzyl esters of 2‐bromo‐2‐methylpropionic acid as the initiators with 2,2‐bipyridyl and Cu(I)Cl it has been possible to use high field <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy to evaluate in some detail the composition and structure of the branched PMMAs obtained. Parallel molar mass size exclusion chromatographic analysis using a multi‐angle light scattering detector with a refractive index detector (MALS/SEC) has allowed the branched architecture of the products to be confirmed. Rather remarkably, high yields of branched PMMAs can be obtained without crosslinking using MMA/EGDMA molar feed ratios of up to 5/1 by appropriate adjustment of the molar feed of initiator. In particular by maintaining the EGDMA/initiator molar feed ratio ∼1/1 fully soluble products can be obtained that are densely branched since this feed ratio ensures that on average each living primary chain initiated contains on average only one branching EGDMA segment. As might be expected this controlled free radical process offers better control in the synthesis of branched polymer than the corresponding system we have reported using conventional free radical polymerization, and unlike the latter which requires the use of a chain transfer agent, the ATRP system requires no additional chain regulating component. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 45: 2375–2386, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of α-phenylvinylphosphinic acid with methyl methacrylate and methacrylic acid
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Controlled radical alternating copolymerization of N‐phenyl maleimide with ethyl α‐ethylacrylate by reversible addition fragmentation chain‐transfer process
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The alternating copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenyl maleimide (NPMI) with ethyl α‐ethylacrylate (EEA) by the reversible addition fragmentation chain‐transfer process was investigated. The monomer reactivity ratios were measured and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.19 ± 0.03 for NPMI and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.20 ± 0.04 for EEA. It was found that before about 45% of the comonomer conversion, the molecular weight of the copolymer increased with the conversion, the molecular weight distribution was rather narrow, and the molecular weight of the copolymer approached a constant value, irrespective of the length of the polymerization time. Electronic spin resonance determined that the radical signal disappeared quickly after the conversion of comonomer exceeded 45%, which may be attributed to the coupling termination of the propagating polymer chains with the EEA end with the intermediate radicals when the concentration of comonomers decreased. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 94: 2376–2382, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Ethylene-Propylene Copolymers. Reactivity Ratios, Evaluation, and Significance
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of alkyl methacrylates with N‐Vinyl carbazole. Determination of reactivity parameters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of ethyl methacrylate and n‐butyl methacrylate with N‐vinyl carbazole was studied in bulk at 333 K using benzoyl peroxide as initiator. The reactivity ratios of the monomers were determined by the FinemanRoss and Kelen‐Tüdős methods and briefly discussed. The Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of methacrylates were evaluated.</jats:p>

Title: A Brief Survey of Methods of Calculating Monomer Reactivity Ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of methacrylic anhydride with vinyl monomers
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of methacrylic anhydride and a variety of common types of vinyl monomers were conducted in bulk and in solution at 60–80° with benzoyl peroxide catalyst. The copolymers were characterized by conversion, solubility in hot dimethyl sulfoxide, elementary analysis, and infrared spectroscopy. A copolymer composition equation was derived for a special divinyl–vinyl system in which the divinyl monomer would cyclize extensively during polymerization and give rise to soluble, although perhaps branched, copolymers. The results showed that both soluble and insoluble copolymers were obtained, depending on the comonomer used and experimental conditions under which the copolymerization was carried out. In general, soluble copolymers were formed under the following conditions: (<jats:italic>a</jats:italic>) the less reactive the comonomer in free radical copolymerizations; (<jats:italic>b</jats:italic>) the greater the dilution; (<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>) the greater the difference in the moles of the two components in charge; and (<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>) the lower the conversion. According to reactivity ratio determinations and a comparison with published data, the anhydride ring radical behaved like a methyl methacrylate radical. The key step which led to gelation was believed to be “ring interruption” by the comonomer (CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = CHR):
<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/nust001.gif" xlink:title="chemical structure image" />
The question why methacrylic anhydride does not gel in homopolymerization, however, still remains unresolved.</jats:p>

Title: Research in the field of terpolymers. I. Copolymerization of acrylonitrile/methaerylic acid/methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>It is known that copolymerization reactions permit the extension of the scope of monomer utilizations, and especially, the controlled modification of the physico‐chemical and mechanical properties of polymers. Many types of elastomers, plastics and synthetic fibers are synthetized at present on the basis of such a reaction.</jats:p><jats:p>In the last years the field of synthetic fibres has acquired an ever wider utilization together with other groups of spinning polymers as, for instance, the polyamides and polyesters, the acrylic and vinylic copolymers where acrylonitrile is the main component, thanks to the properties it imparts on the polymers.</jats:p><jats:p>The kinetics of the copolymerization of the ternary system acrylonitrile/methacrylic acid/methyl methacrylate is studied. The polymerization was carried out in inert medium and homogeneous phase (solvent: ethylene glycole carbonate) using lauryl peroxide as initiator.</jats:p><jats:p>The authors investigated the variation of copolymer composition as compared to the initial monomer ratios at different conversions and depending on polymerization conditions.</jats:p><jats:p>For the calculation of the composition at a high degree of conversion the monomer reactivities were determined at 70°C by using F<jats:sc>INEMAN</jats:sc>‐R<jats:sc>OSS</jats:sc>, M<jats:sc>AYO</jats:sc>‐L<jats:sc>EWIS</jats:sc>, and J<jats:sc>OSHI</jats:sc>‐K<jats:sc>APUR</jats:sc>, relations. Some discrepancies in the results obtained by each of these methods are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer reactivity ratios: Acrylic acid-methylmethacrylate copolymerization in dimethylsulfoxide
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Organotin polymers. VII. Copolymerization of triphenyltin methacrylate with some acrylic and methacrylic acid esters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of triphenyltin methacrylate with methyl acrylate, ethyl acrylate, and butyl acrylate have been found to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.58, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.66, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.37, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.43, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.27, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>0.39</jats:sub> = 0.39, respectively. also, the copolymerization parameters of triphenyltin methacrylate with methyl methacrylate and butyl methacrylate were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.94, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.99, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.68, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.83, respectively. Copolymerization reactions were carried out in solution at 70°C using 1 mol % AIBN, and the copolymer compositions were determined by tin analysis. The sequence distribution of the alternating diad fractions for the systems studied were calculated at various feed compositions. The structure of the triphenyltin methacrylate monomer as well as its azeotropic copolymer with butyl methacrylate were investigated by IR spectroscopy.</jats:p>

Title: Correlation between copolymerization reactivity ratios and rates of radical additions to alkenes
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of styrene with [(2‐methacryloyloxy)propoxy]trialkyl(aryl) silanes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Styrene was copolymerized with [(2‐methacryloyloxy)propoxy]‐trimethylsilane (2‐MAPTMS), [(2‐methacryloyloxy)propoxy]‐dimethylphenylsilane (2‐MAPDMPS), and [(2‐methacryloyloxy)‐propoxy]‐diphenylmethyl silane (2‐MAPDPMS) in toluene at temperatures between 60 and 90°C using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The compositions of the copolymers were determined by silicon estimation. The reactivity ratios were calculated by the Kelen–Tüdös method. The reactivity ratio <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (styrene) is higher for styrene‐2‐MAPDPMS than for the styrene‐2‐MAPDMPS and styrene‐2‐MAPTMS copolymerzation system. The difference between the activation energies <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub> – <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> favors self‐propagation of the polystyryl radical, whereas the ratio of preexponential factors <jats:italic>A</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>A</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> favors cross propagation. For the 2‐MAPTMS radical, the difference <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub> – <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> favors cross propagation but the ratio <jats:italic>A</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>A</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> favors self‐addition. The intrinsic viscosities and the theramal behavior of the copolymers were also studied.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity Ratio Estimation from Cumulative Copolymer Composition Data
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The goal is to present an alternative technique for reactivity ratio estimation in copolymerization. Typically, reactivity ratios are estimated using the instantaneous copolymer composition equation, based on low conversion copolymer composition data. However, using experimental data from the full copolymerization trajectory would, in principle, be more advantageous, and shy away from commonly used restrictive assumptions. Estimation using cumulative copolymerization data and models eliminates the difficulties associated with stopping reactions at low conversion, while one gains to study the full polymerization trajectory. The error‐in‐variables‐model (EVM) method is used for parameter estimation. Two cumulative model forms, the analytical integration of the differential composition equation and the one resulting from the direct numerical integration of this equation, are employed. Using these two types of models improves the reactivity ratio estimation and, in particular, the latter model form is a more reliable and direct method of estimating reactivity ratios. <jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/jpeg" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.jpg"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and polymerization of N‐[1‐(1‐substituted‐2‐oxopropyl)]acrylamides and ‐methacrylamides. copolymerization of these monomers with styrene and substituent effects
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The synthesis and polymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐[1‐(1‐substituted‐2‐oxopropyl)]acrylamides and ‐methacrylamides are described. Seven new monomers were prepared by two kinds of synthetic procedure. The polymerization of these monomers was carried out. Monomer reactivity ratios in the polymerization of these monomers with styrene were determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values calculated. The effects of substituents on the reactivities in copolymerization were observed, and an interpretation of the results is given.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of Monomer Reactivity Ratio by Gas Chromatography
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Experimental and modeling studies on styrene–butyl methacrylate copolymerization reaction
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical‐induced copolymerization of styrene and butyl methacrylate was studied. The effects of the initiator (benzoyl peroxide) concentration, reaction temperature, and poly(vinyl alcohol) amount on the rate of reaction and final product quality are also measured. Kinetics studies and optical microscopy of the reaction mixture indicate that the reaction exhibits autoacceleration behavior, which could be suppressed by reducing the reaction temperature. <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR of the intermediate and final product samples reveals the monomer sequencing. The monomer reactivity ratios at various temperatures are estimated from the experimental data. The reaction is mathematically modeled by a Monte‐Carlo simulation, and the results of this analysis are compared with observed data. © 1993 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymérisation radicalaire du méthyl‐4 styrène avec le méthacrylate de méthyle ou l'acrylonitrile. Détermination des rapports de réactivité
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>4‐Methylstyrene (S) was copolymerized with methyl methacrylate (M) or acrylonitrile (A) in benzene or <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide solution, respectively. The reactions were carried out at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile as free‐radical initiator. The copolymer compositions were determined from oxygen (SM) or nitrogen (SA) analysis, 100 MHz <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR, and 25 MHz <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectra. These methods lead to the same results. Data plotted according to the Kelen‐Tüdős (K‐T) procedure indicate that the copolymerization of S with M can be adequately described by the terminal‐unit model. The corresponding reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,46 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>M</jats:sub> = 0,35 ± 0,02) were in good agreement with literature values and conform with the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>‐scheme. On the other hand, the K‐T plot for copolymerization of the SA system indicates deviations from the terminal model (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,27 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0,10 ± 0,01) in the S‐ and A‐rich regions. This departure was interpreted in terms of penultimate effects on the reactivity of the S‐ and A‐ended radicals. The values of the corresponding reactivity ratios were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>SS</jats:sub> = 0,18 ± 0,03, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AS</jats:sub> = 0,34 ± 0,04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AA</jats:sub> = 0,06 ± 0,01, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>SA</jats:sub> = 0,13 ± 0,01. The theoretical curve of copolymer composition versus monomer feed, calculated with these parameters, is in excellent agreement with the experimental data. This finding shows that, on the basis of the composition data alone, the penultimate model provides an appropriate description of the copolymerization of S and A.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymérisation radicalaire du méthyl‐4 styrène avec le méthacrylate de méthyle ou l'acrylonitrile. Détermination des rapports de réactivité
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>4‐Methylstyrene (S) was copolymerized with methyl methacrylate (M) or acrylonitrile (A) in benzene or <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide solution, respectively. The reactions were carried out at 50°C, using 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile as free‐radical initiator. The copolymer compositions were determined from oxygen (SM) or nitrogen (SA) analysis, 100 MHz <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR, and 25 MHz <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectra. These methods lead to the same results. Data plotted according to the Kelen‐Tüdős (K‐T) procedure indicate that the copolymerization of S with M can be adequately described by the terminal‐unit model. The corresponding reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,46 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>M</jats:sub> = 0,35 ± 0,02) were in good agreement with literature values and conform with the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>‐scheme. On the other hand, the K‐T plot for copolymerization of the SA system indicates deviations from the terminal model (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,27 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0,10 ± 0,01) in the S‐ and A‐rich regions. This departure was interpreted in terms of penultimate effects on the reactivity of the S‐ and A‐ended radicals. The values of the corresponding reactivity ratios were as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>SS</jats:sub> = 0,18 ± 0,03, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AS</jats:sub> = 0,34 ± 0,04, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AA</jats:sub> = 0,06 ± 0,01, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>SA</jats:sub> = 0,13 ± 0,01. The theoretical curve of copolymer composition versus monomer feed, calculated with these parameters, is in excellent agreement with the experimental data. This finding shows that, on the basis of the composition data alone, the penultimate model provides an appropriate description of the copolymerization of S and A.</jats:p>

Title: Graft copolymerization of poly(styrene‐co‐p‐choloromethylstyrene) with methyl methacrylate and acryloylmorpholine by atom transfer radical polymerization: Graft copolymer characterization and monomer reactivity ratios
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Poly[styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐(acryloylmorpholine‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐methyl methacrylate)] graft copolymers in various compositions, poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐acryloylmorpholine), and poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐methyl methacrylate) were prepared by atom transfer radical polymerization with poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chloromethylstyrene) (62/38) as the macroinitiator in the presence of CuBr/1,2‐dipiperidinoethane at 130 °C in <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide. The graft copolymers were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR, and differential scanning calorimetry. The thermal stabilities of the graft copolymers were investigated by thermogravimetric analysis. The monomer reactivity ratios in the graft copolymerization of acryloylmorpholine (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were calculated by the application of linear methods, such as the Finemann–Ross, inverted Finemann–Ross, Yezrielev–Brokhina–Roskin, Kelen–Tüdos, and extended Kelen–Tüdos methods, and the Mayo–Lewis method, which uses an integrated copolymer equation in a terminal model of copolymerization. <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> was 1.13–2.11, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was 0.49–1.05, according to the various methods. The Yezrielev–Brokhina–Roskin method gave the best linearity for the experimental results, and the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values were 1.28 and 0.54, respectively. © 2005 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 43: 3771–3777, 2005</jats:p>

Title: Photocurable and thermally stable polymers based on 1,4‐pentadien‐3‐one‐1‐p‐hydroxyphenyl‐5‐p‐phenyl methacrylate: Copolymerization with ethyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>1,4‐Pentadien‐3‐one‐1,5‐bis(<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hydroxyphenyl) (PBHP) was prepared by reacting <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hydroxybenzaldehyde and acetone in the presence of an acid catalyst. 1,4‐Pentadiene‐3‐one‐1‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hydroxyphenyl‐5‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐phenyl methacrylate (PHPPMA) monomer was prepared by reacting PBHP dissolved in ethyl methyl ketone (EMK) with methacryloyl chloride in the presence of triethylamine. A free‐radical solution polymerization technique was used for synthesizing homo‐ and copolymers of different feed compositions of PHPPMA and ethyl acrylate (EA) in EMK as a solvent with benzoyl peroxide as a free‐radical initiator at 70 ± 1 °C. All the polymers were characterized with IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR techniques. The compositions of the copolymers were determined with the <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR technique. The copolymer reactivity ratios were evolved with Kelen–Tudos (EA = 1.25 and PHPPMA = 0.09) and extended Kelen–Tudos (EA = 1.30 and PHPPMA = 0.09) methods. <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> (0.48) and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> (1.68) values for the new monomer (PHPPMA) were calculated with the Alfrey–Price method. UV absorption spectra for poly(PHPPMA) showed two absorption bands at 302 and 315 nm. The photocrosslinking properties of the polymer samples were examined with the solvent method. Thermal analyses of the polymers were performed with the thermogravimetric‐differential thermogravimetric technique. First, the decomposition temperatures started for poly(PHPPMA), copoly(EA‐PHPPMA) (62:38), and copoly(EA‐PHPPMA) (41:59) were at 350, 410, and 417 °C, respectively. A gel permeation chromatographic method was used for determining the polymer molecular weights (weight‐average molecular weight: 2.67 × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup> and number‐average molecular weight: 1.41 × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup>) and polydispersity index (1.89). The solubility of the monomer and the copolymers occurred at 30 °C with solvents having different polarities. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 41: 1632–1640, 2003</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of n‐butylacrylate with methylmethacrylate by a novel photoinitiator, 1‐(bromoacetyl)pyrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The photopolymerization efficiency of pyrene (Py), 1‐acetylpyrene (AP), and 1‐(bromoacetyl)pyrene (BP) for copolymerization of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylacrylate (BA) with methylmethacrylate (MMA) was compared. A kinetic study of solution copolymerization in DMSO at 30 ± 0.2°C showed that the Py could not initiate copolymerization even after 20 h, whereas with AP as initiator, less than 1% conversion was observed. However, introduction of a Br in α‐methyl group of AP significantly enhanced the percent conversion. The kinetics and mechanism of copolymerization of BA with MMA using BP as photoinitiator have been studied in detail. The system follows nonideal kinetics (R<jats:sub>p</jats:sub> α [BP]<jats:sup>0.67</jats:sup>[BA]<jats:sup>1</jats:sup>[MMA]<jats:sup>0.98</jats:sup>), and degradative solvent transfer reasonably explains these kinetic nonidealities. The monomer reactivity ratios (MRRs) of MMA and BA have been estimated by the Finemann–Ross and Kelen–Tudos methods, by analyzing copolymer compositions determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectra. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (MMA) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (BA) were found to be 2.17 and 0.44, respectively, which suggested the high concentration of alternating sequences in the random copolymers obtained. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Int J Chem Kinet 39: 261–267, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Statistical group transfer copolymerization. Monomer reactivity ratios for allyl methacrylate and n-butyl methacrylate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Solution copolymerization of monomethyl itaconate and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of monomethyl itaconate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) (4‐methyl 1‐hydrogen 2‐methylene‐succinate) with methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was studied in bulk and in ethyl acetate solution. The reactivity ratios were determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,56 ± 0,02 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1,56 ± 0,05. The dependences of copolymerization rate and degree of polymerization on initiator concentration, total monomer concentration and composition of monomer feed were measured. The reaction order with respect to the initiator concentration was near to the theoretical one (0,5), while that with respect to the total monomer concentration was considerably higher than predicted by theory (1,0). It could be explained by the influence of transfer reactions and diffusion control of termination reactions. Transfer reactions contribute to the reaction order mainly at low monomer concentration, while the influence of the medium viscosity becomes predominant at high monomer concentration.</jats:p>

Title: Organotin polymers XIV. Synthesis and copolymerization reactions of p‐acryloyloxy‐tri‐n‐butyltin benzoate with some vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>p‐Acryloyloxy‐tri‐n‐butyltin benzoate (ABTB) was prepared by the reaction of p‐hydroxy‐tri‐n‐butyltin benzoate and acrylic acid in the presence of dicyclohexylcarbodiimide. The monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerizations of ABTB (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with methyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), ethyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), n‐butyl acrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), methyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) and acrylonitrile (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) have been found to be r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.080, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.046; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.039, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.585; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.019, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.076; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.150, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.710; r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.113, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.339 and r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.007, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2.853, respectively. The Q and e values for the prepared organotin monomer were calculated. Copolymerization reactions were carried out in solution at 70°C using 1 mol‐% azobisisobutyronitrile. The structure of the ABTB monomer and the prepared copolymers was investigated by IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylamide with cationic monomers in solution and inverse‐microsuspension
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical copolymerization of acrylamide with three of the most commonly used cationic comonomers diallyldimethylammonium chloride, dimethylaminoethylmethacrylate, and dimethylaminoethylacrylate, the latter two quaternized with methyl chloride, was investigated. The polymerizations were carried out with azocyanovaleric acid and potassium persulfate over the temperature range 45–60°C. The copolymer reactivity ratios were determined with the error‐in‐variables method using residual monomer concentrations, measured by a Nalco HPLC method. This combination of estimation procedure and analytical technique has been found to be superior to any methods used previously for the estimation of reactivity ratios for cationic‐acrylamide copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerization of α‐methylene‐γ‐butyrolactone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of α‐methylene‐γ‐butyrolactone (α‐MBL) homopolymerization was investigated in <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylformamide (DMF) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) as initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) was expresed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.54</jats:sup>[α‐MBL]<jats:sup>1.1</jats:sup> and the overall activation energy was calculated as 76.1 kJ/mol. Kinetic constants for α‐MBL polymerization were obtained as follows: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub><jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> = 0.161 L<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> mol<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>·s<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>; 2<jats:italic>fk</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>d</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 2.18 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The relative reactivity ratios of α‐MBL(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.14, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.87) were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 2.2 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.65. These <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for α‐MBL are higher than those for MMA</jats:p>

Title: Studies of the polymerization of diallyl compounds. XXXVII. Copolymerizations of diallyl phthalate with dialkyl fumarates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Diallyl phthalate (DAP) was copolymerized with dialkyl fumarates, including diethyl fumarate (DEF), di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl fumarate (DBF), and di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐octyl fumarate (DOF) by using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator at 60°C. Both rate and degree of copolymerization were quite enhanced compared with the homopolymerization of DAP and the maximum rate was found at the molar ratio of 1:1 in the monomer feed. The cyclization of DAP was almost exclusively suppressed in the Copolymerization. Gelation was promoted from 25% of the gel‐point conversion for the DAP homopolymerization to 9% of the minimum one observed. Copolymerizability of DAP (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with dialkyl fumarates (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was quite high, with the following monomer reactivity ratios M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>: DEF, 0.01, 1.25; DBF, 0.02, 1.01; DOF, 0.02, 0.96. These results are discussed in mechanistic detail.</jats:p>

Title: Studies of the polymerization of diallyl compounds. XXXVII. Copolymerizations of diallyl phthalate with dialkyl fumarates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Diallyl phthalate (DAP) was copolymerized with dialkyl fumarates, including diethyl fumarate (DEF), di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl fumarate (DBF), and di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐octyl fumarate (DOF) by using 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as an initiator at 60°C. Both rate and degree of copolymerization were quite enhanced compared with the homopolymerization of DAP and the maximum rate was found at the molar ratio of 1:1 in the monomer feed. The cyclization of DAP was almost exclusively suppressed in the Copolymerization. Gelation was promoted from 25% of the gel‐point conversion for the DAP homopolymerization to 9% of the minimum one observed. Copolymerizability of DAP (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with dialkyl fumarates (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) was quite high, with the following monomer reactivity ratios M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>: DEF, 0.01, 1.25; DBF, 0.02, 1.01; DOF, 0.02, 0.96. These results are discussed in mechanistic detail.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effects on the copolymerization of styrene with maleic anhydride: determination of apparent reactivity ratios from the penultimate unit model
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of two bromine containing methacrylate monomers with methylmethacrylate. Determination of reactivity ratios by in situ quantitative 1H NMR monitoring
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>An important method used to make medical implants radiologically visible is based on introduction of radiopaque bromine or iodine containing methacrylic monomers. Thus, 2-(2-bromopropionyloxy) propyl methacrylate (BPPM) and 2-(2-bromoisobutyryloxy) propyl methacrylate (BIPM) were synthesized with the aim to use them as radiopaque agents. The free radical initiated copolymerization of BPPM and BIPM with methyl methacrylate (MMA) were performed directly in a thermostatic cell of the NMR spectrometer. The copolymer compositions obtained from <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectra led to the determination of the reactivity ratios (r<jats:sub>MMA </jats:sub>= 1.08 ± 0.12; r<jats:sub>BPPM </jats:sub>= 1.01 ± 0.13 and r<jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0.95 ± 0.09; r<jats:sub>BIPM</jats:sub> = 0.95 ± 0.1). The reactivity ratios of these two monomers is similar to that of MMA suggesting that the length of the bromine containing monomers side chain does not affect significantly the reactivity of the methacrylic double bond. From the results we conclude the copolymers to have random structure.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical copolymerization of styrene with N‐phenyl maleimide initiated by thiol
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>2‐Methyl–2‐undecanethiol was found efficient to initiate the free‐radical copolymerization of styrene (St) with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenyl maleimide (NPMI) at 40°C. The initial copolymerization rate increases with the increasing of thiol concentration at first, then keeps constant with the further increasing of the thiol concentration. The charge‐transfer complex (CTC) formed between St and NPMI was investigated in different solvents by using <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR. There is no definite correlation between CTC equilibrium constant, <jats:italic>K</jats:italic>, and the polarity of the solvent. With the increasing of CTC concentration, both the copolymerization rate and NPMI content in copolymer enhances, indicating the participation of CTC in both initiation and propagation. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>NPMI</jats:sub> = 0.052 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> − 0.166, showing an alternating tendency for the copolymerization of St with NPMI. The molecular weight approach has shown again the effect of CTC. The function of thiol as a regulator is mitigated due to the involvement of CTC. © 1992 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of ethylene–propylene using high‐activity bi‐supported Ziegler–Natta TiCl<sub>4</sub> catalyst
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta TiCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> catalyst using MgCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and SiO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> as supports was prepared under controlled conditions. Mg(OEt)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was used as a starting material and was expected to convert to active MgCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> during catalyst preparation. Due to the high surface area and good morphological control, SiO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was chosen as well. Slurry copolymerization of ethylene and propylene (EPM) was carried out in dry <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐heptane by using the catalyst system SiO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/MgCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/TiCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>/EB/TiBA or TEA/MPT/H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> at temperatures of 40–70°C, different molar ratios of alkyl aluminum : MPT : Ti, hydrogen concentrations, and relative and total monomers pressure. Titanium content of the catalyst was 2.96% and surface area of the catalyst was 78 m<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>/g. Triisobutyl aluminum (TiBA) and triethyl aluminum (TEA) were used as cocatalysts, while ethyl benzoate (EB) and methyl <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐toluate (MPT) were used as internal and external donors, respectively. H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was used as a chain‐transfer agent. Good‐quality ethylene propylene rubber (EPR) of rubber was obtained at the ratio of [TiBA] : [MPT] : [Ti] = 320 : 16 : 1 and polymerization temperature was 60°C. When TiBA was used as a cocatalyst, a higher and more rubberlike copolymer was obtained. For both of the cocatalysts, an optimum ratio of Al/Ti was obtained relative to the catalyst productivity. Ethylene content of the copolymer obtained increased with increasing TiBA concentration, while inverse results were obtained by using TEA. Addition of H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> increased the reactivity of the catalyst. The highest product was obtained when 150 mL H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/L solvent was used. Increasing temperature from 40 to 70°C decreased the productivity of the catalyst, while irregular behavior was observed on ethylene content.
