Title: Comparison of the precision of estimation of copolymerization reactivity ratios by current methods
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Six recently proposed methods for analyzing copolymerization composition data have been compared to a nonlinear least‐squares analysis to ascertain the precision of the six methods in determining reactivity ratios. Data used were simulated for five hypothetical monomer pairs with three different types of experiment design and contained error structures similar to those observed experimentally. The results of the comparisons suggest that retrospective analyses of existing copolymerization data should only be done with a nonlinear least‐squares analysis. For new data, the design of experiments is of great importance, and when done properly allows the use of some of the linear least‐squares methods of analysis.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Chloride with N-n-Alkylmaleimide
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Analysis of the linear methods of determining copolymerization reactivity ratios, 9. Penultimate systems with r2 = 0
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization equation considering the penultimate unit effect, the so called penultimate model, takes a simplified shape in the case of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 (monomer 2, M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, does not homopolymerize). For this case a method analogous to the conventional KT(Kelen‐Tüdős)‐transformation for estimation of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ is proposed. The new method was verified by literature data for the system styrene/fumarodinitrile, polymerized with benzoyl peroxide at 70°C, yielding <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,062 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ = 0,812. Classification of copolymerization curves by means of the classical copolymerization model permits to distinguish between three curve‐types: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> < 2 (alternation with respect to M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2 (linear diagram with slope 0,5) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> > 2 (non alternating system). The penultimate model permits to generate further curve‐types of “S”‐shape with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> > 2 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ > 2 or <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> > 2 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ < 2 (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ for classically behaving systems and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ≠ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>′ for non‐classically behaving systems).</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics of the free radical copolymerization of diethyl maleate with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical copolymerization of diethyl maleate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with styrene (M<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) was studied in bulk at 60°C with azoisobutyronitrile as initiator. In order to compute the reactivity ratios, we determined the copolymer composition by microanalysis of the carbon content. The evaluation of the data was carried out according to two procedures; the Kelen‐Tüdös linearization method and the non‐linear least‐squares of Tidwell and Mortimer. The ratios obtained with the latter, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> = 0,001 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>31</jats:sub> = 6,592, yielded a better fit. Different kinetic models were tested to describe the observed dependence of reaction rate on monomer mixture composition. The experimental results could be successfully described according to a kinetic model that assumes diffusion control of the termination reaction. The resulting kinetic equation contains two parameters whose values were determined from the experimental copolymerization rates. The value of one of these parameters could be obtained also from homopolymerization data for styrene. This proves that the parameters have physical significance and are not arbitrary quantities chosen to fit the experimental results.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene with α‐chloromaleic anhydride, 2. Spontaneous copolymerization in 1,4‐dioxane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>α‐Chloromaleic anhydride (CMA) copolymerizes spontaneously with styrene (ST) at a higher rate than maleic anhydride (MA), and α,α′ ‐dichloromaleic anhydride (DCMA) does not copolymerize, even in the presence of a radical initiator. The results obtained from the copolymerization of ST with CMA in 1,4‐dioxane in the absence of a radical initiator are as follows: the copolymerization is strongly accelerated by UV‐irradiation; the monomer reactivity ratios of ST and CMA at 60°C are 0,06 and 0,00, respectively; the over‐all activation energy of the copolymerization is 77,4 kJ · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> (18,5 kcal · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>); the maximum rate of copolymerization at a constant total monomer concentration is observed at a mole fraction of ST of 0,4 to 0,5. The rate of copolymerization at equimolar feed composition is of second order with respect to the total monomer concentration. From the results obtained here and shown in the preceding paper, it was inferred that initiating radicals for the spontaneous copolymerization are formed through a charge transfer (CT) complex between the comonomers.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic study of the copolymerization of tetrahydrofuran‐3,3‐dimethyloxetane: Microstructure of the copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The cationic copolymerization of tetrahydrofuran‐(A)‐3,3‐dimethyloxetane (B) was studied at 0°C with BF<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>·OEt<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>‐epichlorhydrin and acetylhexafluoroantimonate as initiators. The values of the reactivity ratios, calculated by the Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdos methods, were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.13, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>B</jats:sub> = 8.1 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.13, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>B</jats:sub> = 7.9, respectively. These values are in satisfactory agreement with those obtained with a kinetic scheme in which depropagation reactions were considered. The product <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub><jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>B</jats:sub> was approximately equal to unity, which indicated an ideal random copolymerization. The copolymers were also analyzed by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. Their spectra presented a doublet at 3.1 and 3.15 ppm that corresponded to the methylene protons of the dimethyloxetane units and allowed the determination of the probabilities <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>(AA), <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>(AB), and <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>(BB). Good agreement was found between the values calculated by spectroscopic methods and those obtained by using the classical probability theory of copolymerization.</jats:p>

Title: Effect of ionic strength on the reactivity ratios of acrylamide/acrylic acid (sodium acrylate) copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The ionic strength (IS) of polyelectrolyte solutions plays an important role in influencing reaction kinetics. The largely unstudied effect of IS on monomer reactivity ratios and copolymerization rates of acrylamide (AAm) and acrylic acid (AAc), in the form of sodium acrylate (NaAc), is investigated. Salt addition affects the nature of overall charges of the polyelectrolyte solution and diminishes the electrostatic repulsions between reacting chains. Therefore, changing the IS of the solution by incorporating salts affect not only the point estimates of the monomer reactivity ratios but also the overall behavior of the copolymerization (with a transition to azeotropic behavior). Experimental results on copolymerization rates confirm the observed trends in reactivity ratio behavior. © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Appl. Polym. Sci. <jats:bold>2014</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>131</jats:italic>, 40949.</jats:p>

Title: Machine learning approach to polymer reaction engineering: Determining monomers reactivity ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Synthesis and Characterization of Imino‐Phenolate Titanium Complexes and Their Use in Homo‐ and Copolymerization of Ethylene
Abstract:
<jats:p>A set of titanium precatalysts [(L)TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>] based on imino‐phenolate tridentate ligands (<jats:bold>Ti1</jats:bold>, L = 3,5<jats:italic>‐t</jats:italic>Bu‐2‐(OH)C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH‐N‐8‐C<jats:sub>9</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>N; <jats:bold>Ti2</jats:bold>, L = 3,5‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu‐2‐(OH)C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH‐N‐C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>‐O‐C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>; <jats:bold>Ti3</jats:bold>, L = 3,5‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu‐2‐(OH)C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH‐N‐CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>‐C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>OMe; <jats:bold>Ti4</jats:bold>, L = 3,5‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu‐2‐(OH)C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH‐N‐C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>‐C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>O) is prepared and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and NMR spectroscopy. Upon activation with methylaluminoxane (MAO), these precatalysts show good activity (200–660 kg of PE mol[Ti]<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> h<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> at 60 °C) in ethylene polymerization yielding high‐density poly­ethylenes (HDPEs) with viscosity‐average molecular weight (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>v</jats:sub>) in the range between 184 and 355 × 10<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> g mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>v</jats:sub> values of the resulting polyethylenes indicate strong influence of the aluminum concentration on the molecular weight, which can be associated to the probability of chain transfer from titanium to aluminum at high [Al]/[Ti] molar ratios. The polydispersity index (PDI) calculated from <jats:italic>G</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub>(<jats:italic>ω</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub>) values are broad (24 to >40) indicating the multisite nature of this class of titanium precatalysts. <jats:bold>Ti1–Ti4</jats:bold> are also tested in the copolymerization of ethylene with 1‐hexene affording high‐molecular‐weight poly(ethylene‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐1‐hexenes) with comonomer incorporation varying from 1.0 to 4.1 mol%. The crystallization analysis fractionation (CRYSTAF) profiles of copolymers produced by <jats:bold>Ti2–Ti3</jats:bold> indicate the production of HDPE with very low efficiency (quantity and distribution) on incorporating 1‐hexene. On the other hand, the polymer produced by <jats:bold>Ti1</jats:bold> shows a broad peak of branching fraction with different amount and comonomer distribution, suggesting a good 1‐hexene distribution along of main polymer chain.
<jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/jpg" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/macp201400167-abs-0001-m.jpg"><jats:alt-text>image</jats:alt-text></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text></jats:p>

Title: Direct Synthesis of Controlled Poly(styrene‐co‐acrylic acid)s of Various Compositions by Nitroxide‐Mediated Random Copolymerization
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Styrene and acrylic acid were copolymerized under controlled conditions, in 1,4‐dioxane solution at 120 °C and 2 bar, using an alkoxyamine initiator based on the <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(1‐diethylphosphono‐2,2‐dimethylpropyl) nitroxide, SG1. A broad composition range from 90/10 to 10/90 was investigated. With slightly different initiator concentrations and a similar initial proportion of free SG1 (4.5 mol‐% with respect to the initiator) the polymerizations exhibited very similar rates, irrespective of the proportion of acrylic acid in the comonomer mixture (80% conversion within 8 h). In all cases, the copolymers presented number average molar masses, <jats:styled-content>$\overline M _{\rm n}$<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-ueqn-1.gif" xlink:title="equation image" /></jats:styled-content>, that increased linearly with overall monomer conversion, and polydispersity indexes that ranged between 1.2 and 1.4. Moreover, <jats:styled-content>$\overline M _{\rm n}$<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-ueqn-2.gif" xlink:title="equation image" /></jats:styled-content> followed the calculated values, based on the initial concentrations of monomers and initiator. The variation in the initiator concentration allowed to target various molar masses, but some limitation appeared at low initiator concentration owing to chain transfer to 1,4‐dioxane. From the kinetic data, the reactivity ratios were determined: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.27 ± 0.07 for acrylic acid and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0.72 ± 0.04 for styrene. Depending on the initial comonomer composition, chains exhibited no or small composition drift, and hence a slightly pronounced gradient structure.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:caption><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for acrylic acid and styrene.</jats:p></jats:caption><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text><jats:caption><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for acrylic acid and styrene.</jats:p></jats:caption></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: Photoinduced Copolymerization of APMP-MMA: The Role of Reactive Hindered Amine APMP
Abstract: <jats:p>4-Acryloyl-1,2,2,6,6-pentamethyl-piperidinol (APMP) is a reactive hindered amine that prolongs the service life of the polymeric materials and exhibits high stability, good resistance to extraction, and low toxicity. In this paper, a photoinduced free radical copolymerization of APMP and methyl methacrylate (MMA) is accomplished at ambient temperature in solution. APMP plays a key role in the copolymerization, owing to the nitroxides generated in situ from the moiety of 1,2,2,6,6-pentamethyl-piperidine under UV irradiation, and mediates the copolymerization, which is confirmed by the linear kinetics. With the increment of initial monomer feed ratios of APMP/MMA, both the copolymerization rate and the average molecular weight increase. According to the reactivity ratios from the extended Kelen-Tüdos (KT) method at high conversion by<jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectroscopy, a nonlinear model is established and the sequential distribution in the copolymers is also investigated. The dispersion of APMP units is regulated by the feed ratios and reactivity ratios.</jats:p>

Title: High conversion copolymerization, 2. Styrene/maleic anhydride copolymer composition studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free radical initiated copolymerization of styrene with maleic anhydride at high conversions is studied. The data of the fractional conversion of the comonomers, of the fractional copolymerization rate, of the instantaneous and cumulative composition of the copolymer for the copolymerization of an equimolar mixture of styrene and maleic anhydride in ethyl methyl ketone (at 60°C) and in 1,4‐dioxane (at 120°C) up to high conversions as a function of the reaction time (resp. conversion) are presented. Negligible differences at 60°C, but significant ones at 120°C were found between the experimentally measured fractional compositions and those calculated according to the integrated form of the copolymer composition equation (Mayo‐Lewis equation), using the published values for the copolymerization reactivity ratios.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of n‐Butyl Methacrylate and D‐Limonene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:label /><jats:p>The bulk free radical copolymerization of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (BMA) and <jats:sc>D</jats:sc>‐limonene is carried out at 80 °C using benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as initiator. Low conversion experiments are conducted to estimate the copolymer reactivity ratios while full conversion runs are performed to verify the estimates and to achieve high monomer conversions. Reactivity ratios of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.0957 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.0459 (1 = BMA, 2 = <jats:sc>D</jats:sc>‐limonene) are obtained using a nonlinear, error‐in‐variables method with the RREVM computer program. Full conversions and reasonably high molecular weights are achieved at high BMA feed concentrations. Achieving high conversion is limited by a degradative chain transfer mechanism due to the <jats:sc>D</jats:sc>‐limonene.<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/mren201400023-gra-0001.png" xlink:title="mren201400023-gra-0001" /></jats:p></jats:sec>

Title: Alternating copolymerization through the complexes of conjugated vinyl monomers–alkylaluminum halides
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A vinyl monomer that has the nitrile or carbonyl group conjugated to the CC double bond, such as acrylonitrile, methyl acrylate, and methyl methacrylate, forms a complex with an alkylaluminum halide, and the complex reacts spontaneously with a hydrocarbon monomer such as styrene, propylene, or ethylene, giving a high molecular weight copolymer. The copolymers always contain the two monomer units in 1:1 ratio. Thus styrene, copolymerized with methyl acrylate or methyl methacrylate in the presence of ethylaluminum sesquichloride in homogeneous toluene solution, gives such an equimolar copolymer regardless of the initial monomer compositions. The NMR spectra of these copolymers are distinctly different from those of the equimolar copolymers obtained with azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator and have simpler and well separated patterns. The copolymers and the corresponding radical copolymers appear to be amorphous, judged by their x‐ray diffraction patterns and their differential thermal analyses. Their infrared spectra resemble each other very closely. Hence, the difference in the NMR spectra may be ascribed to the matter of the sequence distribution. The infrared spectrum of ethylene–methyl acrylate copolymer shows no absorption near 720 cm.<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> due to the methylene sequence arising from ethylene–ethylene linkage. These experimental data lead to the inference that the equimolar copolymers obtained in this work may have an alternating sequence.</jats:p>

Title: Monomers for Adhesive Polymers, 7<sup>a</sup>
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Homopolymerization and copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐(2‐hydroxyethylmethyl)acrylamide (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>′‐diethyl‐1,3‐bis(acrylamido)propane (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) have been studied in ethanol/water solvents or in bulk. The polymerization rate exponent depends on the polymerization temperature and increased from 0.99 at 50 °C to 1.21 at 75 °C. The initial polymerization rate dependence on temperature between 50 and 75 °C in Arrhenius coordinates was linear. However, the slope increased with an increase in monomer concentration. The overall activation energy <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub> varied from 64 kJ · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> at 0.5 mol · L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> to 76 kJ · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> at 2.0 mol · L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> monomer concentration. In addition, the reaction order with respect to the initiator AIBN deviated from the standard free radical polymerization kinetics. The exponent 0.42 indicated a significant participation of primary radicals in termination reactions. The polymerization reaction order declined from ideality as well, and the <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub> and polymerization enthalpy changed with the batch composition variation, which could be explained through monomer/monomer, monomer/solvent, or monomer/polymer complexation. The chain transfer to polymer was considered as an origin for the polymer network formation in monomer <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> homopolymerization if its concentration in the batch was 1 mol · L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> or higher. The more intensive polymerization acceleration with the monomer dilution and the greater heat released reduction with decrease in the monomer <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> to <jats:bold>2</jats:bold> ratios were evidenced in copolymerization. Nevertheless, the deviations from conventional reaction kinetics were not as pronounced as with acrylic or methacrylic acid polymerizations.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text></jats:p>

Title: Synthesis of methallylic monomers bearing ammonium side‐groups and their radical copolymerization with chlorotrifluoroethylene
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Methallylic monomers bearing triethyl or 4‐diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) ammonium side‐groups are prepared and copolymerized with chlorotrifluoroethylene (CTFE). First, three different monomers are synthesized from chloro‐2‐methylprop‐1‐ene or 3‐chloro‐2‐chloromethylprop‐1‐ene in fair to good yields (57–95%). Then, several parameters (initiators, aqueous or solution processes, temperature) of the radical copolymerization of these monomers with chlorotrifluoroethylene are investigated. Various initiators are tested in the presence of ammonium perfluorooctanoate (APFO) as water‐soluble surfactant, and <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl peroxypivalate/APFO leads to the best results in a mixed solvent (H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O/CH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>CN/C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>F<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>). In all experiments, the radical copolymerization shows that CTFE is more reactive than the methallylic monomer as evidenced by the characterization of poly(CTFE‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐M) copolymer by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Thermal degradation of these copolymers by thermogravimetric analyses indicates that the copolymers are stable up to 180 °C without any degradation and have a <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>d,10%</jats:sub> above 300 °C. Finally, their ionic exchange capacities range between 0.94 and 1.69 meq g<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem. <jats:bold>2014</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>52</jats:italic>, 1721–1729</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of chlorotrifluoroethylene with 4‐bromo‐3,3,4,4‐tetrafluorobut‐1‐ene
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of chlorotrifluoroethylene (CTFE) with 3,3,4,4‐tetrafluoro‐4‐bromobut‐1‐ene (BTFB) initiated by <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butylperoxypivalate is presented. The microstructures of the obtained copolymers are determined by means of NMR spectroscopies and elemental analysis and show that random copolymers were obtained. A wide range of poly(CTFE‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐BTFB) copolymers is synthesized, containing from 17 to 89 mol % of CTFE. In all the cases, CTFE is the less reactive of both comonomers. <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>d</jats:sub><jats:sup>10%</jats:sup> values, ranging from 163 up to 359 °C, are dependent on the BTFB content. These variations of thermal property are attributed to the increase in the number of C‐H and C‐Br bonds breakdown when the BTFB molar percentage in the copolymer is higher. <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> values range from 19 to 39 °C and a decreasing trend is observed when increasing the amount of BTFB in the copolymer. This observation arises from the higher flexibility of the copolymer when increasing the number of fluorobrominated lateral chains. These original fluoropolymers bearing reactive pendant bromo groups are suitable candidates for various applications. © 2014 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem. <jats:bold>2014</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>52</jats:italic>, 1714–1720</jats:p>

Title: Acrylonitrile Copolymerizations. IV. Butadiene Copolymerization
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The kinetics of the acrylonitrile-butadiene radical copolymerization, carried out in solution at 60° C, have been followed using gas chromatographic analysis. Remote unit effects are observed only on the butadiene-ended radicals, but they seem to involve a quite long sequence of butadiene units. The following values of the reactivity ratios are proposed: rA=0.067, rAB=0.70, rABB=0.66, rABBB=0.17, rBi→0.01 to 0.06 for large values of i. The results are discussed in terms of either polarity effects, or differences in reactivities between 1,4- or 1,2-butadiene radicals, or finally of charge transfer complexes between the monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios of ethyl acrylate, n‐butyl methacrylate copolymer system by 1H‐NMR
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ethyl acrylate (EA) and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BMA) copolymers were prepared in solution and the composition of the copolymer samples was estimated by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopic techniques. Because the characteristic signals, which vary with the composition of the copolymer, were absent, the ratio of intensities of down‐field protons to that of the total protons was used for the estimation of copolymer composition. Reactivity ratios were calculated from these values by using the Kelen‐Tudos differential linear equation.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios of ethyl acrylate, n‐butyl methacrylate copolymer system by 1H‐NMR
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ethyl acrylate (EA) and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐BMA) copolymers were prepared in solution and the composition of the copolymer samples was estimated by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopic techniques. Because the characteristic signals, which vary with the composition of the copolymer, were absent, the ratio of intensities of down‐field protons to that of the total protons was used for the estimation of copolymer composition. Reactivity ratios were calculated from these values by using the Kelen‐Tudos differential linear equation.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of styrene and styrene–acrylonitrile with polybutadienes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of styrene and styrene–acrylonitrile with polybutadienes of various microstructures was studied and the reactivity ratios determined. It was shown that for the styrene/acrylonitrile/polybutadiene systems the 1,2 structure is twice as reactive as the trans and four times as reactive as the cis. Studies in the temperature range of 50–80°C reveal that the reactivity of the polybutadiene increases as the temperature rises. When styrene is the monomer the reactivity of polybutadiene and the temperature effect is less intense than when styrene–acrylonitrile is used.</jats:p>

Title: Monomer and radical reactivity ratios in 4‐vinylbenzenesulfonic acid sodium salt–acrylamide copolymerization in 0.1M NaCl solution
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reaction kinetics and composition of 4‐vinylbenzenesulfonic acid sodium salt (VB)–acrylamide (Aam) copolymerization in 0.1<jats:italic>M</jats:italic> NaCl solution are investigated. Data obtained by the automatic continuous monitoring of copolymerization system, up to 80% conversion, are analyzed by an “error‐in‐variables method” developed for obtaining the reactivity ratios by on‐line monitoring. Monomer reactivity ratios are found as <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Aam</jats:sub> = 0.085 ± 0.020, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VB</jats:sub> = 2.0 ± 0.33. Although the terminal model describes the composition data well, it is seen to be inconsistent with the reaction rates. This discrepancy is attributed to implicit penultimate effects and using the recently developed calculation method, effective radical reactivity ratios are found as <jats:italic>s</jats:italic><jats:sub>VB</jats:sub> = 0.26 and <jats:italic>s</jats:italic><jats:sub>Aam</jats:sub> = 0.027, and both composition and rate data fit the implicit penultimate model extremely well. On‐line monitored data showed that in the reactions where the VB was completely consumed, the subsequent Aam homopolymerization was very rapid; thus, the reaction showed definitely two rate regimes, before and after VB depletion. Acrylamide take up rate also showed these two rate regimes. We conclude that low conversion results can be misleading and reactions must be monitored up to a high conversion for a robust control of composition and reaction kinetics. © 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2011</jats:p>

Title: Free radical solution copolymerization of monomers of dissimilar reactivity - influencing chemical composition distribution and properties of copolymers of methyl methacrylate and N-vinyl imidazole by varying monomer feeding profiles
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Graft polymers with macromonomers. II. Copolymerization kinetics of methacrylate‐terminated polystyrene and predicted graft copolymer structures
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization studies of methacrylate‐terminated polystyrene macromonomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) with several comonomers (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) verified the modified kinetic scheme and permitted prediction of graft polymer compositions and structures. Instantaneous and cumulative copolymer compositions, average graft distributions, and grafts per molecule are predicted from FORTRAN IV or BASIC programs. The <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> relative reactivity ratios determined from styrene copolymerization (0.61) or from low conversion acrylic monomer in aqueous suspension (∼0.4) had good agreement with literature values (about 0.6 and 0.4, respectively). Decreased macromonomer reactivity determined at high acrylic monomer conversions was attributed to phase separation phenomena. The Macromers also exhibited lower reactivity than predicted when copolymerized with acrylic monomers in DMSO/benzene solutions (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> ∼ 0.8).</jats:p>

Title: Study of free‐radical copolymerization of N‐isopropylacrylamide with 2‐acrylamido‐2‐methyl‐1‐propanesulphonic acid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐isopropylacrylamide and 2‐acrylamido‐2‐methyl‐1‐propanesulphonic acid at varying comonomer mole ratios was studied at 70°C. The extent of conversion was determined as a function of time and comonomer mixture composition, and copolymer compositions were determined using elemental analysis and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectroscopy. Monomer reactivity ratios were evaluated for low conversions using Kelen‐Tüdos and Fineman‐Ross methods. The copolymers were characterized using <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR spectra, FTIR spectroscopy, and differential scanning calorimetry. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 88: 2563–2569, 2003</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 1-vinyltetrazole with vinyl monomers
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Vinyl polymerization. 120. Mutual copolymerization of p‐substituted styrenes through radical mechanism
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical mutual copolymerization of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted styrenes, such as <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐methoxy‐, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chloro‐, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐bromo‐, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐cyanostyrene, and styrene was carried out with one another at 30°C. in the dark. As initiator, azobisisobutyronitrile was used. The plots of the copolymerization rates against H<jats:sc>AMMETT</jats:sc>'s σ values showed no linear relationships and the concave curves were obtained therefrom. The relative reactivities of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted styrenes with a definite <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted polystyryl radical, which were shown by the reciprocal of monomer reactivity ratio r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, were plotted against σ values and concave curves were also obtained. The relative reactivities of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted polystyryl radicals with <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted styrene were calculated from the ratios r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> and the propagation rate constants in homopolymerization. the plots of them against σ values gave straight lines with different ρ values, according to the polarity of substituents. These results suggest that polar structures in transition state affected markedly the copolymerization rates. The effect of substituents on resonance stabilization was also quantitatively estimated.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization characteristics of ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization characteristics of ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate with four different monomers have been investigated, and the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> determined in the case of each comonomer pair. The monomers used were styrene, methyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, and ethyl acrylate. From these data were calculated the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate. It is apparent that this monomer resembles ethyl acrylate very closely in its copolymerization characteristics.</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization characteristics of ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization characteristics of ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate with four different monomers have been investigated, and the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> determined in the case of each comonomer pair. The monomers used were styrene, methyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, and ethyl acrylate. From these data were calculated the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ethyl α‐acetoxyacrylate. It is apparent that this monomer resembles ethyl acrylate very closely in its copolymerization characteristics.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and characterization of methacrylic acid–ethyl acrylate copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methacrylic acid (MAA) and ethyl acrylate (EA) was performed in aqueous medium in the presence of an emulsifier with MAA as the major component (53.7–82.3 mol %). Emulsion stability was studied as a function of concentration and the nature of the emulsifier (ionic or nonionic). Copolymers were characterized using IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectra of MAA–EA copolymers have been discussed in terms of their triad monomer sequence distributions. Reactivity ratios of the MAA–EA pair were determined using a nonlinear least‐square errors in variables method. Partition of the monomers in aqueous and organic phases was studied using a gas chromatographic technique. A two‐loci polymerization mechanism was proposed on the basis of this partition behavior and the calculated composition of the oligomeric radicals formed in the initial stages of polymerization. © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and characterization of methacrylic acid–ethyl acrylate copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methacrylic acid (MAA) and ethyl acrylate (EA) was performed in aqueous medium in the presence of an emulsifier with MAA as the major component (53.7–82.3 mol %). Emulsion stability was studied as a function of concentration and the nature of the emulsifier (ionic or nonionic). Copolymers were characterized using IR and <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectra of MAA–EA copolymers have been discussed in terms of their triad monomer sequence distributions. Reactivity ratios of the MAA–EA pair were determined using a nonlinear least‐square errors in variables method. Partition of the monomers in aqueous and organic phases was studied using a gas chromatographic technique. A two‐loci polymerization mechanism was proposed on the basis of this partition behavior and the calculated composition of the oligomeric radicals formed in the initial stages of polymerization. © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Estimation of monomer reactivity ratios by the error-in-variable method

Title: Polymer‐supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts. II. Ethylene homo‐ and copolymerization with TiCl4/MgR2/poly(ethylene‐co‐acrylic acid) catalyst
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A novel polymer‐supported titanium‐based catalyst shows high activity and nondecaying kinetic profiles for ethylene polymerization. The presence of 1‐hexene comonomer drastically increases the catalyst activity, exhibiting a similarity to the MgCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>‐supported catalysts. However, the nondecaying kinetic profiles of copolymerization distinguish this catalyst from the latter. Infrared analysis indicates that the transition metals were immobilized on the polymer support via functional groups. The effects of polymerization conditions on catalyst activity have been assessed. Characterization of the resulting polymer product by means of <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR, DSC, and SEM demonstrates a branch‐free structure with high melting point, high crystallinity, and high molecular weight for the ethylene homopolymer. The reactivity ratios of ethylene‐1‐hexene copolymerization are evaluated from <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR analysis data. © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.</jats:p>

Title: Structure and reactivities of alkyl vinyl ketones in their radical copolymerizations with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To clarify the effect of the alkyl substituents in alkyl vinyl ketones (RVK) on their radical copolymerizations, the copolymerizations of six such alkyl vinyl ketones with styrene were investigated. From the results obtained, the relative reactivities of RVK toward the polystyryl radical were correlated with the Taft equation: log (1/<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) = ρ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup>σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> + δ<jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>s</jats:sub>, in which σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>s</jats:sub> are polar and steric substituent constants, respectively, and ρ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> and δ are reaction constants. The values of ρ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> and δ obtained were 0.40 ± 0.05 and 0, respectively. It was observed that the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values obtained for RVK increased with increasing of σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> values, and that both relative reactivities and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of methyl vinyl ketone also increased with increasing of the <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>T</jats:sub> values of the solvents used. From the spectral determination of the RVK monomers, it was also found that their <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>–π interactions were related to the copolymerization reactivities. Furthermore, the radical polymerization of <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl vinyl ketone (<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BVK) with azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was investigated, and its rate <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> was found to be expressed by the following rate equation: <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic> [AIBN]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup>[<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐BVK]<jats:sup>1.0</jats:sup>.</jats:p>

Title: Complex radical copolymerization of di‐n‐butylstannyl dimethacrylate with maleic anhydride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Mechanisms of radical copolymerization of di‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylstannyl dimethacrylate with maleic anhydride in the presence of 2,2‐asobisisobutyronitrile are discussed. Complexing (<jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>eq</jats:sub>) and copolymerization (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) constants have been determined. Quantitative contributions of cyclization and complexing to reactivity ratios of the monomers under study and to propagation reactions have been estimated. The copolymerization has been found to proceed predominantly at the complex radical cyclocopolymerization step, leading to cyclized and linear unsaturated units in the macromolecule chain.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetics of polymerization of vinylidene chloride. IV. Copolymerization of vinylidene chloride and acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The emulsion polymerization of vinylidene chloride is divisible into three stages: (I) a normal emulsion polymerization at a rate dependent on the 0.6 power of both the catalyst and surfactant concentration; (II) at a rate less than half that of I; (III) at a rate which increases in direct proportion to the catalyst concentration and independently of surfactant concentration. A careful examination of stirring rate has shown that the slowdown in stage II probably results from monomer starvation caused by slow diffusion of coalesced droplets, and that recovery in stage III is the result of transfer of monomer at the time of collision between a polymer particle and a monomer droplet. Extension of this work to copolymers of vinylidene chloride and acrylonitrile has shown a similar kinetic effect at high ratios of vinylidene chloride. The rate of polymerization for a system containing 90% vinylidene chloride decreases sharply after 15% conversion. The polymer formed increases in acrylonitrile content with conversion, reaches a maximum, and then decreases during stage III of the reaction. A run containing 70% vinylidene chloride in the charge did not show a slowdown but gave evidence of a maximum in the curve relating conversion and composition. At higher acrylonitrile content, no slowing occurred, and the polymer composition changed monotonically with conversion. Since acrylonitrile is partially soluble in water, the partition coefficient of acrylonitrile between vinylidene chloride and water was determined at concentrations similar to those used in the polymerizations. The partition coefficient decreases with increasing acrylonitrile concentration in the water phase. Apparent reactivity ratios were calculated on the basis of the monomer composition corrected for the water solubility of acrylonitrile and the initial composition of the copolymer. These values are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.390 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.585, vinylidene chloride being considered to be the first monomer. The existence of a unique reactivity ratio indicates that the composition of the initial polymer is controlled only by the relative reactivities of the comonomers and the water solubility of acrylonitrile. The polymer formed later is also influenced by the rate of transport of vinylidene chloride to the reaction site. This is confirmed by the conversion curves and the manner in which composition changes with conversion.</jats:p>

Title: Simple and Accurate Determination of Reactivity Ratios Using a Nonterminal Model of Chain Copolymerization
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Method for reactivity ratio determination in high‐conversion copolymerisations by means of 1H‐n.m.r. spectroscopy
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerisation of methyl methacrylate and styrene is carried out in the n.m.r. spectrometer's sample tube, measuring the comonomer concentration against time evolution. The data are processed according to the integrated Mayo‐Lewis and Fineman‐Ross equations in order to obtain the reactivity ratios values. The applicability, advantages and limits of the method are discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of poly(acrylic acid‐co‐itaconic acid)
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios are important parameters used in copolymerization kinetics to predict the rate of polymerization, copolymer composition and monomer sequence length, and by extension, molecular weight and distribution of the final product. Batch aqueous solution copolymerizations of acrylic acid (AA) and itaconic acid (IA) are performed at various feed compositions. Polymerizations are categorized into low (<11 wt %) conversion and higher (< 30 wt %) conversion data sets for analysis. Due to the limited solubility of IA in the reaction mixture, the feed composition of IA in all polymerizations is constrained to lower than 25 mol %. Conversion is determined by gravimetric methods, and copolymer composition via <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR spectroscopy. All data are analyzed using the error‐in‐variables model (EVM) method. Two analyses are used, one with the EVM approach and another with a novel Direct Numerical Integration (DNI) coupled with the EVM method. The DNI/EVM approach yields values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AA</jats:sub> = 0.36 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>IA</jats:sub> = 1.62 for the reactivity ratios. © 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Appl. Polym. Sci. <jats:bold>2016</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>133</jats:italic>, 44014.</jats:p>

Title: Relative reactivity ratios for two new 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The relative reactivity ratios in free‐radical, emulsion copolymerizations for the systems 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene/methyl isopropenyl ketone and 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene/methacrylic acid were found to be 3.6 and 0.1 and 2.68 and 0.15, respectively. Consequently, copolymers are formed substantially richer in 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene units than the comonomer feed, have little alternation tendency, and do not form azeotropes. Distributions of monomer units in the copolymers are described.</jats:p>

Title: Relative reactivity ratios for two new 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The relative reactivity ratios in free‐radical, emulsion copolymerizations for the systems 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene/methyl isopropenyl ketone and 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene/methacrylic acid were found to be 3.6 and 0.1 and 2.68 and 0.15, respectively. Consequently, copolymers are formed substantially richer in 2‐chloro‐1,3‐butadiene units than the comonomer feed, have little alternation tendency, and do not form azeotropes. Distributions of monomer units in the copolymers are described.</jats:p>

Title: A new high‐throughput approach to measure copolymerization reactivity ratios using real‐time FTIR monitoring
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This paper presents a novel high‐throughput approach to measure copolymerization reactivity ratios from a single experiment using high‐speed real‐time Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) monitoring of the isobutylene/isoprene (IB/IP) system initiated by 2‐chloro‐2,4,4‐trimethyl‐pentane (TMPCl)/TiCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> in hexane/methyl chloride (Hx/MeCl) 60:40 v/v solvent at −80 °C. Traditional polymer analysis is severely limited in this system, which is riddled by side reactions. The reactivity ratios calculated by linear (Mayo‐Lewis and Kelen‐Tüdös) methods and by a nonlinear least square (NLLS) method (van Herk algorithm) showed good agreement with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> =1.32 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.74 calculated using Mayr's nucleophilicity scale. Combination of the Kelen‐Tüdös and NLLS methods yielded <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.17 ± 0.01 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.99 ± 0.02. These values agree well with those reported by Thaler et al. but disagree with most reported data. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 42: 4084–4100, 2004</jats:p>

Title: The copolymerization of styrene with the cyclic carbonate of glycidyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The free‐radical copolymerization of styrene with (2‐oxo‐1,3‐dioxolan‐4‐yl)methyl methacrylate (cyclic carbonate of glycidyl methacrylat; GMACC) was carried out in N,N‐dimethylformamide and toluene solution under batch conditions. In toluene, a precipitate was formed during polymerization. The composition of the copolymers was determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. The monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by different methods from the copolymer composition data. The values obtained for the different techniques were compared and showed a good agreement.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios for acrylic acid–methyl acrylate copolymerization in 1,4‐dioxane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We report values of reactivity ratios for the copolymerization in 1,4‐dioxane of acrylic acid (AA) and methyl acrylate (MA), measured as part of work on ion‐binding to polyelectrolytes at different charge densities. Ryabov et al.<jats:sup>1</jats:sup> have shown the reactivity ratios for this and similar systems to depend on the nature and amount of the solvent used.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of β-Cyanoacrolein with Acrylonitrile
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Radical initiated copolymerization of β-cyanoacrolein (CAL, M2) with acrylonitrile (M1) in benzene at 60°C was investigated. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined to be r1=3.2 and r2=0. The copolymerization behavior is discussed in comparison with that in the system of styrene and CAL previously described. The Q and e values of CAL were also estimated to be 0.53 and 2.07, respectively, which were compared with those of other polar monomers.</jats:p>

Title: A new general approach to determine more accurate comonomer reactivity ratios in controlled/living radical copolymerization systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In controlled/living radical copolymerization (atom transfer radical copolymerization in this study) and in any other living chain‐growth copolymerization, the possible preferential addition of one of the comonomers onto the (macro)initiator‐derived (macro)radical can affect the copolymer composition, especially at low conversion; this results in inaccurate comonomer reactivity ratio estimation by the classic approach. A new general approach is introduced in this article, which allowed us to exclude the influence of the possible preferential addition of one of the comonomers onto the (macro)initiator‐derived (macro)radical on the copolymer composition at any conversion. According to this approach, copolymer chain grown during time <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>t</jats:italic> ≠ 0) is considered to be, in fact, the macroinitiator terminated with one of the comonomers under study, which will further grow during the time interval Δ<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′ = <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′ − <jats:italic>t</jats:italic> [where any reaction time <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′ is considered to be grater than reaction time <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>, i.e. <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′ > <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>] from a comonomer mixture with composition of <jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>) [where <jats:italic>f</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>) is the molar ratio of comonomer <jats:italic>i</jats:italic> to comonomer <jats:italic>j</jats:italic> in the comonomer mixture] at time <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>. In such a situation, it is possible to obtain individual comonomer conversions [<jats:italic>x</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>i</jats:italic></jats:sub>(Δ<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′) and <jats:italic>x</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>j</jats:italic></jats:sub>(Δ<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′)], the overall comonomer conversion [<jats:italic>x</jats:italic><jats:sub>ov</jats:sub>(Δ<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′)], and the cumulative average copolymer composition for the copolymer formed during Δ<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>′, from which more accurate comonomer reactivity ratios can be calculated by the various low‐ or high‐conversion methods, depending on the overall comonomer conversion. © 2011 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2011</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic and electron paramagnetic resonance studies on radical polymerization. Radical copolymerization of p‐tert‐butoxy‐styrene and dibutyl fumarate in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butoxystyrene (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and dibutyl fumarate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) initiated with dimethyl 2,2′‐azobisisobutyrate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) was studied in benzene at 60°C kinetically and by means of electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,18 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,01, indicating that homopropagation of M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> is almost negligible in the copolymerization. The copolymerization system was revealed to involve EPR‐observable propagating polymer radicals under practical copolymerization conditions. The apparent rate constants of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) and termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub>) determined by EPR show a rapid increase in the range from 0,9 to 1,0 of feed composition (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = {[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>] + [M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])}) of M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>. From the relationship between <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> based on Fukuda's penultimate model, the rate constants of propagation of copolymerization were evaluated; <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>111</jats:sub> = 140 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>211</jats:sub> = 4,3 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>112</jats:sub> = 778 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>212</jats:sub> = 24 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and k<jats:sub>121</jats:sub> = 19 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, suggesting a pronounced penultimate effect.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetic and electron paramagnetic resonance studies on radical polymerization. Radical copolymerization of p‐tert‐butoxy‐styrene and dibutyl fumarate in benzene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butoxystyrene (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and dibutyl fumarate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>) (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) initiated with dimethyl 2,2′‐azobisisobutyrate (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>) was studied in benzene at 60°C kinetically and by means of electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,18 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,01, indicating that homopropagation of M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> is almost negligible in the copolymerization. The copolymerization system was revealed to involve EPR‐observable propagating polymer radicals under practical copolymerization conditions. The apparent rate constants of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) and termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub>) determined by EPR show a rapid increase in the range from 0,9 to 1,0 of feed composition (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = {[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>] + [M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])}) of M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>. From the relationship between <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> based on Fukuda's penultimate model, the rate constants of propagation of copolymerization were evaluated; <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>111</jats:sub> = 140 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>211</jats:sub> = 4,3 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>112</jats:sub> = 778 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>212</jats:sub> = 24 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and k<jats:sub>121</jats:sub> = 19 L · mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, suggesting a pronounced penultimate effect.</jats:p>

Title: IUPAC recommended experimental methods and data evaluation procedures for the determination of radical copolymerization reactivity ratios from composition data
Abstract: <jats:p>The IUPAC method uses monomer composition, conversion, and copolymer composition to find reactivity ratios. Shown the optimal reactivity ratios in red and a 95% Confidence Interval in blue.</jats:p>

Title: The polymerization and copolymerization of nitroalkyl acrylates and nitroalkyl methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Nitroalkyl acrylates and methacrylates involving some new compounds were prepared. The homopolymerization of these monomers in toluene and their copolymerization with styrene in acetone were carried out with azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The rate of polymerization of the nitroalkyl acrylates showed a correlation with the number of nitro groups situated on the ester side chain. The apparent activation energies of the polymerization were found to be 22.0–27.5 kcal./mole for the nitroalkyl acrylates and about 11.5–13.0 kcal./mole for the nitroalkyl methacrylates. From the reactivity ratios and Q‐e values of the copolymerization the following information was obtained. The copolymerization behavior of nitroalkyl acrylates and methacrylates showed an alternating tendency, and these monomers belong to the conjugative monomer groups. On the reactivities of these monomers, the polarity of vinyl group was affected a little by nitro group of ester bond side, and the resonance affected little. These monomers were crosslinked with 2‐methyl‐2‐nitro‐1,3‐propylene diacrylate. Some of the polymers showed marked improvement in the physical properties of elastomers.</jats:p>

Title: Studies on the polymerization of methacrylic esters. Part III. Copolymerization of n‐butyl methacrylate and isobutyl methacrylate with vinyl acetate and acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylmethacrylate and isobutyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and vinyl acetate as comonomers have been studied and the reactivity ratios of the monomers in copolymers reactions computed.</jats:p>

Title: Studies on the polymerization of methacrylic esters. Part III. Copolymerization of n‐butyl methacrylate and isobutyl methacrylate with vinyl acetate and acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butylmethacrylate and isobutyl methacrylate with acrylonitrile and vinyl acetate as comonomers have been studied and the reactivity ratios of the monomers in copolymers reactions computed.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity Ratios and Surface Properties of Confined and Bulk ATRP Copolymerization of Butyl Methacrylate and 2Hydroxyethyl Acrylate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Radical copolymerization of crotonyl compounds with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios for the radical copolymerization of crotononitrile (CN), methyl crotonate (MC), and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐propenyl methyl ketone (PMK) with styrene (St) were measured at 60°C. in benzene and little penultimate unit effect was shown for these systems. The values obtained were: St–CN, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 24.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0; St–MC, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 26.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01; St–PMK, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 13.7, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01. The rate of copolymerization and the viscosity of the copolymer decreased markedly as the molar fraction of the crotonyl compound in the monomer mixture increased. The <jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic> values were also calculated to be as follows: CN, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.13, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.009; MC, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.36, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.015; PMK, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.61, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.024. A linear relationship was obtained between the <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of the crotonyl compounds and their Hammett constants σ<jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic></jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of crotonyl compounds with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios for the radical copolymerization of crotononitrile (CN), methyl crotonate (MC), and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐propenyl methyl ketone (PMK) with styrene (St) were measured at 60°C. in benzene and little penultimate unit effect was shown for these systems. The values obtained were: St–CN, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 24.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0; St–MC, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 26.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01; St–PMK, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 13.7, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.01. The rate of copolymerization and the viscosity of the copolymer decreased markedly as the molar fraction of the crotonyl compound in the monomer mixture increased. The <jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic> values were also calculated to be as follows: CN, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.13, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.009; MC, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.36, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.015; PMK, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.61, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.024. A linear relationship was obtained between the <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of the crotonyl compounds and their Hammett constants σ<jats:sub><jats:italic>m</jats:italic></jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of new pyrazolone‐containing monomers with certain vinyl comonomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The polymerization ability of two new pyrazolone‐containing monomers—3‐methyl‐1‐phenyl‐4‐crotonoyl‐pyrazolone‐5 (<jats:bold>Cr</jats:bold>) and 3‐methyl‐1‐phenyl‐4‐(3′‐phenyl‐acryloyl) pyrazolone‐5 (<jats:bold>Cy</jats:bold>)—was investigated. The monomers were obtained by acylation of 3‐methyl‐1‐phenyl‐pyrazolone‐5 with crotonyl chloride or cinnamoyl chloride, respectively. It was established that the two monomers do not homopolymerize either under the action of ionic and radical initiators nor with γ‐rays (doses between 2 and 10 MRad). In contrast to this, the two monomers copolymerize with other vinyl comonomers. Copolymers of <jats:bold>Cr</jats:bold> and <jats:bold>Cy</jats:bold> with methacrylic acid (MAA), methyl methacrylate (MMA), and Styrene (St) were synthesized by radical copolymerization. The molecular weights of the polymer products obtained were in the 10,000–65,000 range. It was established that the molecular weight characteristics of the copolymers were affected by the concentration of the pyrazolone‐containing monomer and by the chemical nature of the solvent used. The copolymerization of <jats:bold>Cr</jats:bold> and <jats:bold>Cy</jats:bold> with MAA was investigated in detail in order to evaluate the relative activity of the new monomers during copolymerization. The reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic>) were calculated by three different methods with good agreement. The values obtained for the monomer pairs are: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAA</jats:sub> = 0.61 ± 0.01, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Cr</jats:sub> = 0.04 ± 0.01; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAA</jats:sub> = 0.64 ± 0.05, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>Cy</jats:sub> = 0.02 ± 0.02. The <jats:italic>Q/e</jats:italic> values for <jats:bold>Cr</jats:bold> and <jats:bold>Cy</jats:bold> were determined using the reactivity ratios of both monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 2-carboxyphenyl acrylate with styrene and N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone: Reactivity ratios, molecular weights and 13C n.m.r. spectra
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerizations of methacryloyl fluoride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of methacryloyl fluoride (MAF) homopolymerization was investigated in methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) as initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) followed the expression <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.55</jats:sup>[MAF]<jats:sup>1.18</jats:sup>. The overall activation energy was calculated as 74.4 kJ/mol. The relative reactivity ratios of MAF(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.083, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.14), and methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.48, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.81) in methyl ethyl ketone were obtained. Application of the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme (in styrene copolymerization) led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 2.22 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.31. The glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of poly(MAF) was 90°C by thermomechanical analysis. Thermogravimetry of poly(MAF) showed a 10% weight loss of 228°C in air.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerizations of methacryloyl fluoride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of methacryloyl fluoride (MAF) homopolymerization was investigated in methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) as initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) followed the expression <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.55</jats:sup>[MAF]<jats:sup>1.18</jats:sup>. The overall activation energy was calculated as 74.4 kJ/mol. The relative reactivity ratios of MAF(M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerization with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.083, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.14), and methyl methacrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.48, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.81) in methyl ethyl ketone were obtained. Application of the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> scheme (in styrene copolymerization) led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 2.22 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 1.31. The glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of poly(MAF) was 90°C by thermomechanical analysis. Thermogravimetry of poly(MAF) showed a 10% weight loss of 228°C in air.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of propene with high‐1‐olefin using a MgCl<sub>2</sub>/TiCl<sub>4</sub> catalyst
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of propene and 1‐olefins including 1‐octene, 1‐decene, 1‐dodecene, 1‐tetradecene, and 1‐hexadecene were studied with the catalyst system MgCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/TiCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>‐Al(i‐Bu)<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>. It was found that the polymerization productivity and the consumption rate of propene are improved significantly in the presence of the comonomer. The total productivity of propene/1‐olefin copolymerizations decreases as follows: 1‐octene> 1‐decene>1‐dodecene>1‐hexadecene>1‐tetradecene. The reactivity ratios were estimated from the copolymerization results. <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR was used to characterize the microstructures of propene/1‐octene copolymer. Finally, the oxygen enrichment behavior of propene/1‐octene copolymer was investigated.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerizations of N‐vinyluccinmmide and of N,N‐methyl vinyl p‐toluenesulfonamide with some vinyl compounds
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerizations of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylsuccinimide (VSI) and of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methyl vinyl <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐toluenesulfonamide (VSA) with vinyl acetate (VAc), acrylonitrile (AN), stryrene (St), methyl acrylate (MA), methyl methacrylate (MMA), and n‐butyl vinyl ether (BVE) were examianed at 60°C., using benzoyl peroxide or azobisiobutyronitrile as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios and the monomer reactivity factors of VSI and VSA were as follows. VSI as monomer 1: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 15, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 (VBE); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.09, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 7.0 (St); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.05, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.185 (VAc); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.4. r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.2 (MA); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.16, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.54 (AAAN), Q<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.15, e<jats:sub>1M/s</jats:sub> = ‐0.26. VSA as monomer 1: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.42 (AN); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.68 (MMA) r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 12.3 (St); Q<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.092, e<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = ‐0.87. The difference in copolymeizability between VSI and VSA sesms to arise primarily from the difference in thieir polarity factors.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerizations of N‐vinyluccinmmide and of N,N‐methyl vinyl p‐toluenesulfonamide with some vinyl compounds
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerizations of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylsuccinimide (VSI) and of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methyl vinyl <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐toluenesulfonamide (VSA) with vinyl acetate (VAc), acrylonitrile (AN), stryrene (St), methyl acrylate (MA), methyl methacrylate (MMA), and n‐butyl vinyl ether (BVE) were examianed at 60°C., using benzoyl peroxide or azobisiobutyronitrile as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios and the monomer reactivity factors of VSI and VSA were as follows. VSI as monomer 1: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 15, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0 (VBE); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.09, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 7.0 (St); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 6.05, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.185 (VAc); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.4. r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.2 (MA); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.16, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.54 (AAAN), Q<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.15, e<jats:sub>1M/s</jats:sub> = ‐0.26. VSA as monomer 1: r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.42 (AN); r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.68 (MMA) r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 12.3 (St); Q<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.092, e<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = ‐0.87. Title: Some aspects of the copolymerization of vinylacetate and butylacrylate

Title: Reactivity ratios in group transfer copolymerization of methyl methacrylate/ethyl methacrylate and methacrylonitrile/methyl methacrylate systems obtained by semi‐integral and integral methods
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The monomer reactivity ratios for the methyl methacrylate/ethyl methacrylate (MMA/EMA) and methacrylonitrile/methyl methacrylate (MAN/MMA) systems are calculated by linearized semi‐integral and nonlinear fully integral methods. For the MMA/EMA system, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> values obtained by various methods are between 1.24 and 1.25 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>EMA</jats:sub> values between 0.30 and 0.34. For MAN/MMA system, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAN</jats:sub> values are between 3.2 and 3.8 and for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> an upper bound can be determined, i.e., <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub><0.05. The results show that previous values obtained by the linearized method (the initial Kelen‐Tüdős method) overestimate the reactivity of the less active monomer.</jats:p>

Title: Prediction of monomer reactivity ratios in radical copolymerization of vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:p>Quantitative structure-property relationship (QSPR) models are developed to predict monomer reactivity ratios (log <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>) in radical copolymerization with monomers M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> (styrene, methyl methacrylate and acrylonitrile) and M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (vinyl monomers). The quantum chemical descriptors are calculated by the density functional theory (DFT) at B3LYP level of theory with 6-31G(d) basis set. Stepwise multiple linear regression analysis and artificial neural network (ANN) were used to generate Model S (monomer 1: styrene), Model MM (monomer 1: methyl methacrylate) and Model A (monomer 1: acrylonitrile). Simulation results show that the predicted log <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> values are in good agreement with the experimental data, with the test sets possessing correlation coefficients of 0.972 for Model S, 0.933 for Model MM and 0.946 for Model A.</jats:p>

Title: General conclusions about the copolymerization of ethylene with other monomers by free radical catalysis
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The behavior of ethylene in copolymerization with methyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, diethyl fumarate, and diethyl maleate was investigated, and reactivity ratios for these systems reported. Significant deviations of all systems investigated, except ethylene–vinyl acetate, from the conventional copolymerization equation are noted and interpreted on the basis of substantial penultimate and penpenultimate effects. The consistency of the reactivity ratios developed in the systems ethylene–methyl acrylate and ethylene–methyl methacrylate with reported values for methyl acrylate–methyl methacrylate is shown by application of the relationship <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ab</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>bc</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ca</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ac</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>cb</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ba</jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: General conclusions about the copolymerization of ethylene with other monomers by free radical catalysis
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The behavior of ethylene in copolymerization with methyl acrylate, methyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, diethyl fumarate, and diethyl maleate was investigated, and reactivity ratios for these systems reported. Significant deviations of all systems investigated, except ethylene–vinyl acetate, from the conventional copolymerization equation are noted and interpreted on the basis of substantial penultimate and penpenultimate effects. The consistency of the reactivity ratios developed in the systems ethylene–methyl acrylate and ethylene–methyl methacrylate with reported values for methyl acrylate–methyl methacrylate is shown by application of the relationship <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ab</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>bc</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ca</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ac</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>cb</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ba</jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Spontaneous copolymerization of N‐butyl maleimide and ethyl α‐phenyl acrylate with high alternating tendency
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐butyl maleimide (BMI) and ethyl α‐phenyl acrylate (EPA) was successfully carried out without an initiator. A high alternating tendency was observed. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were derived by Alfrey–Price equations: <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.09, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.81 for BMI and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.21, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.5 for EPA, and the monomer reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>BMI</jats:sub> = 0.15 ± 0.01 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>EPA</jats:sub> = 0.18 ± 0.08, respectively. In this system BMI was donor and EPA was acceptor. The maximum copolymerization rate and molecular weight appeared at 70 mol % (BMI) in the feed ratio. The spontaneous alternating copolymerization was considered to be completed by a contact‐type charge‐transfer complex formed by the monomer pairs. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 94: 355–360, 2004</jats:p>
