Title: General relationships among monomers in copolymerization
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Although there is general recognition of the value of the Alfrey‐Price relationship, controversy has not abated concerning the theoretical basis for the equations and the accuracy of the monomer reactivity ratios predicted. A heretofore unrecognized possibility for approaching the problem of general monomer reactivity relationships appears to lie in the consideration of terpolymers. The relationship between monomer and terpolymer compositions is given by the equations
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
A more general and yet simplified relationship underlying terpolymers which has not been previously recognized is derived. This relationship is shown to hold for a wide range of monomer types and concentrations. The overall probability of initiating a, c, and b sequences immediately preceded by b, a, and c, respectively, and of undefined terminating units is equal to the probability of terminating a, c, and b sequences with b, a, and c units, respectively, but of undefined initiating units. This relationship of product probabilities is as follows:
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
and is shown to hold for numerous terpolymer and related copolymer systems. It follows that
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
Methods are presented for predicting the behavior of monomers A and C in copolymerization when the behaviors of A‐B and B‐C are known. Furthermore, it is shown that the value of eq. (3) is frequently in the range of 0.02–0.06. This result is probably related to the fact that terpolymerization of monomers of equal reactivity in equimolar concentrations will yield product probabilities equal to 0.037. Variations in individual probabilities require compensating changes in the other related probabilities. Application of this relationship allows the calculation of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>13</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>31</jats:sub> where <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>23</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>32</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> are known.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile and vinyl pyridine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 5‐ethyl‐2‐vinyl pyridine, 2‐vinyl pyridine, and 4‐vinyl pyridine has been investigated. The copolymer compositions have been determined by the titration of the copolymers in nonaqueous solvents with perchloric acid in glacial acetic acid, using methyl violet as an indicator. The reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, respectively, have been determined in the three systems: AN/5‐ethyl‐2‐VP, (0.02 ± 0.02 and 0.43 ± 0.05); AN/2‐VP, (0.113 ± 0.002 and 0.47 ± 0.03); and AN/4‐VP, (0.113 ± 0.005 and 0.41 ± 0.09). The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for individual monomers have been calculated and compared with each other. The data obtained present no evidence for different reactivities of 2‐ and 4‐VP. The data shows that 5‐ethyl‐2‐VP has reactivity similar to those of above two monomers, but some difference caused by its ethyl group has been found. It has been also shown that the reactivity of 5‐ethyl‐2‐VP is quite identical with that of styrene.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile and vinyl pyridine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 5‐ethyl‐2‐vinyl pyridine, 2‐vinyl pyridine, and 4‐vinyl pyridine has been investigated. The copolymer compositions have been determined by the titration of the copolymers in nonaqueous solvents with perchloric acid in glacial acetic acid, using methyl violet as an indicator. The reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, respectively, have been determined in the three systems: AN/5‐ethyl‐2‐VP, (0.02 ± 0.02 and 0.43 ± 0.05); AN/2‐VP, (0.113 ± 0.002 and 0.47 ± 0.03); and AN/4‐VP, (0.113 ± 0.005 and 0.41 ± 0.09). The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for individual monomers have been calculated and compared with each other. The data obtained present no evidence for different reactivities of 2‐ and 4‐VP. The data shows that 5‐ethyl‐2‐VP has reactivity similar to those of above two monomers, but some difference caused by its ethyl group has been found. It has been also shown that the reactivity of 5‐ethyl‐2‐VP is quite identical with that of styrene.</jats:p>

Title: Radical‐initiated homo‐ and copolymerization of methoxymethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of methoxymethyl methacrylate (MOMA) homopolymerization has been investigated in benzene, using azobis(isobutyronitrile) as an initiator. The rate of polymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) could be expressed by <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>[AIBN]<jats:sup>0.5</jats:sup> [MOMA]<jats:sup>1.19</jats:sup>. The overall activation energy was calculated to be 73.2 kJ/mol. Kinetic constants for MOMA polymerization were obtained as follows: <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub><jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> = 0.091 L<jats:sup>1/2</jats:sup> · mol<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup> · s<jats:sup>−1/2</jats:sup>; 2<jats:italic>fk</jats:italic><jats:sub>d</jats:sub> = 1.37 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>. The values of <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> in the Mark–Houwink equation, [η] = <jats:italic>KM</jats:italic><jats:sup><jats:italic>a</jats:italic></jats:sup>, where <jats:italic>K</jats:italic> = 5.89 × 10<jats:sup>−5</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> = 0.82 when <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> = <jats:styled-content><jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content><jats:sub>n</jats:sub> and the solvent was benzene. The relative reactivity ratios of MOMA (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) copolymerizations with styrene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.40, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.58) were obtained. Applying the <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> scheme led to <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.78 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = 0.67. The glass transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>) of poly(MOMA) was observed to be 64°C by DSC. Thermogravimetry of poly(MOMA) showed a 10% weight loss at 230°C in air.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization and structure of copolymers of α, β‐unsaturated aldehydes with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical bulk copolymerization of styrene with acrolein, methacrolein, and α‐ethyl‐acrolein is studied and monomer reactivity ratios are determined. Employing the dilatometric method the overall rate of polymerization is measured and discussed with respect to the special structure of copolymers. Quantitative IR spectroscopy is used to elucidate the structure of copolymers, and the absorption behavior of copolymers is compared with the statistical theory on sequence length distribution.</jats:p>

Title: The homopolymerization and copolymerization of an azo dye, N‐methyl‐N‐[4‐(2,5‐dichlorophenyl) azophenyl]‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The properties of a polymerizable dye, N‐methyl‐N‐[4‐(2,5‐dichlorophenyl)azophenyl]‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>I</jats:bold>), its homopolymerization and the properties of the homopolymer were characterized. The copolymerization parameters (r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> with styrene (St), methyl methacrylate (MMA), N,N‐dimethyl‐2‐aminoethyl methacrylate, 2,2,2‐trichloroethyl methacrylate and methacrylic acid and the rates of copolymerization were determined in benzene solution at 50°C with 0.01 M 2,2′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The Alfrey‐Price e and Q constants were calculated for <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> using the r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values for the system <jats:bold>I</jats:bold>/St. The retardative effect of the azo group in the homopolymerization and copolymerization of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> was evaluated by determining the ratio of rate constants of addition of polymer radicals to the model azo compound and to the monomer in the homopolymerization of St and MMA. The relative permittivities of monomers and their solutions were measured, and the effect of the molecular interaction of comonomers on the composition of the copolymers was discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Radical copolymerization of acrylonitrile with 2,2,2‐trifluoroethyl acrylate for dielectric materials: Structure and characterization
Abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Radical copolymerization based on acrylonitrile (AN) and 2,2,2‐Trifluoroethyl acrylate (ATRIF) initited by AIBN was investigated in acetonitrile solution. The resulting poly(AN‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐ATRIF) copolymers were characterized by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H, <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C, and <jats:sup>19</jats:sup>F NMR and IR spectroscopy, and size exclusion chromatography (SEC). Their compositions were assessed by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR. The kinetics of radical copolymerization of AN with ATRIF was investigated from sereval experiments achieved at 70 °C from initial [AN]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[ATRIF]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> molar ratios ranging between 20/80 and 80/20 and was enabled to determine the reactivity ratios of both comonomers. From the monomer—polymer copolymerization curve, the Fineman–Ross and Kelen–Tüdos laws enabled to assess the reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub>= <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.25 ± 0.04 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ATRIF</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.93 ± 0.05 at 70 °C) while the revised patterns scheme led to <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 1.03, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ATRIF</jats:sub> = 0.78 at 70 °C. In all cases, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> x <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ATRIF</jats:sub> product was close to unity, which indicates that poly(AN‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐ATRIF) copolymers exhibit a random structure. This was also confirmed by the Igarashi's and Pyun's laws which revealed the presence of AN‐ATRIF, AN‐AN, and ATRIF‐ATRIF dyads. The <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ATRIF were also assessed (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.62 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.93). The glass transition temperature values, <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>, of these copolymers increased from 17 to 61 °C as the molar percentage of ATRIF decreased from 77 to 16% in the copolymer. Thermogravimetry analysis of poly(AN‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐ATRIF) copolymers showed a good thermal stability compared to that of poly(ATRIF) homopolymer due to incorporation of AN comonomer. © 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Polym. Sci., Part A: Polym. Chem. <jats:bold>2013</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>51</jats:italic>, 3856–3866</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization parameters of the system N,N‐dimethylacrylamide‐acrylic acid
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Anionic copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Previous work with anionic copolymerizations held that the terminal carbanion played no role in determining which monomer was next added. Recent work by Graham et al. has demonstrated that this is untrue for monomers of extremely dissimilar polarities. In this paper the kinetics of copolymerization of dissimilar monomers has been developed. As a result it is shown that the ratio of monomers in the initial copolymer <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] is directly proportional to the square of the initial monomer ratio ([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> when the monomers are dissimilar. The earlier theory resulted in a first‐power proportionality for all cases. Log—log plots of the equation <jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] = <jats:italic>K</jats:italic>([M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>])<jats:italic><jats:sup>a</jats:sup></jats:italic> show that <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> has a value of 2.0 for styrene—methyl methacrylate, 1.0 for styrene—isoprene and 1.3 for methyl methacrylate—methacrylonitrile. The conclusion is drawn that values of <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> of 1.0 and 2.0 represent extremes of behavior for monomers of very similar and very dissimilar polarites. As a corollary of this it is concluded that reactivity ratios for these systems where <jats:italic>a</jats:italic> is not 1.0 are of questionable theoretical significance.</jats:p>

Title: Free‐radical solution copolymerization of the ionic liquid monomer 1‐vinyl‐3‐ethylimidazolium bromide with acrylonitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ionic liquid monomer 1‐vinyl‐3‐ethylimidazolium bromide (ViEtIM<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>Br<jats:sup>−</jats:sup>) was first used to copolymerize with acrylonitrile (AN) successfully under various conditions. This was achieved with azobisisobutyronitrile as the initiator and dimethyl sulfoxide as the solvent. The kinetics of this copolymerization were studied. The values of the monomer apparent reactivity ratios were calculated by the Kelen–Tüdos method. The apparent reactivity ratios of ViEtIM<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>Br<jats:sup>−</jats:sup> (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ViEtIM+Br−</jats:sub>) and AN (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub>) were similar at polymerization conversions of less than 10% (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>AN</jats:sub> = 0.954, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>ViEtIM+Br−</jats:sub> = 0.976). The copolymers were obtained with high molecular weights and high hydrophilicities. The copolymers were characterized by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, differential scanning calorimetry, and thermogravimetric analysis. These copolymers may be potentially useful in the preparation of precursor fibers and carbon fibers. © 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2009</jats:p>

Title: Determination of propagation and termination rate constants for some methacrylates in their radical polymerizations
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Rotating sector determinations of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> and 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> for ten methacrylates undergoing radical polymerization were carried out at 30°C. Ester groups in the monomers were: isopropyl, ethyl, β‐cyclohexylethyl, methyl, γ‐phenylpropyl, β‐phenylethyl, β‐methoxyethyl, benzyl, β‐chloroethyl, and phenyl. Values of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> obtained were 121, 126, 1190, 141, 149, 228, 249, 1250, 254, and 411 l./mole‐sec., respectively; values of 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> × 10<jats:sup>−6</jats:sup> were 4.52, 7.35, 32.8, 11.6, 0.813, 1.88, 9.30, 41.9, 6.71, and 11.9 l./mole‐sec., respectively.</jats:p><jats:p>Omitting the data for the β‐cyclohexylethyl and benzyl esters, a Taft correlation, log <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = (0.70 ± 0.18)σ* + 2.2, was established, where σ* denotes Taft's polar substitutent constants for the above‐mentioned ester groups. The steric substituent constants <jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>s</jats:italic></jats:sub> were found to have no influence on <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>. Combination of <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> data from copolymerization studies with styrene or methyl methacrylate as M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> comonomer revealed that the more reactive monomer gave rise to the more reactive polymer radical. Monomer viscosities and molar volumes of the ester groups were found to correlate with 2<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>.</jats:p>

Title: Homopolymerization of styrenic monomers and their copolymerization with ethylene using group 4 <scp>non‐metallocene</scp> catalysts
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Homopolymerization of styrenic monomers (St, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Me‐St, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu‐St, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>BuO‐St) and their copolymerization with ethylene, with the use of [(<jats:sup><jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu2</jats:sup>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>NN′)ZrCl]<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(μ‐O) (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) and (<jats:sup><jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu2</jats:sup>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>NN′)TiCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), where <jats:sup><jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu2</jats:sup>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>NN′ = Me<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>N(CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>N(CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>‐2‐O<jats:sup>−</jats:sup>‐3,5‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>‐C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, is explored in the presence of MMAO and (<jats:italic>i</jats:italic>Bu)<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>Al/Ph<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>CB(C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>F<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>. The ethylene/styrenic monomers copolymerization with <jats:bold>1</jats:bold>/MMAO produces exclusively copolymers with high activity and good comonomer incorporation whereas the other catalytic systems yield mixtures of copolymers and homopolymers. The use of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐alkyl styrene derivatives instead of styrene raises the catalytic activity, comonomer incorporation and molecular weights of the copolymers. Complex <jats:bold>2</jats:bold> exhibits higher activity in homopolymerization of styrenic monomers than <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> irrespective of the kind of the activator employed. A clear dependence is observed for the molecular weight and catalyst activity against the kind of the styrenic monomer. The obtained polymers were atactic and only the complex <jats:bold>2</jats:bold>, when activated by MMAO, promoted the highly syndiospecific polymerization of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Me‐St and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>Bu‐St. Poly(<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>BuO‐St) exhibits fiber‐forming properties.</jats:p>

Title: The effect of sodium methacrylate on the soapless emulsion copolymerization of methyl methacrylate and n‐butyl acrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The soapless emulsion polymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate (BA) containing various concentrations of sodium methacrylate (NaMA) or methacrylic acid (MMA) is studied. The hydrosoluble yields in final latexes are not larger than 1.3–5%, depending on the concentration of NaMA used. Below 25% conversion, the change of conversion with reaction time follows the square rule and the particle size is proportional to the 2/3 power of time. Above 25% conversion, serious gel effect occurs, and the conversion follows the seventh power on time and the growth of particle diameter obeys the 2.5 power on time. The multiple glass transition (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>) occur below 20% conversion, where monomer droplets exist. NaMA added induces more <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s. The effect of molecular weight of the copolymers obtained on <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub> (even the molecular weight distributions were shown to be shouldertype bimodal) is estimated to be insignificant. Thus, the heterogeneity of copolymer compositions for multiple <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>s is ascribed to be caused from neither the molecular weight heterogeneity nor the shifts in compositions due to the difference of the monomer reactivity ratios. Referring to the results mentioned, we assume the sublayer surrounding the particle, rich with SO<jats:sub>4</jats:sub><jats:sup>−</jats:sup> and COO<jats:sup>−</jats:sup> groups, and the concentration gradients of monomers in particles to illustrate particle morphology. In addition, the relatively hydrophilic sublayer is proposed to be closely relative with the occurrence of the composition heterogeneity in particles.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of styrene with Zn(II), Co(II), Ni(II) and Cu(II) acrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of styrene with Zn(II), Co(II), Ni(II) and Cu(II) acrylates in methanol at 60°C was studied and that of styrene with Cu(II) acrylate also in acetonitrile at 80°C. In a given period of time an increase of conversion was observed with increasing concentration of the first three metal acrylates in mixtures with styrene. With Cu(II) acrylate, however, a decrease of conversion was found. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined as follows: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 1,10, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-2.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0025116X:media:MACP021860114:tex2gif-inf-2"/> = 0,90; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 1,74, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-5.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0025116X:media:MACP021860114:tex2gif-inf-5"/> = 0,56; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 1,83, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-8.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0025116X:media:MACP021860114:tex2gif-inf-8"/> = 0,53; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>St</jats:sub> = 5,94, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-11.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0025116X:media:MACP021860114:tex2gif-inf-11"/> = 0,12 (in acetonitrile). The products of the reactivity ratios, almost equal to one, reflect an “ideal” copolymerization and therefore a very little alternating tendency in propagation reactions. The Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> parameters for the metal acrylates were calculated and discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Radical polymerization behavior of N,N‐disubstituted acrylamide: Absolute rate constants for polymerization and copolymerization of N‐acryloylpiperidine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The absolute rate constants of propagation (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub>) and of termination (<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐acryloylpiperidine (NAPi) were determined by the rotating sector method in bulk; <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 273 and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub> = 1.79 × 10<jats:sup>7</jats:sup> L/mol s at 30°C. It was noted that <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> for NAPi was 100 times smaller than that for N,N‐dimethylacrylamide (DMAcAm). The absolute rate constants of cross‐propagations for copolymerizations with common monomers were evaluated by combination of the <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> value and the monomer reactivity ratios. Quantitative comparison of the rate constants with those of DMAcAm and poly(DMAcAm) radical shows that NAPi is as reactive as DMAcAm and the smaller <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>p</jats:italic></jats:sub> value for NAPi is ascribable to much the lower reactivity of the poly(NAPi) radical. The large difference in reactivity of the polymer radicals is discussed in relation to the steric factor of the piperadino and the dimethylamino groups which seems to affect the capability of the carboxamide group to stabilize the polymer radical.</jats:p>

Title: Cationic Copolymerization of 2-Chloroethyl Vinyl Ether with Styrene Derivatives. II. Temperature Dependence of Monomer Reactivity Ratios
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Characterization by tin‐specific size exclusion chromatography of the free radical copolymerization of tributyltin methacrylate and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of tributyltin methacrylate (TBTM) and methyl methacrylate (MMA) comprise an important class of biocidal slow‐release organometallic polymers (OMPs). Little is known of the kinetics and mechanism of copolymerization. TBTM and MMA were copolymerized in the presence of a free radical initiator (benzoyl peroxide) at 80.1°C. Aliquots, taken at preselected intervals from 0 to 1440 min, were fractionated by size exclusion chromatography (SEC) coupled with ultraviolet (UV) and tin‐specific graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) detectors. A UV absorbance observed at 254 nm was associated with low‐molecular‐weight species, decreasing in concentration continuously with time of reaction. Tin‐specific GFAA indicated a decrease in low‐molecular‐weight species (ca. 350 daltons) with concurrent increases in high‐molecular‐weight species (ca. 40,000 daltons). The fraction of high molecular‐weight increased as a linear function of the logarithm of the time of reaction. SEC–UV–GFAA thus provides a tool of major importance for characterizing the time dependence and continuity of the process by which monomers of TBTM are converted to a useful bioactive slow‐release coating material.</jats:p>

Title: Polymers containing fluorinated ketone groups. III. Synthesis of styrene/p‐vinyltrifluoroacetophenone copolymers by modification of polystyrene and the copolymerization of monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of styrene/<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinyltrifluoroacetophenone were prepared by two different reaction routes: (1) modification of polystyrene with trifluoroacetyl chloride and (2) copolymerization of styrene and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐vinyltrifluoroacetophenone (VTFA). There appears to be a limit to the modification method because only a maximum content of 14.5 mole % trifluoroacetyl functionality could be attached to the polymer before the onset of crosslinking. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was used to determine their <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>g</jats:italic></jats:sub>'s. In addition, the reactivity ratios of styrene and VTFA were investigated. The reactivity ratios and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.30 ± 0.09 (styrene) and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.3 ± 0.3 (VTFA); <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.0 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = −0.8 (styrene); <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.44 and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.93 (VTFA).</jats:p>

Title: Living/controlled copolymerization of acrylates with nonactivated alkenes
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The living/controlled copolymerization of methyl acrylate with 1‐alkenes and norbornene derivatives through several radical polymerization techniques has been achieved. These techniques include atom transfer radical polymerization, reversible addition–fragmentation transfer polymerization, nitroxide‐mediated polymerization, and degenerative transfer polymerization. These systems display many of the characteristics of a living polymerization process: the molecular weight increases linearly with the overall conversion, but the polydispersity remains low. Novel block copolymers have been synthesized through the sequential addition of monomers or chain extension. © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 42: 6175–6192, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Cationic copolymerization of 3‐methyltetrahydrofuran and 3,3‐dimethyloxetane: Structural study of the copolymers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The bulk cationic copolymerization of 3‐methyltetrahydrofuran and 3,3‐dimethyloxetane was studied at 0°C using acetylhexafluoroantimonate as initiator. Values of the composition of the copolymers and the dyad and triad probabilities were obtained by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐ and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C‐NMR spectroscopy. A kinetic scheme was proposed for this copolymerization and the values of the reactivity ratios were directly determined from the dyad probabilities. The experimental values of the triad probabilities were found to be in good agreement with those calculated from the reactivity ratios.</jats:p>

Title: Methyl α‐cyanoacrylate. II. Copolymerization studies
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of methyl alpha;‐‐cyanoacrylate with five reference monomers gave values <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = +2.1 and of log <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 0.65, with much scatter in the latter value. Alternating copolymers are formed by copolymerization with monomers of <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = −0.8 or less. Bulk copolymerization with such monomers could not be accomplished, as a rapid noncatalyzed polymerization occurred upon mixing even at 0°C. Random copolymers with methyl methacrylate could be prepared in bulk; those with ca. 10% methyl methacrylate had physical properties similar to the homopolymer of methyl α‐‐cyanoacrylate, except that the heat distortion temperature was lowered 10–15°C. The alternating copolymers were more thermally stable than the random copolymers. Glass temperature values for alternating copolymers do not appear to agree with values predicted from equations for random copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Monoalkylitaconates–vinylpyrrolidone copolymers. 2. Reactivity ratios and viscometric behaviour in dilute solutions
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of mono‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐decyl and mono‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐decyl and mono‐<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐dodecyl itaconate with vinylpyrrolidone (MOI‐VP, MDI‐VP and MDoI‐VP) was carried out using AIBN as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined by the Fineman‐Ross and Kelen‐Tüdös methods. Values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> were found to be less than unity for MOI‐VP, MDI‐VP and MDoI‐VP, corresponding to random copolymers with some tendency to alternance. Copolymers of various compositions were studied in solution, and Mark‐Houwink‐Kuhn‐Sakurada relationships were established in ethanol for MOI‐VP and MDI‐VP copolymers, and in 1‐propanol for MDoI‐VP. The rigidity factors s̀ and the characteristic ratio <jats:italic>C</jats:italic><jats:sub>∞</jats:sub> were obtained from <jats:italic>K</jats:italic><jats:sub>θ</jats:sub> values determined by using the Stockmayer‐Fixman relation. In all the copolymers the introduction of vinylpyrrolidone units produces flexibility of the polymer chain relative to the poly(monoitaconate) homopolymers, and the solution properties of these copolymers can be described by assuming a random coil model instead of a rigid rod or wormlike model as in poly(monoitaconates).</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of n-butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate in xylene solvent
Abstract:
<jats:p>Introduction: Copolymers are being used in a variety of fields because of their diversity and since any change could result in significant modifications. The butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate copolymer is an extensively used polymer system with many advantages. This study aims to analyze some changes in copolymerization, from using different time or temperature of synthesis, in order to find an optimal process that can be applied in Vietnam.
Methods: Copolymerization of butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate copolymer with different butyl acrylate/methyl methacrylate monomer ratios was done using Xylene solvent. Copolymer compositions were determined from the Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectra and Gel permeation chromatography.
Results: The experimental results indicate that the copolymer was successfully synthesized. The highest molecular weight was 15,591 g/mol, with the lowest dispersity of 1.53 at 100 oC after 6 hours of copolymerization.
 </jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of vinyl acetate with ethyl α‐cyanocinnamate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Trisubstituted ethylene, ethyl α‐cyanocinnamate, is readily copolymerized with vinyl acetate by a conventional radical initiator. Terminal, penultimate, and “complex” copolymerization models were applied by using the data of composition of the copolymers obtained in bulk and by copolymerization in benzene, ethyl acetate, and chloroform. The model based on the participation of the monomer complexes describes satisfactorily the deviation from the terminal copolymerization model. The proton NMR analyses of the monomer mixtures indicate that the interaction between the monomers leads to the formation of weak monomer complexes. Kinetic studies of the initial rate dependence on the total monomer concentration and monomer feed composition enabled us to evaluate the degree of participation of the free uncomplexed monomers and the monomer complex in the propagation reactions. The contribution of the complexed monomers in the propagation stages increases with the increase in total monomer concentration. The initial rate of the copolymerization is proportional to the square root of the initiator concentration, thus confirming the bimolecular termination of the macrochains. The rate constants of the addition reactions of the complex and free monomers were evaluated from the kinetic studies. The quantitative kinetic treatment provided information regarding the relative weight of the termination reaction and indicated that the termination in the system occurs predominantly by the cross‐termination reaction between two growing polymer radicals with different kinds of monomer units at the ends. Additional information on the termination in this system was obtained from viscosity measurements.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization behavior of m‐ and p‐styrenesulfonyl fluorides
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Styrenesulfonyl fluorides are useful starting materials for the synthesis of a broad range of polymers and copolymers of styrenesulfonic acid.</jats:p><jats:p>The reactivity ratios were determined for the copolymerization of <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>‐ and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐styrenesulfonyl fluoride with styrene and with methyl acrylate:

Title: Modeling of unseeded emulsion copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A mathematical model for the unseeded emulsion copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate has been developed. This model, which includes a new rate coefficient for radical desorption, was used to analyze the effect of the styrene/methyl methacrylate molar ratio in the initial charge on the number of particles, overall conversion and copolymer composition. It was found that the number of particles increased with the methyl methacrylate content and that a drift of the copolymer composition resulted during the polymerization of styrene/methyl methacrylate molar ratios other than 50/50. Good agreement between experimental results and model predictions was achieved.</jats:p>

Title: Generality of product probability values in unifying and predicting relationships among monomers in copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>It is shown that a knowledge of the reactivity ratios for the binary systems A–B and B–C allows reactivity ratios for the copolymer system A–C to be calculated from the relationship: <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ab</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>bc</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ca</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ac</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>cb</jats:sub><jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:sub>ba</jats:sub> =  (a constant). The various probabilities include the possibilities of adding A, B, or C monomers to any of the corresponding radicals and can be expressed in terms of binary reactivity ratios. At equimolar concentrations it is shown that for systems of three conjugated or three unconjugated monomers  approximates 0.037. Similarly, for systems of two conjugated and one unconjugated monomers or two unconjugated and one conjugated monomers  approximates 0.006. Once the appropriateness of these constants is established, it is shown how the relationship may be used to assess the most probable values among widely varying reported reactivity ratios. It is shown that the values of the constant  for different combinations of monomers allow the assessment of the reactivity of conjugated monomers compared with unconjugated monomers for conjugated or unconjugated radicals. It develops that the reactivity of unconjugated monomers is between 5 and 10% of that of conjugated monomers for unconjugated radicals. For more precise assessment of unknown reactivity ratios it is suggested that  is a product function of unique reactivity parameters characteristic of the individual monomers involved.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of crotonic acid with vinylpyrrolidone
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization studies. III. Reactivity ratios of model ethylene copolymerizations and their use in Q–e calculations
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of ethylene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, vinyl chloride, vinyl acetate, and vinyl fluoride have been measured at 1000 atm. The respective values and the experimental temperatures are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 11.9, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, = 0.03, 70°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.6, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.24, 90°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.07, 90°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.16, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.39, 160°C. Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ethylene calculated from these reactivity ratios, uncorrected for differences in reaction pressure, are 0.03 and −0.43, respectively. New <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub>) for these four comonomers were calculated on the basis of ethylene rather than styrene as the reference monomer. Assuming that the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> values for ethylene are 1.0 and zero, respectively, the monomer's <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> value are as follows: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, 33.3, + 1.02; vinyl chloride, 4.2, + 0.37; vinyl acetate, 0.93, ∼0; vinyl fluoride, 0.25, + 0.6. These <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> values give calculated reactivity ratios which are in reasonable agreement with experimental ones. Good agreement is also obtained when the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> value for the vinyl acetate/ethylene copolymerization is compared with the directly determined rate constant ratio for the addition of an ethyl radical to ethylene and to vinyl acetate, respectively, calculated from previously published data.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization studies. III. Reactivity ratios of model ethylene copolymerizations and their use in Q–e calculations
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of ethylene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, vinyl chloride, vinyl acetate, and vinyl fluoride have been measured at 1000 atm. The respective values and the experimental temperatures are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 11.9, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, = 0.03, 70°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.6, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.24, 90°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 1.08, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.07, 90°C.; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.16, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 4.39, 160°C. Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for ethylene calculated from these reactivity ratios, uncorrected for differences in reaction pressure, are 0.03 and −0.43, respectively. New <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values (<jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub>) for these four comonomers were calculated on the basis of ethylene rather than styrene as the reference monomer. Assuming that the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> values for ethylene are 1.0 and zero, respectively, the monomer's <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> value are as follows: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate, 33.3, + 1.02; vinyl chloride, 4.2, + 0.37; vinyl acetate, 0.93, ∼0; vinyl fluoride, 0.25, + 0.6. These <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> values give calculated reactivity ratios which are in reasonable agreement with experimental ones. Good agreement is also obtained when the <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> value for the vinyl acetate/ethylene copolymerization is compared with the directly determined rate constant ratio for the addition of an ethyl radical to ethylene and to vinyl acetate, respectively, calculated from previously published data.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 2‐sulfoethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of 2‐sulfoethyl methacrylate, (SEM) were prepared with ethyl methacrylate, ethyl acrylate, vinylidene chloride, and styrene in 1,2‐dimethoxyethane solution with <jats:italic>N,N</jats:italic>′‐azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. The monomer reactivity ratios with SEM (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were: vinylidene chloride, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.6 ± 0.5, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.22 ± 0.03; ethyl acrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 3.2 ± 0.6, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.30 ± 0.05; ethyl methacrylate, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.0 ± 0.4, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.0 ± 0.1; styrene, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.6 ± 0.2, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.37 ± 0.03. The values of the copolymerization parameters calculated from the monomer reactivity ratios were <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> = +0.6 and <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> = 1.4. Comparison of the monomer reactivities indicates that SEM is similar to ethyl methacrylate with regard to copolymerization reactivity in 1,2‐dimethoxyethane solution. The sodium salt of 2‐sulfoethyl methacrylate, SEM<jats:sup>⊖</jats:sup>Na<jats:sup>⊕</jats:sup>, was copolymerized with 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) in water solution. Reactivity ratios of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.7 ± 0.1 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.6 ± 0.1 were obtained, indicating a lower reactivity of SEM<jats:sup>⊖</jats:sup>Na<jats:sup>⊕</jats:sup> in water as compared to SEM in 1,2‐dimethoxyethane. This decreased reactivity was attributed to greater ionic repulsion between reacting species in the aqueous medium.</jats:p>

Title: Acroleindiethylacetal: Reaction with free radicals and copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reaction between acroleindiethylacetal (3.3‐diethoxypropene) and free radicals and the behaviour of this acetal in the free radical copolymerization with unsaturated monomers has been investigated. The decomposition of benzoyl peroxide and tert.‐butyl peroxide in acroleindiethylacetal has been studied in the liquid phase. On the basis of the obtained products a mechanism is proposed which involves the abstraction of a hydrogen atom by a primary radical from a carbon atom which is adjacent to oxygen. We also tried to copolymerize the acetal with several conventional comonomers but copolymers were only obtained when acrylonitrile and maleic anhydride were used. The remarkably uniform composition of the copolymers from the acetal and maleic anhydride is explained through a donor‐acceptor complex between the two monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios from analysis of triad fractions—analysis of the copolymerization of styrene and acrylonitrile as evidence for the penultimate model
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Effect of pressure on free‐radical copolymerization kinetics. III. An improved method of measuring monomer reactivity ratios under high‐pressure conditions
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To investigate high‐pressure copolymerizations a sampling technique has been developed enabling continual on‐line GLC analysis of the reaction mixture. As a result more reliable kinetic data are obtained. This new “sequential sampling” method, allowing the use of gaseous monomers, has been tested for the copolymerization of ethylene with vinyl propionate at 118 MPa and 335 K with <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol as solvent. The results are compared with those obtained with the “quenching” method used so far, which yields compositional data on the reaction mixture before and after the high‐pressure stage, only. It is shown that the “sequential sampling” method is the most adequate method of determining high‐pressure monomer reactivity ratios. Furthermore, it is an important safety feature that the present procedure can be easily remote controlled. The present experimental method is neither restricted to copolymerization nor to gas‐chromatographic analysis of the reaction mixture.</jats:p>

Title: Free radical copolymerization of ethylene
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Estimation of Reactivity Ratios in the Copolymerization of Styrene and VeoVa‐10
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The styrene and vinyl neodecanoate copolymerization system shows a strong tendency to form two separate homopolymers. In order to improve the feeding strategies and hence the copolymer uniformity, it is necessary to know the reactivity ratios between these monomers. The error‐in‐variables‐method (EVM) is the most recommended mathematical procedure for estimating these parameters. Experiments on free‐radical copolymerization in solution in sealed ampoules are carried out to provide data for the conversion (via gravimetry) and fractional monomer compositions (via Fourier transform mid‐infrared (mid‐FT‐IR) spectroscopy). These data allow estimation of the reactivity ratios. EVM appropriately takes into account the experimental errors in the data and allows determination of the reactivity ratio values by the Mayo–Lewis model (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 28.60 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.23). The convergence and robustness of the method decrease considerably with a larger discrepancy between the reactivity values.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Vinyl Compounds with Dienes<sup>1</sup>
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of N‐vinylurethane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Vinylurethane (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), prepared by the method of Hart, has been copolymerized with vinylacetate vinylpyrrolidone, acrylic acid, and maleic anhydride. From the copolymerization reactivity ratios with vinyl acetate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.33; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.33) and with vinylpyrrolidone (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.42; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2) <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were evaluated, in agreement with the Alfrey‐Price equation, to 0.12 and −1.91, respectively. These results are compared to those of other <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐substituted monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of N‐vinylurethane
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Vinylurethane (<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>), prepared by the method of Hart, has been copolymerized with vinylacetate vinylpyrrolidone, acrylic acid, and maleic anhydride. From the copolymerization reactivity ratios with vinyl acetate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.33; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.33) and with vinylpyrrolidone (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.42; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 2) <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were evaluated, in agreement with the Alfrey‐Price equation, to 0.12 and −1.91, respectively. These results are compared to those of other <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐substituted monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Aqueous‐Phase Copolymerization of N‐Vinylpyrrolidone and N‐Vinylformamide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Aqueous‐phase batch free‐radical copolymerization of NVP and NVF is studied at 60 and 85 °C with varying initial monomer mixture compositions and monomer to water ratios. The rate of monomer conversion is found to increase with increasing NVP molar fraction and with decreasing total monomer concentration, in accordance with the expected behavior based on homopolymerization kinetics. The copolymer composition is equal to the initial comonomer composition, indicating monomer reactivity ratios to be unity. A terminal copolymerization model provides a good description of polymerization rate, copolymer composition, and polymer molar mass distributions using the same kinetic rate coefficients as used to previously describe the homopolymerization of the two monomers.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Acrylamide with Acrylic acid
Abstract: <jats:p>Low conversion copolymerization of acrylamide AM (monomer-1) have been conducted with acrylic acid AA in dry benzene at 70°C , using Benzoyl peroxide BPO as initiator . The copolymer composition has been determined by elemental analysis. The monomer reactivity ratios have been calculated by the Kelen-Tudos and  Finman-Ross graphical procedures. The derived reactivity ratios (r1, r2) are: (0.620, 0.996)  for (AM / AA)  systems , and found that the reactivity of the monomer AA is more than the monomer AM in the copolymerization of (AA/AM) system. The reactivity ratios values were used for microstructures calculation.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Acrylamide with Acrylic acid
Abstract: <jats:p>Low conversion copolymerization of acrylamide AM (monomer-1) have been conducted with acrylic acid AA in dry benzene at 70°C , using Benzoyl peroxide BPO as initiator . The copolymer composition has been determined by elemental analysis. The monomer reactivity ratios have been calculated by the Kelen-Tudos and  Finman-Ross graphical procedures. The derived reactivity ratios (r1, r2) are: (0.620, 0.996)  for (AM / AA)  systems , and found that the reactivity of the monomer AA is more than the monomer AM in the copolymerization of (AA/AM) system. The reactivity ratios values were used for microstructures calculation.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effect in radical copolymerization of styrene with p‐aminostyrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐Aminostyrene (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>, M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and styrene (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were radically copolymerized at 60°C in various solvents. There is a significant solvent effect on monomer reactivity ratios, especially on <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, suggesting a specific interaction between the solvent and the polymer radical with the <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐aminostyrene moiety at the terminal position. In order to clarify the solvent factor influencing the relative reactivity, the hydrogen‐bond‐accepting basicity of the solvent (β) was determined from enhanced UV shifts for <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> relative to <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethyl‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐aminostyrene. Regression analysis of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> with the solvatochromic parameters revealed that β is the major factor responsible for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>‐variations.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization de l'acenaphtylene avec le n-vinylcarbazole
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Iodine transfer copolymerization of vinylidene fluoride and α‐trifluoromethacrylic acid in emulsion process without any surfactants
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The synthesis of poly(VDF‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐TFMA) copolymers (where VDF and TFMA stand for vinylidene fluoride and α‐trifluoromethacrylic acid, respectively) by iodine transfer polymerization without any surfactant is presented. First, the synthesis and the control of the copolymerization of VDF and TFMA were investigated in the presence of two chain transfer agents, 1‐perfluorohexyl iodide (C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>F<jats:sub>13</jats:sub>I) and 1,4‐diodoperfluorobutane (IC<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>F<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>I). TFMA monomer was incorporated in the copolymer in good yields. Moreover, the molecular weights of the resulting poly(VDF‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐TFMA) copolymers were in good agreement with the theoretical values for feed of TFMA/VDF ratios that ranged from 50/50 to 0/100 mol %, showing that TFMA does not disturb the controlled radical polymerization of VDF. The microstructures of the produced copolymers were characterized by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H and <jats:sup>19</jats:sup>F NMR to assess the amount of each comonomer, and the molecular weights and the end‐groups of the copolymers. The results on the control of the copolymerization were compared to those obtained with and without the presences of TFMA and surfactant. The addition of a low amount of TFMA improved the control of the polymerization of VDF without using any surfactant. Also, the size of particles, assessed by light scattering, was smaller than 200 nm. The addition of TFMA in low proportions, that is, 5 to 10 mol %, enabled us to stabilize the particle size and to decrease the size by one order of magnitude. The emulsifying behavior of TFMA (in low amount in the copolymer, that is, <10 mol %) was similar to those achieved when a surfactant was added. Indeed, neither sedimentation nor destabilization was observed after several days. The reactivity ratios for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>TFMA</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VDF</jats:sub> were 0 and 1.6 at 80 °C, respectively. © 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 47: 4710–4722, 2009</jats:p>

Title: Analysis of the linear methods of determining copolymerization reactivity ratios, 12. Copolymerization of styrene or methyl methacrylate with N‐p‐tolylcitraconimide or fumarodinitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>For copolymerization of styrene or methyl methacrylate with <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐tolylcitraconimide (in toluene) or fumarodinitrile (in benzene) at 60°C with 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator, the composition of the resulting copolymers was measured as a function of the monomer feed composition. To provide good accuracy of reaction modelling in terms of the terminal and penultimate models, the linearized forms of both models were applied assuring high sensitivity of the evaluation. Among the systems considered the styrene/fumarodinitrile system with <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>′<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>r</jats:italic>′<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ≈ 10 was found to copolymerize according to the penultimate mechanism to a significant degree.</jats:p>

Title: New synthetic route to α‐alkylacrylonitriles and a study of their homopolymerization and copolymerization reactions
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Aliphatic aldehydes have been condensed with cyanoacetic acid and the resulting olefin intermediates hydrogenated and then submitted to a Mannich‐type reaction to produce α‐alkylacrylonitriles with the alkyl groups ranging from C<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> to C<jats:sub>12</jats:sub>. It was not necessary to isolate the intermediates when the reactions were carried out in acetonitrile solutions. The α‐alkylacrylonitriles with C<jats:sub>7</jats:sub> or higher alkyl groups in the chains would polymerize by radical initiation in emulsion to give polymers which were sticky, rubbery products and showed adhesive characteristics. Anionic initiation did not yield polymers with the α‐alkylacrylonitriles containing high alkyl groups but did convert the C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> to C<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> alkyl‐substituted acrylonitriles to low molecular weight colored products. Some copolymers of α‐alkylacrylonitriles with acrylonitrile were prepared in emulsion by radical initiation. The monomer ratios in these copolymers were determined by nuclear magnetic resonance spectra.</jats:p>

Title: Analysis of Linear Methods for Determining Copolymerization Reactivity Ratios. III. Linear Graphic Method for Evaluating Data Obtained at High Conversion Levels
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: N‐Oxyl‐Controlled Radical Copolymerization of Styrene with Ethyl α‐Cyanocinnamate
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:bold>Summary:</jats:bold> The block copolymers of styrene and ethyl <jats:italic>α</jats:italic>‐cyanocinnamate were prepared in dioxane and xylene with TEMPO‐capped polystyrene (PSTEMPO) as macroinitiator. The copolymerizations were carried out at 125 °C and 135 °C. The reactivity ratios were determined according to Kelen Tüdos and compared with the reactivity ratios from the radical copolymerization of styrene and ethyl <jats:italic>α</jats:italic>‐cyanocinnamate determined by Kohn et al. The influence of the comonomer ethyl <jats:italic>α</jats:italic>‐cyanocinnamate on the glass transition temperature was studied in comparison with the corresponding homopolystyrene.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:caption><jats:p>Plots of conversion versus molecular weight distributions of the polymerizations with styrene at 125 °C.</jats:p></jats:caption><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text><jats:caption><jats:p>Plots of conversion versus molecular weight distributions of the polymerizations with styrene at 125 °C.</jats:p></jats:caption></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of monomethyl maleate and ‐fumarate with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of monomethyl maleate (MMM) or monomethyl fumarate (MMF) with styrene is investigated. The dependence of the copolymerization rates on the composition of the monomer mixture and the monomer reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> are determined. An identical structure of the MMM and MMF polymer radicals was found, that is the <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub>‐values of both copolymerization systems are equal (monomer 1 ≡ styrene; monomer 2 ≡ MMM or MMF). From this knowledge the difference of the copolymerization rates between MMM and MMF can be attributed to the <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub>‐values.</jats:p>

Title: Organometallic polymers. XXIV. Radical‐initiated copolymerization of ferrocenylmethyl acrylate and methacrylate with acrylonitrile, maleic anhydride, and N‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ferrocenylmethyl acrylate (I) and ferrocenylmethyl methacrylate (II) have been readily copolymerized with maleic anhydride in benzene–ethyl acetate solutions. Similarly, II has been copolymerized with both acrylonitrile and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone in benzene solutions to give higher molecular weight copolymers in high yields. In all cases azobisisobutyronitrile has been the initiator. Based on <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values obtained, the metal carbonyl substituent acts as an electron‐withdrawing group. Over a wide range of comonomers (<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐2‐pyrrolidone, styrene, vinyl acetate, methyl acrylate, acrylonitrile, and maleic anhydride) I and II exhibit <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> values lower than (and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> values higher than) similar copolymerizations with methyl acrylate or methyl methacrylate. Further more, the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> values found for I (0.03–0.11) and II (0.08–0.18) are smaller than those for methyl acrylate (0.46) and methyl methacrylate (0.74). Thus, I and II are less reactive than expected, presumably due to steric effects.</jats:p>

Title: The temperature dependence of the monomer reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of styrene with phenyl and tert-butyl cinnamates
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Unexpected reactivity for the RAFT copolymerization of oligo(ethylene glycol) methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Homo‐ and copolymers of di(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (DEGMA) and oligo(ethyleneglycol) methyl ether methacrylate (OEGMA<jats:sub>1100</jats:sub>) were synthesized with various chain lengths via reversible addition fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) polymerization in ethanol using [M]/[RAFT] ratios of 100 and 200. Kinetic investigations on the homo‐ and copolymerization of these monomers were performed using a parallel synthesizer resulting in well‐defined polymers with polydispersity indices mostly below 1.3. The polymerization kinetics are presented and discussed in detail surprisingly revealing that the DEGMA homopolymerization is slower than the OEGMA<jats:sub>1100</jats:sub> homopolymerization. Transfer coefficients <jats:italic>c</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:0887624X:media:POLA23363:tex2gif-stack-1" /> were estimated to be ∼0.5 for the RAFT polymerization of both DEGMA and OEGMA<jats:sub>1100</jats:sub> resulting in hybrid behavior at the beginning of the polymerizations. Subsequent copolymerization also revealed fast incorporation of the OEGMA<jats:sub>1100</jats:sub> and relatively slow incorporation of DEGMA resulting in well‐defined copolymers with a molecular weight up to 100 kDa and polydispersities around 1.20. © 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 47: 2811–2820, 2009</jats:p>

Title: Some aspects of inverse emulsion copolymerization of acrylamide with methacrylic acid
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Investigations on the continuous copolymerization of acrylonitrile with methyl methacrylate in a heterogeneous system
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Investigations were carried out on continuous copolymerization of acrylonitrile with methyl methacrylate in a tank type reactor and in a heterogeneous system. It was found that the reaction rate of copolymerization is directly proportional to the concentration of comonomers in the reactor and proportional to the residence time to the −0.65 power. Investigations on the influence of the concentration of initiator upon the reaction rate gave evidence of a change in the mechanism of termination reaction at higher concentrations of initiator in the system. The molecular weights of the copolymers, at sufficiently long residence times, were constant. The composition of the copolymers obtained was in accordance with theoretical anticipations. Some discrepancies between the equations derived and the experimental results were tentatively explained on the basis of the influence of the heterogeneous nature of the system.</jats:p>

Title: Comprehensive Study of Free Radical Copolymerization Using a Monte Carlo Simulation Method, 1
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:bold>Summary:</jats:bold> In order to investigate the influence of reactivity ratios and initial feed composition on the microstructure of macromolecules in free radical copolymerization, a comprehensive study was carried out using a Monte Carlo simulation method. As a result, a new procedure was introduced to modify the works of others on the initiation step. The variation of the copolymer composition and the fashion of the arrangement of monomers in simulated chains were evaluated as a function of copolymerization parameters. The model was capable of monitoring any change in azeotropy as well as the magnitude and direction of composition drift from the azeotrope point. The maximum reachable conversion (MRC) was predicted for different combinations of initial feed compositions and reactivity ratios. According to the simulation results, a critical conversion where the macromolecules produced inherited the maximum allowed alternation was obtained for the reactivity ratios given.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:caption><jats:p>Change of sequence distribution of simulated copolymer chains with conversion for various initial feed compositions on a triangular graph (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.5, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>B</jats:sub> = 0.9).</jats:p></jats:caption><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text><jats:caption><jats:p>Change of sequence distribution of simulated copolymer chains with conversion for various initial feed compositions on a triangular graph (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>A</jats:sub> = 0.5, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>B</jats:sub> = 0.9).</jats:p></jats:caption></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: Determination of copolymerization parameters in steady state
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the proposed method copolymerization is carried out in an agradient flow reactor where a steady state is established. For the homogenous radical process the following copolymerization equation holds
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
where <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> are the reactivity ratios; <jats:italic>a</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>b</jats:italic><jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>a, b</jats:italic> are the feed (with index) and steady mole ratios of monomers to an internal standard. Experimentally the relative substance quantities in the reaction system can be measured with the help of gas‐chromatography. It is possible to calculate statistically the most probable values for <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> as parameters of the linear form of the above equation. As an example the reaction of styrene and methyl methacrylate in toluene initiated by benzoyl peroxides at 100°C was used. The results are <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> =0,582±0,044 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> =0,530±0,004; they agree well with literature values.</jats:p>

Title: Graft efficiency
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Polystyrenes carrying <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl peracrylic side groups have been synthesized by copolymerization of styrene with acrylyl chloride, partial esterification of the acid chloride units with <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl hydroperoxide, and, finally, methylation of the remaining free carboxylic groups. The weight percent of perester units varied from 0.9 to 3.4, that of methyl acrylate between 14 and 18%. These copolymers were used at 75 °C. in benzene solution for initiating the polymerization of methyl methacrylate; this second step polymerization obeys the square‐root law with respect to the initiator concentration, and is proportional to the monomer concentration. The graft efficiency, <jats:italic>i.e.</jats:italic> the ratio of the amount methyl methacrylate bonded as grafts to that of homopolymer, has been determined by carrying out fractionation of the several reaction products, using the precipitation method with chloroform as solvent and methanol as precipitant. The graft efficiency decreases from 1.52 to 0.77 when the monomer concentration increases from 1.91 to 7.54 mole· 1<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>; it is however unsensitive to the macroinitiator concentration, unsensitive to the bulk viscosity of the reaction medium as well as to the presence of non‐solvent (methanol) in this medium.</jats:p><jats:p>The perester‐content of the macroinitiator exerces a slight influence, the efficiency being higher when this content increases.</jats:p><jats:p>The temperature affects strongly the efficiency ratio; this ratio increases from 0.53 to 1.11 when the temperature rises from 55 ° to 75 °C.; this effect stresses the strong influence of the nature of the radical with respect to their ability of monomer addition.</jats:p>

Title: Nitrogen‐containing monomers. II. Reactivity ratios of n‐vinyloxazolidone and N‐vinylpyrrolidone with vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyloxazolidone with styrene, methyl methacrylate, decyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, and vinyl chloride have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values calculated. Reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylpyrrolidone with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and vinyl acetate have also been determined and the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values determined. <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Vinyloxazolidone was found to be similar but less reactive than <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylpyrrolidone as a comonomer; however, the properties of the resultant copolymers differed appreciably.</jats:p>

Title: Nitrogen‐containing monomers. II. Reactivity ratios of n‐vinyloxazolidone and N‐vinylpyrrolidone with vinyl monomers
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyloxazolidone with styrene, methyl methacrylate, decyl methacrylate, vinyl acetate, and vinyl chloride have been determined and the Alfrey‐Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values calculated. Reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylpyrrolidone with styrene, methyl methacrylate, and vinyl acetate have also been determined and the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values determined. <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐Vinyloxazolidone was found to be similar but less reactive than <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylpyrrolidone as a comonomer; however, the properties of the resultant copolymers differed appreciably.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity of N‐alkylated cyclic iminoether salts having vinyl groups, 4. Radical polymerization and copolymerization of 3‐methyl‐2‐vinyl‐5,6‐dihydro‐4H‐1,3‐oxazinium trifluoromethanesulfonate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Radical homopolymerization and copolymerizations of a new ionic monomer, 3‐methyl‐2‐vinyl‐5,6‐dihydro‐4<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>‐1,3‐oxazinium trifluoromethanesulfonate (<jats:bold>2c</jats:bold>), were studied. The homopolymerization was initiated with 2,2′‐azoisobutyronitrile or benzoyl peroxide in acetonitrile to produce a polymer, poly[1‐(3‐methyl‐5,6‐dihydro‐4<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>‐1,3‐oxazinium‐2‐yl)ethylene] (<jats:bold>3c</jats:bold>), with a relatively low solution viscosity ([η] ≈ 0,2). The monomer was found to be copolymerizable with both electron‐rich (styrene and butyl vinyl ether) and electron‐deficient monomers [methyl methacrylate (MMA)]. For the copolymerization of the monomer and MMA the reactivity ratios <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0,31 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0,37 (MMA) were determined. From these values the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values were calculated to be 3,7 and 1,9, respectively. The <jats:italic>e</jats:italic>‐value is one of the highest among vinyl monomers reported thus far, which is consistent with the anionic polymerizability of monomer <jats:bold>2c</jats:bold>.</jats:p>

Title: Reactive polymers III: Copolymerization of N‐1‐alkenyl‐N′, N′‐ethyleneureas and of N‐1‐alkenylglycidylurethans
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monomer reactivity ratios were determined by the copolymerization of N‐vinyl monomers (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) having an aziridine or epoxy ring as a reactive group, which were synthesized by the reaction of 1‐alkenyl isocyanate with ethylenimine or glycidol. Such monomers were N‐vinyl‐N′,N′‐ethyleneurea (I), N‐isopropenyl‐N′, N′‐ethyleneurea (II), N‐vinylglycidylurethan (III), and N‐isopropenylglycidylurethan (IV). They were copolymerized with vinyl monomers (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>): styrene, methyl methacrylate, acrylonitrile, and vinyl acetate. Isomerization of III and IV to N‐alkenyl‐5‐hydroxypentoxazoridone was studied. Reactivity of epoxy groups in the copolymer was similar to that in the monomeric compounds.</jats:p>
