Title: Radically initiated polymerization of a methacryloylamido‐terminated saccharide, 2. Copolymerization with 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Kinetics of radically initiated copolymerization of 6‐deoxy‐6‐methacryloylamido‐<jats:sc>D</jats:sc>‐glucopyranose (MAG) with 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) was investigated at 60°C in water using 4,4′‐azobis(4‐cyanopentanoic acid) as initiator. Reactivity ratios of the binary system were determined to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>HEMA</jats:sub> = 3.50 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MAG</jats:sub> = 0.60, indicating a strong copolymerization drift as polymerization proceeds. Copolymers with homogeneous composition were prepared using a simple and easy method based on the knowledge of the consumption rate of each monomer. These copolymers were then characterized with regard to composition (by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR) and physicochemical properties in aqueous media (using SEC with MALLS and refractometry detection and viscosimetric measurements).</jats:p>

Title: Theoretical Study of Ethylene−Vinyl Acetate Free-Radical Copolymerization:  Reactivity Ratios, Penultimate Effects, and Relative Rates of Chain Transfer to Polymer
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Styrene‐methyl methacrylate copolymer microstructure according to terminal and penultimate model for free‐radical copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Microstructure of styrene‐methyl methacrylate copolymers was determined according to the “bootstrap model” description using the terminal and the penultimate model of copolymerization. The implication of non‐uniqueness in determining the penultimate model reactivity ratios from the copolymer microstructure is discussed. The styrene centred triad sequences in the copolymer obtained in the free‐radical copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate in bulk at 40°C were calculated using various sets of terminal and penultimate model reactivity ratios with very similar standard deviations. Calculations showed that for both models, the terminal model and the penultimate model, different reactivity ratios with very similar standard deviations are equally well suited for the quantitative description of the triad sequence distribution in the copolymer. The terminal and penultimate models produce different styrene centred triad sequence distributions in the copolymer, the difference depending on the penultimate model reactivity ratios used for calculation and on the type of the styrene centred triad sequence. The best equivalence of the two kinetic models was found when the initial <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>‐parameters guess used for determining the penultimate reactivity ratios by the simplex method were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>11</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>22</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>. The results suggest that the penultimate effect on the styrene‐methyl methacrylate free‐radical copolymerization system is limited.</jats:p>

Title: A method for determining reactivity ratios in copolymerizations in the presence of a ceiling temperature effect
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of styrene and methyl methacrylate initiated with lithium metal
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the presence of a lithium dispersion, styrene and methyl methacrylate copolymerize by a radical‐anionic propagation in agreement with TOBOLSKY's <jats:italic>et al.</jats:italic> datas, Homopolymerization rate measurements suggest a much more active participation of the styrene in the initiation step by an easy electron transfer from lithium to this monomer.</jats:p><jats:p>Using various molar fractions of styrene in the monomer mixture, namely 0.48, 0.736, and 0.84, copolymers were obtained containing 4, 11, and 22% styrene, respectively, and these compositions were confirmed by precipitation fractionation of four samples.</jats:p><jats:p>In the presence of benzoquinone it was possible to reduce the relative importance of the anionic growth, and thus to increase appreciably the styrene content of the copolymers. For a given monomer solution containing 0.723 mole of styrene and 0.778 mole methyl methacrylate, the styrene content of the copolymers was equal to 20, 24, and 30 weight precent in the presence of 1, 1.5, and 2.5% benzoquinone with respect to the monomers, respectively; in the absence of benzoquinone, the styrene content was only 4%.</jats:p><jats:p>These results demonstrate unequivocally the duality of the propagation mechanism during these lithium metal initiated copolymerization.</jats:p>

Title: Anionic copolymerization of α‐methylstyrene and styrene: Kinetics and mechanism
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A kinetic study of copolymerization of styrene and α‐methylstyrene accompanied with depropagation, initiated by n‐butyilithium in cyclohexane with tetrahydrofuran as an additive polar solvent, has been performed. The various propagation rate constants of active species and the complexation equilibrium constants between different kinds of active species were determined. Furthermore, the reactivity ratios of two monomers with regard to monomeric, monoetherated and dietherated active species were obtained.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of propylene and styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerizations of propylene and styrene were carried out with various Ziegler‐Natta type catalysts in order to find the catalytic activity, the monomer reactivity ratios, and some properties of the copolymer. The polymerization products were confirmed to be copolymers from the facts that special behaviors were observed in the infrared and NMR spectra and that the melting point dropped with increasing styrene content. Generally, copolymer produced with a AlR<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>–TiCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> catalyst had low stereoregularity and comparatively low molecular weight. On the contrary, a copolymer produced with a AlR<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>–TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> catalyst had high stereoregularity and high molecular weight (viscosity). In order to reduce the viscosity various additives were examined. Monomer reactivity ratios obtained by the catalysts areas follows: for Al(<jats:italic>i</jats:italic>‐Bu)<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>–TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 20.0 ± 3.5, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.20 ± 0.13; for AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>–TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 20.5 ± 3.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.30 ± 0.15; for AiEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>–VCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>: <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 7.2 ± 0.7, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.16 ± 0.08. All cases show that the reactivity of propylene is much larger than that of styrene.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of vinyl acetate with benzylidenemalononitrile
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Vinyl acetate was copolymerized with benzylidenemalononitrile in bulk by radical initiation at 80°C up to low conversions. Alternating copolymers were formed over a wide range of monomer feed ratios. The copolymerization parameters were determined by the conventional scheme. The copolymers were characterized by IR, proton, and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C spectroscopy and their basic properties, solubility, viscosity, and thermal behavior were determined.</jats:p>

Title: The monomer reactivity ratios in the copolymerization of vinyl compounds with trialkylboron catalysts
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization. VII. Relative rates of addition of various monomers in copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Information concerning monomer reactivity in copolymerization has been obtained for thirteen copolymerization systems. The influence of substituents and chain length in vinyl polymerization is discussed in the light of this and preceding data. Unsaturated acid behavior in copolymerizations is discussed for the first time.</jats:p>

Title: Allyl reactivity in group transfer copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Statistical copolymers of allyl methacrylates with methyl and ethyl methacrylates are synthesized. Moderate conversions are used. Reactivity ratios are calculated by linearised methods which take composition drift into account as well as by non‐linear least‐squares approximation. For the allyl methacrylate/methyl methacrylate system, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>allyl</jats:sub> values obtained by various methods are between 1,62 and 1,60 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>methyl</jats:sub> values between 0,36 and 0,34. For the allyl methacrylate/ethyl methacrylate system, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>allyl</jats:sub> values are between 1,37 and 1,16 and r<jats:sub>ethyl</jats:sub> values between 0,40 and 0,47.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios for the copolymerisation of vinyl acetate with methyl acrylate by proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for the copolymerisation of vinyl acetate with methyl acrylate have been determined in bulk at 60°C for conversions smaller than 1% using proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The values (r<jats:sub>ma</jats:sub> = 6.3 ± 0.4; r<jats:sub>va</jats:sub> = 0.031 ± 0.006) thus obtained were compared with the values obtained by other workers using different analytical techniques. The present method appears to be extremely simple and accurate.</jats:p>

Title: Determination of reactivity ratios for the copolymerisation of vinyl acetate with methyl acrylate by proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Reactivity ratios for the copolymerisation of vinyl acetate with methyl acrylate have been determined in bulk at 60°C for conversions smaller than 1% using proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The values (r<jats:sub>ma</jats:sub> = 6.3 ± 0.4; r<jats:sub>va</jats:sub> = 0.031 ± 0.006) thus obtained were compared with the values obtained by other workers using different analytical techniques. The present method appears to be extremely simple and accurate.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of butyl acrylate and vinylpyridine
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate with both 2 and 4 vinylpyridine was investigated. Spectrophotometric analysis was employed for determining copolymer compositions utilizing the vinylpyridine absorption at 263 mμ. Reactivity ratios for butyl acrylate/2‐vinylpyridine were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.50 ± 0.50 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.10 ± 0.04. For butyl acrylate/4‐vinylpyridine <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 5.51 ± 0.09 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.46 ± 0.09. These values were compared with calculated estimates made from the <jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic> scheme.</jats:p>

Title: Homopolymerization and copolymerization of tert‐butyl methacrylate and norbornene with nickel‐based methylaluminoxane catalysts
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The homopolymerization and copolymerization of <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (tBMA) and norbornene (NB) with nickel(II) acetylacetonate in combination with methylaluminoxane were systematically investigated. This catalytic system showed high activity toward the homopolymerization of both NB and tBMA. For these copolymerizations, activity was gradually lost with an addition of tBMA to NB or of NB to tBMA. This result was qualitatively explained with the trigger coordination mechanism. Furthermore, the determination of the reactivity ratios indicated a significantly higher reactivity for NB than for tBMA (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>NB</jats:sub> = 4.14 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>tBMA</jats:sub> = 0.097), and this was interpreted by the coordination mechanism. The synthesized acrylate/NB copolymers exhibited glass‐transition temperatures of 100–250°C. The absence of crystallinity and the homogeneous repartition of the monomer units along the main chain yielded products with high transparency and high stability © 2004 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 92: 1824–1833, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Influence of ethyl benzoate on copolymerization of styrene and 1‐hexene with the titanium‐based systems (α)‐TiCl<sub>3</sub>(H) and TiCl<sub>3</sub> · 1/3 AlCl<sub>3</sub>
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The influence of ethyl benzoate (E.B.) on the copolymerization of styrene with 1‐hexene, initiated by isospecific Ziegler‐Natta catalysts α‐TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>(H)‐AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> and TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> · 1/3 AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>‐AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> (mole ratio Al/Ti = 3), was examined. Ethyl benzoate was found to reduce the activity of the catalysts. In addition it leads, depending on the Ti catalyst, to opposite effects on the apparent reactivity order of the two monomers. Incorporation of styrene into the copolymers is reduced when E. B. is added to TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> · 1/3 AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>‐AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>. On the contrary, a much higher incorporation of styrene is observed with α‐TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>(H)‐AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> in the presence of E. B. For this system the calculated reactivity ratio varies strongly with increasing proportion of E. B.: for a mole ratio AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>/E. B. = 3, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 0,94 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 1,46 and for AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>/E. B. = 2, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>S</jats:sub> = 8 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>H</jats:sub> = 0,1. Changes in the stereoregularity of copolymers suggest that E. B. leads to an inhibition of the less stereospecific sites for TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> · 1/3 AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>‐AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, whereas its addition suppresses the stereospecificity of the α‐TiCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>(H)‐AlEt<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> catalyst. Contributions of conventional cationic and/or radical processes to the copolymerization reaction were examined and may be ruled out.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Fluorinated Monomers with Hydrophilic Monomers in Aqueous Solution in Presence of Cyclodextrin
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:bold>Summary:</jats:bold> New fluorinated copolymers were synthesized by copolymerization of 1<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>,1<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>,2<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>,2<jats:italic>H‐</jats:italic>perfluorodecyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) with hydrophilic comonomers methacrylic acid (<jats:bold>3</jats:bold>), 2‐acrylamido‐2‐methylpropane sulfonic acid (<jats:bold>6</jats:bold>), 3‐trimethylammonium propyl methacrylamide chloride (<jats:bold>7</jats:bold>) and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐dimethylmethacrylamidopropyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐3‐sulfopropylammoniumbetaine (<jats:bold>8</jats:bold>). The reaction was carried out in water using randomly methylated <jats:italic>β</jats:italic>‐cyclodextrin (RAMEB) for solubilization of the fluorinated monomer by forming a host‐guest complex (<jats:bold>1a</jats:bold>). Polymerization kinetics were investigated and copolymerization parameters were determined. Additionally, a RAMEB complex of <jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl methacrylate (<jats:bold>2a</jats:bold>) was copolymerized with <jats:bold>1a</jats:bold> in water. For comparison, copolymerization of the uncomplexed monomers <jats:bold>1</jats:bold> and <jats:bold>2</jats:bold> were carried out in organic solvents. Evaluation of copolymerization kinetics and parameters showed significant differences in the relative reactivities of the free monomers and the monomer‐RAMEB complexes.
<jats:boxed-text content-type="graphic" position="anchor"><jats:graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mimetype="image/gif" position="anchor" specific-use="enlarged-web-image" xlink:href="graphic/mgra001.gif"><jats:alt-text>magnified image</jats:alt-text></jats:graphic></jats:boxed-text>
</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of acrylonitrile with benzyl- and tetrahydrofuryl acrylates
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Preparation of macromonomers by copolymerization of methyl acrylate dimer involving β fragmentation
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The unsaturated dimer of methyl acrylate [CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>C(CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>)CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, or MAD] was copolymerized with various monomers to prepare copolymers bearing the ω‐unsaturated end group [CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>C(CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>CH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>)CH<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] arising from β fragmentation of the MAD propagating radical. Copolymerizations of MAD with cyclohexyl and <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>‐butyl acrylate resulted in copolymers with ω‐unsaturated end groups, and increasing the temperature up to 180 °C resulted in an increase in the rate of β fragmentation of MAD radicals relative to propagation. Only a small amount of unsaturated end groups was introduced by copolymerization with ethyl methacrylate (EMA), and the EMA content in the copolymer increased with temperature. These findings could be explained by the reversible addition of the poly(EMA) radical to MAD. The copolymerization with ethyl α‐ethyl acrylate (EEA) did yield a copolymer containing unsaturated end groups with MAD units as part of the main chain, although the steric hindrance of the ethyl group suppressed homopropagation and crosspropagation of EEA, resulting in low polymerization rates. Therefore, the copolymerization of MAD with acrylic esters at high temperatures was noted as a convenient route for obtaining acrylate–MAD copolymers bearing unsaturated end groups at the ω end (macromonomer). © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 42: 597–607, 2004</jats:p>

Title: Studies in cyclocopolymerization. Relative rates of addition in the free radical‐initiated copolymerization of 1,4‐dienes and substituted olefins
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A general copolymer composition equation is developed for the cyclocopolymerization of 1,4‐dienes (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and monoolefins (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>). The general equation relates copolymer composition to monomer feed composition in terms of five reactivity ratio parameters. When cyclization is very rapid relative to other chain propagation steps the general equation simplifies to the form: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = (1 + <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)(1 + <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)/[<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic> + (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>) + 2], where <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = [m<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[m<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] in the copolymer, <jats:italic>x</jats:italic> = [M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>][M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] in the monomer feed, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> are reactivity ratios for the chain propagation steps of diene, monoolefin, and cyclized radicals, respectively. The theory is applied to the free radical initiated copolymerization of (A) divinyl ether/maleic anhydride, (B) 1,4‐pentadiene/maleic anhydride, (C) divinyl ether/<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenylmaleimide, (D), divinyl ether/acrylonitrile; and (E) 1,4‐pentadiene/acrylonitrile. Systems A, B, and C form alternating copolymers of composition <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 0.5. For system D, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.024, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.938, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub> = 0.017. For system E, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ⋍ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub> ⋍ O, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.13.</jats:p>

Title: Studies in cyclocopolymerization. Relative rates of addition in the free radical‐initiated copolymerization of 1,4‐dienes and substituted olefins
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A general copolymer composition equation is developed for the cyclocopolymerization of 1,4‐dienes (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and monoolefins (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>). The general equation relates copolymer composition to monomer feed composition in terms of five reactivity ratio parameters. When cyclization is very rapid relative to other chain propagation steps the general equation simplifies to the form: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = (1 + <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)(1 + <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic>)/[<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub><jats:italic>x</jats:italic> + (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>x</jats:italic>) + 2], where <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = [m<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>]/[m<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] in the copolymer, <jats:italic>x</jats:italic> = [M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>][M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>] in the monomer feed, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>c</jats:italic></jats:sub> are reactivity ratios for the chain propagation steps of diene, monoolefin, and cyclized radicals, respectively. The theory is applied to the free radical initiated copolymerization of (A) divinyl ether/maleic anhydride, (B) 1,4‐pentadiene/maleic anhydride, (C) divinyl ether/<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐phenylmaleimide, (D), divinyl ether/acrylonitrile; and (E) 1,4‐pentadiene/acrylonitrile. Systems A, B, and C form alternating copolymers of composition <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 0.5. For system D, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.024, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.938, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub> = 0.017. For system E, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> ⋍ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>c</jats:sub> ⋍ O, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.13.</jats:p>

Title: Gamma-ray induced copolymerization of acrylonitrile and ethylene
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Reactivity ratios of free monomers and their charge‐transfer complex in the copolymerization of N‐butyl maleimide and styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>As for the charge‐transfer complex (CTC) formed by <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐butyl maleimide (NMBI) and styrene in chloroform, the complex formation constant was determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR of Hanna–Ashbaugh. The copolymerization of NBMI (NBMI, <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and styrene (St, <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) in chloroform using AIBN as an initiator was investigated. On the basis of the kinetic model proposed by Shan, the reactivity ratios of free monomers and CTC in the copolymerization were calculated to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 0.0440, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 0.0349, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1C</jats:sub> = 0.00688, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2C</jats:sub> = 0.00476, and the ratios of rate constants were obtained to be <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>1C</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>12</jats:sub> = 6.40, <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>2C</jats:sub>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>21</jats:sub> = 7.33. In addition, the copolymer was characterized by IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, DSC, and TGA. © 2002 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 83: 3007–3012, 2002; DOI 10.1002/app.2330</jats:p>

Title: Synthesis and property behavior of dioctyl phthalate plasticized styrene–acrylate particles by Shirasu porous glass emulsification and subsequent suspension copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Two‐phase model styrene–acrylate copolymers were synthesized with a soft phase consisting of methyl acrylate, butyl acrylate, and butyl methacrylate. Besides the styrenic copolymers, copolymers containing a hard phase of methyl methacylate and methyl acrylate were also synthesized. Comonomer droplets with a narrow size distribution and fair uniformity were prepared using an SPG (Shirasu porous glass) membrane having pore size of 0.90 μm. After the single‐step SPG emulsion, the emulsion droplets were composed mainly of monomers, hydrophobic additives, and an oil‐soluble initiator, suspended in the aqueous phase containing a stabilizer and inhibitor. These were then transferred to a reactor, and subsequent suspension polymerization was carried out. Uniform copolymer particles with a mean diameter ranging from 3 to 7 μm, depending on the recipe, with a narrow particle size distribution and a coefficient of variation of about 10% were achieved. Based on the glass‐transition temperatures, as measured by differential scanning calorimetry, the resulting copolymer particles containing a soft phase of acrylate were better compatibilized with a hard phase of methyl methacrylate than with styrene with dioctyl phthalate (DOP) addition. Glass‐transition temperatures of poly(MMA‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐MA) particles were strongly affected by the composition drift in the copolymer caused by their substantial difference in reactivity ratios. Incorporation of DOP in the copolymer particles does not significantly affect the glass‐transition temperature of MMA‐ or MA‐containing copolymer particles, but it does affect the St‐containing copolymer and particle morphology of the copolymers. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 90: 3037–3050, 2003</jats:p>

Title: ZnCl2 complexes of para‐substituted phenyl methacrylates in radical copolymerization with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of phenyl methacrylate, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐tolyl methacrylate, and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chlorophenyl methacrylate with styrene was carried out in the absence and in the presence of ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>. It was found by <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR, and IR spectroscopy that complexes of zinc chloride with the corresponding methacrylates are formed. Reactivity ratios as well as <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values for the monomers and complexes were calculated. A correlation between <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C chemical shift of the vinyl group of monomers and complexes with ZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was found.</jats:p>

Title: The Radical Polymerization and Copolymerization of Triallylidene Sorbitol with Styrene or Acrylonitrile
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The polymerization of triallylidene sorbitol (TAS) and the copolymerization of TAS with styrene (St) or acrylonitrile (AN) have been carried out, using benzoyl peroxide as an initiator at 80°C. They were kinetically investigated in relation to the degradative or effective chain transfer by the allylidene group, and by the cyclization by three double bonds. The results can be summarized as follows: 1) the relation among the rate of polymerization, Rp, the initiator concentration, (I), and the monomer concentration, (M), can be expressed by the following equation: ((I)/Rp–a)−1=A(M)+B, where a, A, and B are constant; 2) the ratio of the rate of unimolecular cyclization to the total rate of bimolecular propagation and the chain transfer of uncyclized radical was estimated to be 0.291; 3) the degree of polymerization depends on the monomer concentration, but not on the initiator concentration; 4) the rates of copolymerization decrease markedly with an increase in the TAS or tricrotylidene sorbitol (TCS) mole fraction in monomer mixtures; and 5) the following monomer reactivity ratios were ascertained: St(M1)-TAS(M2)r1=4.60, r2=0.13, AN(M1)-TAS(M2) r1=0.70, r2=0.26, St(M1)-TCS(M2) r=2.31, r2=0.39, AN(M1)-TCS(M2) r1=0.30, r2=0.36. The Q and e values for the functional group were calculated from the above values as 0.05 and −0.08 (TAS), and 0.10 and −0.25 (TCS) respectively.</jats:p>

Title: Variation in the reactivity ratios of ethylene and propylene in copolymerization on supported Ziegler catalysts
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of cyclopentadiene with styrene by methylaluminoxane catalyst
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Random copolymerization of cyclopentadiene (CPD) and styrene initiated by methylaluminoxane was investigated. The copolymer was analyzed using FT‐IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The reactivity ratios of the monomers were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>CPD</jats:sub> = 19.53, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>styrene</jats:sub> = 0.60. A single glass transition temperature is observed for each copolymer, which is in agreement with a random type copolymer structure. And a cationic initiation mechanism was speculated based on the polymerization results. Copyright © 2006 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.</jats:p>

Title: Kinetik der radikalischen polymerisation und copolymerisation von N‐vinyl‐N‐methylacetamid
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In order to get information on the kinetics of free radical polymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylacetamide (VIMA) polymerizations of the purified monomer were performed in dilatometers using the temperature range from 25 to 70°C, monomer concentrations of 10 to 100% in methanol, and initiation either by γY‐irradiation or by radical initiators. Molecular weight meassurements of the polymer were calibrated by light scattering determinations of <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub> according to the following equation at 30 °C in methanol: [η]/(ml/g) = 5,02 · 10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> · <jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub><jats:sup>0,794</jats:sup>6. Normal kinetics of free radical polymerization were found to be valid and Arrhenius parameters were calculated for the ratio <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>/<jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> of the propagation rate constant <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and the termination rate constant <jats:italic>k</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub> as well as for the monomer transfer constant <jats:italic>C</jats:italic><jats:sub>M</jats:sub> and for the efficiency of initiation <jats:italic>f</jats:italic>. For copolymerizations of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinyl‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐methylacetamide with different comonomers the mean <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic>‐values were calculated as follows: <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>VIMA</jats:sub> ≅ 0,06; e<jats:sub>VIMA</jats:sub> ≅ − 1,8.</jats:p>

Title: On the copolymerization of acrylonitrile with styrene in the presence of Lewis acid, 3. Photoinitiated copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The rate of the acrylonitrile (AN)‐styrene (St) copolymerization (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub>) photoinitiated (λ=365 nm) by the StANZnCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> complex at 30°C is proportional to the square root of the intensity of radiation. The limiting viscosity number [η] of alternating copolymers increases with the intensity of radiation. The 1/[η] vs. <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> relationship for the StAN copolymers is similar as has been found for the initiation of copolymerization by thermal decomposition of 2,2‐azoisobutyronitrile. Provided benzophenone combined with 2‐propanol is used as a photosensitizer, the rate of the StAN copolymerization in acetone—at constant concentrations of both comonomers, zinc chloride, and benzophenone—decreases with 2‐propanol concentration in the reaction mixture. If benzophenone alone (e.g. without 2‐propanol) is used as a photosensitizer under equal conditions, the observed values of the rate of copolymerization are lower in comparison with the system where the ternary molecular complex is empolyed as a photosensitizer. Moreover, <jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sub>p</jats:sub> decreases with increasing concentration of benzophenone in the system. These findings are interpreted as a result of the termination reactions of ketyl radicals (hydroxydiphenylmethyl radicals) with macroradicals of copolymer.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of fluoroketones with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We have studied the free‐radical copolymerization of vinyl acetate (VAc) with hexa‐fluoacetone (6FK) and symdichlorotetrafluoroacetone (4FK) through the carbonyl group. The carbon of the carbonyl group is attacked by the growing radical. A strong penultimate effect was found for both copolymerizations (fluoroketone does not homopolymerize). Reactivity ratios were as follows: VAc/6FK − <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.12 ± 0.01, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>′, = 4.1† 0.5; VAc/4FK ‐ <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>, = 0.41 ± 0.02, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>′, = 5.6 ± 0.3. The mechanism of chain termination is also discussed. We conclude that the main transfer step is dismutation of the fluoroketyl radical to a trihalomethyl radical and a trihalomethyl ketone polymer end.</jats:p>

Title: Dispersion copolymerization of acrylamide and dimethyl diallyl ammonium chloride in ethanol‐water solution
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Poly (acrylamide‐dimethyldiallylammonium chloride) (PAM‐DMDAAC) particles have been prepared via dispersion polymerizations using poly (vinyl pyrrolidone) (PVP) as a steric stabilizer in ethanol‐water media. The monomer reactivity ratios of acrylamide (AM, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and dimethyldiallylammonium chloride (DMDAAC, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) were determined as 6.664 and 0.120, respectively, which means that PAM‐DMDAAC is a nonideal copolymer. The effects of various polymerization parameters (e.g., concentration of monomer and initiator, medium polarity, the ratio of AM to DMDAAC, initial temperature and ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid disodium (EDTA)) on the intrinsic viscosity and conversion of copolymer have been investigated. The copolymer was characterized by FTIR and NMR. The optimum operating conditions for preparing PAM‐DMDAAC were determined as ethanol content 50%, C<jats:sub>monomer</jats:sub> (wt %) 40%, <jats:italic>n</jats:italic><jats:sub>AM</jats:sub>: <jats:italic>n</jats:italic><jats:sub>DMDAAC</jats:sub> 8 : 2, <jats:italic>C</jats:italic><jats:sub>initiator</jats:sub> (wt %) 0.04% and initiate temperature 40°C. © 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci, 2011</jats:p>

Title: Polymerization of coordinated monomers. IV. Copolymerization of methyl methacrylate– and methacrylonitrile–Lewis acid complexes with styrene
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Complexes of methyl methacrylate and methacrylonitrile with Lewis acids (SnCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>, AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, and BF<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>) were copolymerized with styrene at −75°C under irradiation with a high‐pressure mercury lamp in toluene solution. The resulting copolymers consisted of equimolar amount of methyl methacrylate or methacrylonitrile and styrene, regardless of the molar ratio of monomers in the feed. NMR spectroscopy showed the copolymers to have an alternate sequence. The tacticities of the copolymers varied with the complex to have an alternate sequence. The tacticities of the copolymers varied with the complex species: the copolymer from the SnCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> complex system had a higher cosyndiotactieity, while those from the AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> and the BF<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> complex systems showed coisotacticity to predominate over cosyndiotacticity. NMR spectroscopic investigation of the copolymerization system indicated the presence of a charge‐transfer complex between the styrene and the methyl methacrylate coordinated to SnCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>. The concentration of the charge‐transfer complex was estimated to be about 30% of monomer pairs at −78°C at a 1:1 molar ratio of feed. The growing end radicals were identified as a methyl methacrylate radical for the AlCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> complex–styrene system and a styrene radical for the SnCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> complex–styrene system by the measurement of the ESR spectra of the copolymerization systems under or after irradation with a high‐pressure mercury lamp. The tacticity of the resulting polymer appears to be controlled by the structure of the charge transfer complex. In the case of the SnCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> complex a certain interaction of SnCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> with the growing end radical seems to be a factor controlling the polymer structure. These copolymerizations can be explained by an alternating charge‐transfer complex copolymerization scheme.</jats:p>

Title: Investigation of styrene/1‐hexene copolymerization by homogeneous and heterogeneous bisindenyl ethane zirconium dichloride catalyst system
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Homogeneous copolymerization of styrene and 1‐hexene was carried out in toluene at room temperature using bisindenyl ethane zirconium dichloride/methylaluminoxane (MAO). The supported catalyst was prepared with immobilization of Et(Ind)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>ZrCl<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>/MAO on silica (calcinated at 500°C) with premixed method. Heterogeneous copolymerization of styrene/1‐hexene with different mole ratios was carried out in the presence of supported catalyst system. The copolymers obtained from homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst system were characterized by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR and <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR. Composition of the resulting copolymers was determined by <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H NMR data. Analysis of <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR spectra of obtained copolymers by homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst systems present isotactic olefin‐enriched copolymers. Molecular weight and thermal behavior of resulting copolymers was investigated. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 104: 4008–4014, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of vinyl acetate with a homologous series of vinyl esters: A comparative study of vinyl acetate–vinyl ester and ethylene–vinyl ester copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The effect of the alkyl group on the relative reactivity of a homologous series of vinyl esters (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) has been studied with vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) as reference monomer and<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl alcohol as solvent at 62°C and 35 kg/cm<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>. The description of the relative reactivities of the vinyl esters toward the vinyl acetate (VAc) macroradical in terms of the Taft relation is analogous to our previous findings in a similar study with ethylene (Eth) as reference radical. This implies that chiefly polar factors affect the relative reactivity, whereas from vinyl pivalate (VPV) on steric hindrance impairs the addition rate. The constancy of the<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>values, also found in the series with Eth (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) as reference monomer (viz.,<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>= 1.50), appears to exist in the present investigation (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>= 1.04) but does not hold for the VAc–VPV combination. This can be interpreted in terms of steric hindrance. A combination of kinetic results indicates sterically hindered additions in all those reactions in the system Eth–VAc–VPV that involve at least one VPV unit as macroradical or monomer (except for the addition of Eth to a VPV macroradical). The monomer reactivity ratios that pertain to the Eth–VAc–vinyl ester systems are discussed in terms of the<jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic>scheme and the product relation postulated by Ham. The Ham relation does not hold for the latter systems.</jats:p>

Title: Reactive microgels by the self‐emulsifying copolymerization of unsaturated polyester resins with acrylic and methacrylic esters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The self‐emulsifying copolymerization of unsaturated polyesters (UP) with various acrylic and methacrylic esters was studied. The structure of comonomers significantly influences the character of microgels obtained. Among these monomers the copolymerization of UP with methyl methacrylate (MMA) was investigated in detail in order to make clear the behavior of this polymerization as compared with that of styrene. The water/monomer and UP/MMA ratios were found to be the most important factors controlling the molecular weight and solution viscosity of the microgels. The relationship between <jats:italic>M̄</jats:italic><jats:sub>w</jats:sub> and intrinsic viscosity of microgels suggests that the microgels from MMA have less compact structure than those from styrene.</jats:p>

Title: Photo and thermal polymerization sensitized by donor–acceptor interaction. I. N‐vinyl‐carbazole–acrylonitrile and related systems
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Spontaneous photo and thermal polymerization of <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylcarbazole (VCZ)–acrylonitrile (AN), VCZ–acetonitrile, AN‐N‐ethylcarbazole, and AN‐ferrocene were studied. These combinations of electron donor with acceptor were thermally rather stable but showed prominent photopolymerizability when the systems were irradiated by near ultraviolet light. The VCZ–AN system showed multireactivity producing VCZ polymer and a copolymer of VCZ with AN. The composition of copolymer was approximately the same as that of polymer produced in radical copolymerization. The effects of additives (DPPH, NH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O, air) indicated simultaneous occurrence of cationic and radical polymerization in the AN–VCZ and acetonitrile–VCZ systems. The results were interpreted on the assumption of initial formation of a cation radical–anion radical pair. The ratio of cationic to radical polymerization differed for photo and thermal polymerization. In no case was anionic polymerization detected.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios ofN-cyclohexylmaleimide and methylmethacrylate by infrared spectroscopy
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Copolymerization of sodium 2‐acrylamido‐2‐methyl‐propanesulfonate with vinyl acetate
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Sulphur‐containing polyacrylates. III: UV‐induced copolymerization of methyl methacrylate with some dimethacrylates containing ether or thioether linkage
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The UV‐induced copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MM) with 2,2′‐thiobisethanol dimethacrylate (TEDM) and MM with 2,2′‐oxybisethanol dimethacrylate (OEDM) was investigated for a wide range of the diester content (6‐80 mol%) in the initial mixture. The influence of the feed composition on the course of copolymerization was determined. It was found that there exists a minimum on the plot of maximum yield of soluble copolymer versus diester content at a diester content of 30 mol%. The total copolymer yields were lower in the case of mixtures containing TEDM comonomer. Determination of the reactivity ratios gave the following values: for MM + TEDM <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0·21, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 4·59 and for MM + OEDM <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>a</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0·55. <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>b</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 4·42. A possible explanation of the results obtained is discussed.</jats:p>

Title: Reactivity ratios in diene and diene–vinyl copolymerization
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Radical copolymerization studies of an amphiphilic macromonomer derived from Triton X-100. Reactivity ratios determination by in situ quantitative 1H NMR monitoring
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Biradical Initiation in Photoinitiated Copolymerization of Styrene and Maleic Anhydride
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐maleic anhydride) (SMAnh) is a copolymer system that is well known for its alternating tendency, which has been thoroughly investigated by many research groups over the decades and is widely used in industry. Investigations have focused almost entirely on thermally initiated systems. However, very few investigations have been conducted on light‐initiated radical copolymerization. In this study, the photoinitiated copolymerization of styrene and maleic anhydride is investigated without the use of an external radical source, such as the classical 2,2‐azobis(2‐methylpropionitrile) (AIBN), benzoyl peroxide (BPO), or any photoinitiators. The initiation of the polymerization is instead found to take place through an excited state biradical generated in situ from a photoexcited charge‐transfer complex (CTC) comprising the donor (styrene) and acceptor (maleic anhydride) monomers. The formation of the complex is found to be solvent dependent. Excitation of the complex results in copolymerization of monomers to afford high‐molecular‐weight (>10<jats:sup>5</jats:sup> g·mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) alternating copolymers.</jats:p>

Title: Allylic polymers. I. Copolymerization of allyl esters with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of allyl esters with vinyl acetate has been studied in the range from 10 to 90 mol % allyl esters in the feed. The Kelen‐Tüdos method was employed to determine the monomer reactivity ratios. The following values were found for the reactivity ratios: allyl propionate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.42, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.29; allyl butyrate <jats:italic>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)</jats:italic>–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.64, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.97; allyl isobutyrate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.51, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.04; allyl valerate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.58, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.07; allyl trimethylacetate <jats:italic>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)</jats:italic>–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.34, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.15. The <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> parameters were calculated from the allyl esters (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) reactivity ratios. The <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> parameters of allyl ester monomers have been found to be nicely correlated with parameters such as dissociation constants of carboxylic acids, which are constituents of allyl ester monomers, and Taft σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> constants of the alkyl group in the acids. The molecular weights of copolymers were measured by GPC and ranged from (1.0–15.0) × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup>.</jats:p>

Title: Allylic polymers. I. Copolymerization of allyl esters with vinyl acetate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization of allyl esters with vinyl acetate has been studied in the range from 10 to 90 mol % allyl esters in the feed. The Kelen‐Tüdos method was employed to determine the monomer reactivity ratios. The following values were found for the reactivity ratios: allyl propionate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.42, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.29; allyl butyrate <jats:italic>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)</jats:italic>–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.64, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.97; allyl isobutyrate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.51, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.04; allyl valerate (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.58, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.07; allyl trimethylacetate <jats:italic>(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)</jats:italic>–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>), <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>1</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 0.34, <jats:italic>r<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:italic> = 1.15. The <jats:italic>Q‐e</jats:italic> parameters were calculated from the allyl esters (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)–vinyl acetate (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) reactivity ratios. The <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> parameters of allyl ester monomers have been found to be nicely correlated with parameters such as dissociation constants of carboxylic acids, which are constituents of allyl ester monomers, and Taft σ<jats:sup>*</jats:sup> constants of the alkyl group in the acids. The molecular weights of copolymers were measured by GPC and ranged from (1.0–15.0) × 10<jats:sup>4</jats:sup>.</jats:p>

Title: Formation of crosslinked polymers in the copolymerization of 9,10‐anthrylenedimethyl dimethacrylate and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The formation of a crosslinked polymer during the copolymerization of mono‐and bifunctional monomers was investigated choosing as an example the free‐radical copolymerization of methyl methacrylate (MMA) and 9,10‐anthrylenedimethyl dimethacrylate (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>). The anthracenecontaining crosslinks permit the determination of the topological structure of soluble MMA‐1 copolymers containing bridge bonds. This copolymer is formed first and characterized by a considerable structural heterogeneity. The intrinsic viscosity of the soluble copolymer increases sharply in a certain reaction stage and, at the same time, an insoluble copolymer fraction appears. In the formation of the gel fraction those branched macromolecules which consist of a greater number of linear components and contain a greater number of “pendent” double bonds participate first.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of some further monomer pairs
Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Synthesis and polymerization of fluorinated monomers bearing a reactive lateral group. XIV. Radical copolymerization of vinylidene fluoride with methyl 1,1‐dihydro‐4,7‐dioxaperfluoro‐5,8‐dimethyl non‐1‐enoate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The radical copolymerization in solution of vinylidene fluoride (VDF; or 1,1‐difluoroethylene) with methyl 1,1‐dihydro‐4,7‐dioxaperfluoro‐5,8‐dimethyl non‐1‐enoate (MDP) initiated by di‐<jats:italic>tert</jats:italic>‐butyl peroxide is presented. Six copolymerization reactions were investigated with initial [VDF]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>/[MDP]<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> molar ratios of 35/65 to 80/20. Both of these comonomers copolymerized in this range of copolymerization. Moreover, these comonomers homopolymerized separately under these conditions. The copolymer compositions of these random copolymers were calculated by means of <jats:sup>19</jats:sup>F NMR spectroscopy, which allowed the quantification of the respective amounts of each monomeric unit in the copolymers. The Tidwell–Mortimer method was used for the assessment of the reactivity ratios (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>i</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of both comonomers, which showed a higher incorporation of MDP in the copolymers (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MDP</jats:sub> = 2.41 ± 2.28 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>VDF</jats:sub> = 0.38 ± 0.21 at 120 °C). The Alfrey–Price <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values of the trifluoroallyl monomer MDP were calculated to be 0.024 (from <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>VDF</jats:sub> = 0.008) or 0.046 (from <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>VDF</jats:sub> = 0.015) and 0.70 (vs <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>VDF</jats:sub> = 0.40) or 0.80 (vs <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>VDF</jats:sub> = 0.50), respectively, indicating that MDP was an electron‐accepting monomer. The thermal properties of these fluorinated copolymers were also determined. Except for those containing a high amount of VDF, the copolymers were amorphous. Each showed one glass‐transition temperature (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>) only, and with known laws of <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub>'s, <jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> of the MDP homopolymer was assessed. It was compared to that obtained from the direct radical homopolymerization of MDP and discussed. Indeed, these two values were close (<jats:italic>T</jats:italic><jats:sub>g</jats:sub> = −3 °C). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed, and they showed that the copolymers were rather thermostable because the thermal degradation occurred at 280 °C. © 2003 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Polym Sci Part A: Polym Chem 41: 3109–3121, 2003</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of dimethyl diallyl ammonium chloride and acryl amide
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The copolymerization of dimethyl dially ammonium chloride (DMDAAC) and acryl amide results in deviations from the MAYO‐Lewis model. Monomer reactivity ratios can be determined precisely within limited ranges of the monomer ratio. The values of <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> depend on the content of DMDAAC in the initial comonomer solution as well as on the total concentration of both comonomers. These experimental results can be explained by assciation of the cationic monomer and by electrostatic interactions.</jats:p>

Title: Emulsion copolymerization of hydrophobic and hydrophilic monomers: an experimental study with styrene and 2- hydroxyethyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Ab initio emulsion copolymerization of styrene with 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) at weight ratios of the hydrophilic monomer of 1 and greater was investigated at various temperatures in dependence on the concentration of sodium dodecylsulfate (SDS) and potassium peroxodisulfate as emulsifier and initiator, respectively. Both the course of the polymerization and the latex properties are strongly influenced by the hydrophilic monomer. For instance, transparent or highly translucent latexes are obtained resembling the appearance of microemulsion latexes with polymer contents as high as 10 weight-% but at much lower surfactant concentration. Moreover, polymerization rate, average particle size, and particle morphology depend on the surfactant and initiator concentration, monomer feed composition, and polymerization temperature.</jats:p>

extracted_data.PDF_name: Emulsion copolymerization of hydrophobic and hydrophilic monomers: an experimental study with styrene and 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate

Title: Copolymerization of tri‐n‐butyltin‐α‐chloroacrylate with 2‐hydroxyalkyl methacrylates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of tri‐n‐butyltin‐α‐chloroacrylate (TCA) with 2‐hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) and 2‐hydroxypropyl methacrylate (HPMA) were synthesized in solution at 55°C using azobisisobutyronitrile as initiator. Copolymer compositions were determined by tin analysis. Monomer reactivity ratios were calculated by the Kelen‐Tüdős method. The copolymers were further characterized by IR, <jats:sup>1</jats:sup>H‐NMR, TGA, DSC, XRD and solubility. Biotoxicity studies of the copolymers are also reported. The copolymer system is compared with similar copolymers of tri‐n‐butyltín methacrylate.</jats:p>

Title: Ethylene–propylene copolymerization initiated with solubilized Ziegler–Natta macromolecular complexes. I. Determination of kinetic parameters
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymerization of ethylene with propylene (E–P) was initiated with soluble polystyrene <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-ueqn-1.gif" xlink:title="equation image" />–butadiene<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-ueqn-2.gif" xlink:title="equation image" />–Li/TiCl<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> complexes in toluene leading to vinylic‐olefinic based block copolymers. The activity of the system was measured at a constant ratio <jats:italic>r</jats:italic> = Li/Ti for different feed compositions. From measurements of the amount of copolymers produced, a direct determination of the efficiency of the catalytic system was made. This efficiency was found to be close to that obtained for homopolymerizations of C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> and C<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub> initiated with the same catalytic complex (≃ 80% with respect to the concentration of “carbon‐titanium” bonds).</jats:p><jats:p>Both the measured values of the efficiency and the determination of the molar masses of the polyolefinic block are consistent with a living character of the system involved in the E–P copolymerization. In such conditions well‐defined linear [styrene]‐b‐[ethylene‐co‐propylene] copolymers were obtained. Furthermore, <jats:sup>13</jats:sup>C NMR analyses allowed determination of the comonomer reactivity ratios, the values of which indicate an E–P random copolymerization.</jats:p><jats:p>From both these values and those of the absolute rate constants of propagation determined for the homopolymerization of C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> and C<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>6</jats:sub> initiated with the same catalytic system, the absolute rate constants of cross‐propagation were deduced.</jats:p>

Title: Ceric(<scp>IV</scp>) ion‐induced graft copolymerization of acrylamide and ethyl acrylate onto cellulose
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Graft copolymerization of acrylamide (AAm) and ethyl acrylate (EA) onto cellulose has been carried out from their binary mixtures using ceric ammonium nitrate (CAN) as an initiator in the presence of nitric acid at 25 ± 1 °C. The extent of acrylamide grafting increased in the presence of the EA comonomer. The composition of the grafted chains (<jats:italic>F</jats:italic><jats:sub>AAm</jats:sub> = 0.52) was found to be constant during the feed molarity variation from 7.5 × 10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> to 60.0 × 10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> mol L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>, whereas the composition of the grafted chains (<jats:italic>F</jats:italic><jats:sub>AAm</jats:sub>) was found to be dependent on feed composition (<jats:italic>f</jats:italic><jats:sub>AAm</jats:sub>) and reaction temperature. The effects of ceric(<jats:sc>IV</jats:sc>) ion concentration, reaction time and temperature on the grafting parameters have been studied. The grafting parameters showed an increasing trend up to 6.0 × 10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> mol L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> concentration of CAN at a feed molarity of 30.0 × 10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> mol L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and showed a decreasing trend on further increasing the concentration of CAN (>6.0 × 10<jats:sup>−3</jats:sup> mol L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) at a constant concentration of nitric acid (5.0 × 10<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> mol L<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>). The composition of the grafted chains (<jats:italic>F</jats:italic><jats:sub>AAm</jats:sub>) was determined by IR spectroscopy and nitrogen content and the data obtained then used to determine the reactivity ratios of the acrylamide (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and ethyl acrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) comonomers by using a Mayo and Lewis plot. The reactivity ratios of acrylamide and ethyl acrylate were found to be <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.54 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 1.10, respectively, and hence the sequence lengths of acrylamide (m̄<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and ethyl acrylate (m̄<jats:italic>M</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) in the grafted chains are arranged in an alternating form, as the product of the reactivity ratios of acrylamide and ethyl acrylate (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> × <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) is less than unity. The rate of graft copolymerization of the comonomers onto cellulose was found to be dependant on the ‘squares’ of the concentrations of the comonomers and on the ‘square root’ of the concentration of ceric ammonium nitrate. The energy of activation (Δ<jats:italic>E</jats:italic><jats:sub>a</jats:sub>) of graft copolymerzation was found to be 5.57 kJ mol<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> within the temperature range from 15 to 50 °C. On the basis of the results, suitable reaction steps have been proposed for the graft copolymerzation of acrylamide and ethyl acrylate comonomers from their mixtures. Copyright © 2005 Society of Chemical Industry</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of Styrene and Methyl Methacrylate with Lithium as Initiator
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Copolymers of styrene and methyl methacrylate prepared with lithium dispersion as initiator do not contain random sequences of both monomers. Fractionation of the copolymers with acetonitrile and the NMR spectra of the insoluble fractions show that these are block copolymers which consist of a polystyrene portion and a poly(methyl methacrylate) portion. When the copolymerization is stopped at low conversion the copolymer has a high styrene content, which sometimes exceeds the value expected for radical copolymerization. This fact would indicate that styrene is preferentially polymerized at the early stages of chain propagation. When the copolymerization is carried to high conversion some crosslinked polymer is formed which contains more styrene than the soluble part of the same experiment. When a piece of metallic lithium is used as initiator, it is found that the crosslinked polymer is formed on the surface of the metal. The addition of lithium phenoxide or β‐naphthoxide to the system eliminates the formation of crosslinked polymer. A possible mechanism is proposed.</jats:p>

Title: Solvent effect on the methacrylic acid‐methyl methacrylate radical copolymerization. Analytical estimation by linear and nonlinear solvation energy relationships
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The calculated methacrylic acid‐methyl methacrylate monomer reactivity ratios in toluene (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 1,06 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,10 ± 0,01), isopropyl alcohol (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,33 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,78 ± 0,03), acetone (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,63 ± 0,02; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,31 ± 0,02) and acetonitrile (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MA</jats:sub> = 0,46 ± 0,03; <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>MMA</jats:sub> = 0,27 ± 0,03) depend strongly on the polarity, proton donor and proton acceptor ability of the solvent. It is proved that the solvent influence on the logarithm of the relative comonomer reactivities is expressed much better by the linear relationships of the solvatochromic polarity, proton donor and proton acceptor indexes than by the dependences reflecting these effects individually. The possibility of a statistically confident description of the complex solvent influence on the comonomer reactivities by quadratic solvatochromic relationships taking into account the interdependence of solvent effects is shown for the first time.</jats:p>

Title: Preparation of monomers functioning as initiators and use of their polymers for graft copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>New types of esters of methacrylic acid functioning as radical initiators, α,α′‐azobis(α‐methylbenzyl) dimethacrylate (<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>) and 1,1′‐azobis(1‐methylethyl) dimethacrylate (<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>), were synthesized by reaction of the corresponding chlorides with salts of methacrylic acid. These monomers<jats:bold>1</jats:bold>and<jats:bold>2</jats:bold>were utilized to produce copolymers containing the respective azoinitiator units. Decomposition of the initiator units in the presence of a second monomer resulted in graft copolymers. Polystyrene and poly(methyl methacrylate) were grafted onto the polymers bearing α‐azo‐α‐methylbenzyl units. Poly(styrene‐<jats:italic>graft</jats:italic>‐diisopropyl fumarate) was prepared by decomposition of polystyrene containing 1‐azo‐1‐methylethyl units in the presence of monomeric fumarate at 150 and 180°C. The number of the grafting sites along the main chain was estimated on the basis of the molecular weight of the polymer, the content of the initiator unit, and the decomposition rate.</jats:p>

Title: Polymerization and Polymers of Itaconic Acid Derivatives. V. The Copolymerization Reactivity of Itaconic Acid in an Aqueous Solution
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The copolymerization of itaconic acid with acrylonitrile has been carried out in aqueous solutions of three different pH values. From the composition data obtained, the monomer reactivity ratios and the Q-e values have been calculated. The results indicate that itaconic acid, when ionized to the second-step dissociated form, is able to copolymerize with other monomers, while it is almost completely unable to homopolymerize.</jats:p>

Title: Polar effects in radical polymerization of vinyl monomers; radical copolymerization of several p‐substituted vinyl benzoates
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The mutual radical copolymerizations of several <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted vinyl benzoates such as vinyl <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐methoxy‐, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐methyl‐, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐chloro‐, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐bromo‐, and <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐cyanobenzoate and vinyl benzoate were carried out at 60°C. The monomer reactivity ratios were determined by the method of F<jats:sc>INEMAN</jats:sc> and R<jats:sc>OSS</jats:sc>. The relative reaction rates of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted vinyl benzoates to a given poly‐vinyl‐<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted benzoate radical plotted against H<jats:sc>AMMETT'S</jats:sc> σ‐values gave straight lines. The linear relationships and small ρ‐values show in contrary to <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituted styrenes that <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituents in this case have only a little polar effect on the vinyl group and on the polymer radical which are separated from the aromatic ring through the carboxyl‐group, and on the exaltation of resonance stabilization of polymerizing species at transition state. The observed σ‐values were correlated with the ρ‐values of <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐substituents on the polymer radicals. Polymers and copolymers of these monomers were hydrolysed to give polyvinyl alcohol.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of trialkylvinyltin compounds
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The polymerizations of trimethylvinyltin (TMSnV) and tributylvinyltin (TBSnV) were carried out with the use of γ‐ray, radical, or ionic initiators. These monomers did not undergo the polymerization by themselves, but they did copolymerize with styrene (St) or methyl methacrylate (MMA) when a radical initiator was used. From the results obtained by the copolymerization, monomer reactivity ratios and <jats:italic>Q–e</jats:italic> values were obtained as follows: for the system St(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)TMSnV, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 44.8, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.001, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.005, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.962; for the system MMA (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)TMSnV, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 25.1, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.036, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.933; for the system St(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)TBSnV, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 16.0, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.005, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.017, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.822; for the system MMA(M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)TBSnV, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 27.9, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.03, <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.031, <jats:italic>e</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.822. The abilities of TMSnV and TBSnV to polymerize are discussed on the basis of the <jats:italic>Q</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>e</jats:italic> values obtained.</jats:p>

Title: Amine‐derivatized poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) from N‐vinylformamide copolymerization
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The reactivity ratios for the aqueous free‐radical copolymerization of diallyldimethylammonium chloride and <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylformamide were found to be 0.13 and 1.92, respectively, from a Fineman–Ross analysis of a series of batch polymerizations. Because batch polymerization could not give a uniform product in a high yield with two monomers of such different reactivities, a semibatch procedure was developed in which the more reactive <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylformamide was added in 10 steps over the course of the copolymerization. The poly(diallyldimethyl‐ ammonium chloride‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐vinylformamide) copolymers were hydrolyzed to give poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride‐<jats:italic>co</jats:italic>‐vinylamine). The utility of the vinylamine/diallyldimethylammonium chloride copolymers was demonstrated by the preparation and characterization of three derivatives: (1) a copolymer with coupled dansyl groups for fluorescence detection; (2) a copolymer with coupled dabsyl groups for ultraviolet–visible detection; and (3) an ultra‐high‐molecular‐weight (1.6 × 10<jats:sup>6</jats:sup> Da) poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) by chain extension (coupling) with glycerol diglycidyl ether. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Appl Polym Sci 104: 1068–1075, 2007</jats:p>

Title: Mechanochemically initiated copolymerizations, 10. Kinetic data on the copolymerization of the acrylonitrile/vinyl acetate/α‐methyl styrene ternary system by vibratory milling
Abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The kinetics of mechanochemical copolymerization of the ternary system based on acrylonitrile, vinyl acetate, and α‐methyl styrene, by vibratory milling activation was studied. A general relation for expressing the reaction rate is proposed as follows:
<jats:disp-formula>

</jats:disp-formula>
Kinetics has been followed by measuring the amount of unreacted monomer by gas chromatography. Partial reaction orders – related to each comonomer, had almost unitary values, being determined from the conversion‐time curves for 7 ternary systems with different comonomer ratios. The values of the reaction rate constant – taken for three temperatures – permitted the computation of the activation energy (18.82 kJ mol<jats:sup>‐1</jats:sup>), such a low value showing that the contribution of the thermal energy in this type of synthesis is unsignificant.</jats:p>

Abstract: No abstract available

Title: Photosensitized copolymerization of optically active N‐l‐menthylmaleimide with styrene and methyl methacrylate
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Photosensitized copolymerization of optically active <jats:italic>N</jats:italic>‐<jats:italic>l</jats:italic>‐menthylmaleimide (NMMI) with styrene (Sty) and methyl methacrylate (MMA) was carried out in tetrahydrofuran (THF) at 30°C with benzoyl peroxide (BPO). The monomer reactivity ratios for the copolymerization of NMMI (M<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) with Sty (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) and MMA (M<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>) were <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 0.08 ± 0.10, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.20 ± 0.05 and <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>1</jats:sub> = 2.85 ± 0.06, <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 0.07 ± 0.06, respectively. Copoly‐MMA–NMMI and poly‐NMMI showed positive circular dichroism(CD) curves of equal intensity and shape over the wavelength region from 230 to 270 nm; copoly‐Sty–NMMI also showed a positive CD curve which was similar in shape but was different in intensity from that of poly‐NMMI. The correlation between monomer unit ellipticity of the copolymers and their composition would suggest the alternating and stereoregular copolymerization of NMMI with Sty.</jats:p>

Title: Copolymerization of 2‐methylene‐4‐phenyl‐1,3‐dioxolane with electrophilic vinyl monomers through zwitterionic mechanism
Abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Spontaneous copolymerization of cyclic ketene acetal, 2‐methylene‐4‐phenyl‐1,3‐dioxolane (<jats:bold>I</jats:bold>) with common electrophilic vinyl monomers, such as methyl α‐cyanoacrylate (MCA), acrylonitrile (AN), and methyl methacrylate (MMA) were investigated to further explore zwitterion polymerization method with cyclic ketene acetals. In the reaction of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> with MCA and AN, spontaneous copolymerization took place at ambient temperature. The copolymers of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> with MCA gave low molecular weight polymers, but copolymers obtained with <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> and AN were high molecular weight polymers. In the reaction of <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> and MMA, high molecular weight copolymer was obtained only at temperatures above 80°C. Thus, obtained polymers were not the alternating copolymers and possessed high <jats:bold>I</jats:bold> content in all the cases. From the above results, macrozwitterionic mechanism was suggested as discussed.</jats:p>
